questions.text:
A 42-year-old female presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, associated with nausea and vomiting for 2 days. She has a fever and tachycardia. Her serum lipase is 1200 U/L, total bilirubin is 4.2 mg/dL and direct bilirubin is 3.1 mg/dL. The diameter of the Common Bile Duct is 10 mm on ultrasound as shown below. What is the most appropriate next step in management after giving IV fluids and analgesics?

ERCP - Early Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography
MRCP - Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography
questions.solution:
Severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, nausea & vomiting, and elevated serum lipase points raise suspicion for Acute Pancreatitis. Dilation of the Common Bile duct (CBD) on Ultrasound and elevated bilirubin suggests gallstone pancreatitis. The immediate next step in this patient with gallstone pancreatitis should be ERCP within 24-48 hours.

Early ERCP addresses the underlying biliary obstruction, reduces the risk of cholangitis, and decreases the length of hospital stay. Indications for urgent ERCP include:

  • Cholangitis
  • Persistent biliary obstruction
  • Worsening liver function tests
  • Common bile duct stone visible on imaging

Specific indications for ERCP present in this specific patient with gallstone pancreatitis:

  • Dilated CBD (>8mm)
  • Rising bilirubin
  • No signs of resolution

Other Options:

Option A: Acute inflammation increases surgical risks, and there is an urgent need to address ongoing obstruction first. Cholecystectomy is indicated after the resolution of acute episodes, usually during the same admission.

Option B: While supportive care is essential, this patient has evidence of biliary obstruction. Conservative management alone is appropriate for mild pancreatitis without obstruction.

Option C: MRCP is diagnostic in function and not therapeutic. It can be considered if ERCP is unsuccessful or anatomy is unclear.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought with a high fever and noisy breathing. The child had a cough and cold for the past few days. A lateral x-ray of the neck showed a soft tissue swelling and widening of the prevertebral shadow. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the widening of prevertebral shadow on a lateral x-ray of the neck in a 2-year-old child suggests a diagnosis of retropharyngeal abscess. 

An acute retropharyngeal abscess commonly occurs in children below 3 years of age due to infections of adenoids or tonsils, causing suppuration in the retropharyngeal lymph nodes, which leads to abscess formation. Since the retropharyngeal lymph nodes disappear after this age, an adult retropharyngeal abscess is uncommon and usually occurs secondary to trauma.

The clinical features of a retropharyngeal abscess include dysphagia, dyspnea, stridor, croupy cough, torticollis (extended stiff neck), and unilateral swelling on the midline of the posterior pharyngeal wall. The lateral view of the radiograph shows soft tissue swelling and the widening of the prevertebral shadow. The extent of the abscess can be visualised on a contrast-enhanced CT scan.

Treatment is usually done by incision and drainage of the abscess and antibiotics. Tracheostomy is required in cases of a large abscess causing obstruction to the airway or leading to laryngeal oedema. 

The image below shows a retropharyngeal abscess seen on a lateral x-ray of the neck:

Other options:

Option A - Parapharyngeal abscess can occur from acute and chronic infections of the tonsils like dental infections, Bezold abscess, petrositis, trauma to the neck, and infections of the parotid, retropharyngeal and submaxillary spaces. Patients with anterior compartment involvement present with prolapse of the tonsil and tonsillar pillar, trismus, and swelling of the parotid region. Patients with posterior compartment involvement present with bulges of the pharynx behind the posterior pillar; paralysis of cranial nerves IX, X, XI, and XII and sympathetic chain; and swelling of the parotid region. Symptoms common to both compartments are fever, odynophagia, sore throat, torticollis, and signs of toxaemia. The extent of a lesion can be revealed by a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the neck. 

The image below shows an enhanced CT scan revealing a large mass involving the left parapharyngeal and retropharyngeal spaces, causing significant airway narrowing.

Option C- Peritonsillar abscess/quinsy is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx. It presents with severe pain in the throat, fever, chills and rigours, and a hot potato voice. There is congestion and swelling of the tonsil, pillars, and soft palate on the involved side. On examination, a bulging of the soft palate and anterior pillar above the tonsil can be seen. Uvula may be pushed to the opposite side. The presence and the extent of the abscess can be identified on a contrast-enhanced CT scan or MRI. 

The image below shows a peritonsillar abscess.

Option D- Acute epiglottitis is an acute inflammatory condition involving the epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, and arytenoids (supraglottic structures). It is usually caused by Haemophilus influenzae and group A beta-hemolytic streptococci. The symptoms have an acute onset with a rapid progression. These include fever, sore throat, dysphagia, dyspnea, and stridor. Indirect laryngoscopy shows oedema and congestion of the supraglottic structure. A lateral x-ray of the neck shows swollen epiglottis (thumb sign).

Below is an image showing the thumb sign on a radiograph:

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: Given below is a dissected heart specimen of a middle-aged man showing the internal structure of the right atrium and ventricle. The structures marked as 1 and 2 are the remnants of which of the following structures respectively?
questions.solution:
The structures marked as 1 and 2 are the limbus and floor of fossa ovalis, which are the remnants of septum secundum and septum primum respectively.

Fossa ovalis is an oval-shaped depression in the septal wall of the right atrium just above the opening of the inferior vena cava. It marks the location of the embryonic foramen ovale. 

  • The floor of fossa ovalis is the remnant of the septum primum.
  • The limbus of the fossa ovalis is the prominent upper margin of the fossa ovalis. It is a remnant of the septum secundum.

Related Pearl: Development of Interatrial septum

  • The Inter-atrial septum develops from Septum Primum and Septum Secundum
  • The septum primum begins to develop at 28 days. It is a thin, crescentic fold of endocardium that arises craniodorsally and grows down to the AV cushions, leaving an ostium primum below its free edge.
  • Septum primum fuses with the AV cushions at approximately 35 days, obliterating the ostium primum.
  • The ostium secundum is an opening in the upper part of the septum primum. It forms at about 33 days, i.e., before the ostium primum closes.
  • The septum secundum is a thick muscular septum that arises to the right of the septum primum. It grows from the roof of the atrium but does not reach the AV cushion. The gap between the two septa is known as foramen ovale.
  • After birth, the foramen ovale is obliterated by the fusion of the septum primum with the septum secundum.
  • In terms of adult anatomy, the annulus ovalis/limbus of fossa ovalis is the lower free edge of the septum secundum, while the floor of fossa ovalis represents the septum primum.

Related Pearl: Remnants of Various Embryonic Parts of the Cardiovascular System

Embryonic part

Remnants

Ductus arteriosus

Ligamentum arteriosum

Umbilical artery

Proximal part: Superior vesical artery; Distal part: Medial umbilical ligament

Umbilical vein (left)

Ligamentum teres

Ductus venosus

Ligamentum venosum

Septum primum

Floor of fossa ovalis

Septum secundum

Lower free edge: Annulus ovalis

 curved upper Margin: limbus fossa ovalis

questions.text: Your consultant is on a ward round with you, and he is worried about his post-operative patient going into septic shock. Which laboratory test would best inform your team about this patient’s tissue perfusion?
questions.solution:
Lactate levels and base deficit are key laboratory parameters to assess tissue perfusion. 

In septic shock, tissue hypoperfusion leads to anaerobic metabolism, resulting in increased lactate production. Measuring serum lactate is crucial because it serves as an early indicator of shock before other vital signs deteriorate. It helps assess the severity of hypoperfusion and monitor the response to resuscitation. Persistent lactic acidosis is associated with higher morbidity and mortality. The degree of lactic acidosis (measured by serum lactate level and the base deficit) is sensitive for both diagnosing shock and monitoring the response to resuscitation.

Base Deficit (negative base excess) is another useful marker of metabolic acidosis in shock. A base deficit >6 mmol/L suggests significant cellular hypoxia and worse outcomes. Furthermore, the length of time in shock with an increased base deficit is important, even if all other vital signs and parameters have returned to normal.

The table below represents stages of shock based on the base deficit level:

Stage of Shock Lactate (mmol/L) Base Deficit (mmol/L) Clinical Features
Compensated (Stage 1) Normal (<2) 0 to -2 Tachycardia, normal BP, mild metabolic acidosis
Mild Shock (Stage 2) 2–4 -2 to -6 Hypotension, increasing tachycardia, cool extremities
Moderate Shock (Stage 3) 4–6 -6 to -10 Worsening hypotension, reduced urine output, confusion
Severe Shock (Stage 4) >6 <-10 Multi-organ failure, refractory shock, severe metabolic acidosis

Other Options:

Option A: pH can be influenced by respiratory compensation, renal function, and metabolic disorders. It does not provide a direct measurement of anaerobic metabolism or tissue hypoxia.

Option B: pO₂ reflects oxygenation in the blood but does not indicate whether tissues utilize oxygen effectively. A patient can have normal or even high pO₂ but still have poor tissue perfusion due to shock-related microvascular dysfunction.

Option D: Bicarbonate can be decreased in metabolic acidosis from various causes (e.g., renal failure, diarrhea, ketoacidosis), making it less specific for tissue hypoxia.

questions.text:
A 55 year old male with SIADH is admitted to the hospital due to severe hyponatremia and requires vasopressin receptor antagonist therapy. The patient is initially started on a vasopressin receptor antagonist intravenously in the acute setting, followed by oral therapy for management. Based on this scenario, which of the following statements is correct regarding the drugs used?

1. Conivaptan is used intravenously in the acute setting to rapidly correct sodium levels.

2. Tolvaptan is used orally for management of euvolemic and hypervolemic hyponatremia.

3. Both drugs are selective V2 receptor antagonists.

4. Tolvaptan requires close monitoring of liver function.
questions.solution:
The correct statements include 1,2,4.

1. Conivaptan is a non-selective V1a and V2 receptor antagonist administered intravenously in acute settings for rapid correction of hyponatremia.

2. Tolvaptan is an oral selective V2 receptor antagonist. Both Conivaptan and Tolvaptan are used for the management of euvolemic and hypervolemic hyponatremia while they are contraindicated in hypovolemic hyponatremia.

3. Conivaptan is non-selective, acting on both V1a and V2 receptors, whereas Tolvaptan is selective for V2 receptors.

4. Tolvaptan has a risk of hepatotoxicity and requires close monitoring of liver function.

Conivaptan is reserved for hospitalized patients requiring acute sodium correction via IV administration.

Tolvaptan, though effective orally, has a black box warning for liver toxicity and must not be used for more than 30 days. Both drugs necessitate careful monitoring of serum sodium to prevent complications such as osmotic demyelination syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to clean a blood spill in the emergency room?
questions.solution:
Sodium hypochlorite, a compound of chlorine, is the best disinfectant for surface blood spills. It is used with a concentration of 0.5-5%.

If the spill contains large amounts of blood or body fluids, clean the visible matter with disposable absorbent material and discard the contaminated materials in appropriate, labeled containment. 

A 1:10–1:100 dilution of 5.25%–6.15% sodium hypochlorite (i.e., household bleach) or an EPA-registered tuberculocidal disinfectant has been recommended for decontaminating blood spills. 

Phenolic compounds (option B), Quaternary ammonium compounds (option C) and Alcoholic compounds (option D) are not effective in blood spills.

Related Pearl: Methods of sterilisation

questions.text: The image below shows finding seen on eliciting plantar reflex in a patient in the neurology ward. All of the following signs may be seen in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The image shows extensor plantar response (positive Babinski sign), suggestive of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Fasciculations are seen in lower motor neuron lesions (not UMN).
 
UMNs refer to corticospinal tract neurons and brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons. Injury to UMNs lead to:
  • Spasticity
  • Hypertonia 
  • Hyperreflexia
  • Abnormal plantar extensor reflex (positive Babinski sign).
Babinski sign refers to dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of other toes when the lateral aspect of the sole of the foot is scratched. It is a sign of an upper motor neuron lesion. In normal adults, the response is plantar flexion of all the toes.
 

The image below shows a positive Babinski sign in an adult, which is abnormal and indicative of a UMN lesion. 

In infants whose corticospinal tracts are still underdeveloped, dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of other toes is a normal response to scratching of the sole of the foot.

The image below shows an extensor response in an infant, which is normal.

Related Pearl: Features of Motor Neuron Lesions

Upper Motor Neuron Lesion

Lower Motor Neuron Lesion

Upper motor neuron typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons

Lower motor neurons are those whose axons terminate on skeletal muscles

Little or no muscle wasting → weakness of relatively large group of muscles

Muscle atrophy → muscle weakness of an individual and specific muscle

Hypertonia

Hypotonia

Increased or exaggerated deep tendon reflexes (hyperreflexia)

Hyporeflexia or areflexia

Spasticity

Flaccidity

Positive Babinski sign (abnormal plantar extensor reflex)

Fasciculations

questions.text: A 38-year-old farmer is bitten by an insect whose life cycle is as portrayed below. He develops a characteristic eschar at the site of the bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and a maculopapular rash 2 weeks later. A positive serological diagnosis for this condition is made using agglutination with antigens from which of the following species?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing characteristic eschar with lymphadenopathy and rash, along with the life cycle of a trombiculid mite (which acts as the vector), is suggestive of scrub typhus. It gives a positive Weil-Felix reaction with OX K agglutinins, which are derived from Proteus mirabilis.

Scrub typhus, also known as chigger-borne typhus, is caused by Rickettsia or Orientia tsutsugamushi. The vector is trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. The incubation period is 1–3 weeks. The patient typically develops a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash.

Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction, wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Proteus strains—Proteus vulgaris strains OX19 and OX2 and Proteus mirabilis strain OXK. The basis of the test is sharing an alkali-stable carbohydrate antigen by some rickettsiae and some strains of Proteus.

OXK is agglutinated only in scrub typhus.

questions.text: The banding technique used for staining the telomeres of chromosomes is:
questions.solution:
The banding technique used for staining the telomeres of chromosomes is T banding.

Karyotyping is the process by which chromosomes are isolated, stained, and examined to find chromosomal anomalies. It is used in prenatal diagnosis, investigation of repeat pregnancy loss, investigation of children and adults suspected of having a chromosomal disorder, and subtyping of lymphomas and leukemias for the purpose of exact diagnosis, giving a prognosis, and treatment. Various techniques are used in karyotyping to study chromosomes. Staining with various compounds produces various results and helps us to understand the chromosomes better. Common techniques used are:

  • Q banding - Fluorescence staining with quinacrine mustard
  • G banding - Giemsa staining after partial denaturation of chromatin. It is the most common technique used in cytogenetics to produce a visible karyotype.
  • R banding - Reverse Giemsa staining. In this, the light and dark areas are reversed
  • C banding - Staining of heterochromatin with silver salts
  • T banding - Staining the telomeres of chromosomes

questions.text: An adolescent girl complains of dropping objects from her hands, these are precipitated during early morning hours and exams, and the frequency of such jerks increases whenever she is sleep-deprived. There is no history of loss of consciousness. One of her cousins has been diagnosed with epilepsy. What can be the most likely EEG finding in this case?

choices.text: 1-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep

questions.solution:
The diagnosis here is juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME), which is characterized by isolated jerks, usually involving both arms; the jerks can be as subtle as finger twitches, but in this case, they manifest as dropping objects. 4-5 Hz epileptic spikes can be seen on the EEG in this condition.

Factors supporting the diagnosis:

  • The hallmark seizures in JME are myoclonic jerks, which are most frequent in the morning.
  • Consciousness is preserved.
  • The myoclonus in JME is epileptic, as opposed to physiologic or essential.
  • Patients may have reflex seizures triggered by various types of stimuli, such as writing, reading, praxis, or higher mental activities, and aggravated by sleep deprivation.
Disease Typical EEG feature
Lennox-Gastaut syndrome
  • 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves
  • polyspike bursts in sleep
  • slow background in wakefulness
Absence seizures 3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern)
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy 4-5 Hz spike
West syndrome Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background)

questions.text: A 3-day-old newborn, previously admitted to the NICU for transient tachypnea, is now exhibiting jitteriness. A capillary blood glucose check reveals a level of 98 mg/dL. Given the mother’s history of diabetes mellitus and insulin requirement during her pregnancy, what would be the next best step in managing this infant?

choices.text: Start a glucose infusion rate of 6 mg/kg/min
Send blood samples for vitamin D and parathyroid hormone levels

questions.solution:
This patient has normal glucose levels and jitteriness. Jitteriness is most likely due to hypocalcemia in infants of diabetic mothers. So, the best next step would be to administer intravenous 10% calcium gluconate to this patient.

During the first three days after birth, infants may appear jittery, tremulous, and hyper-excitable. Other symptoms can include hypotonia, lethargy, and poor feeding. While the early onset of these signs is typically associated with hypoglycemia, they can also be caused by hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia, which may occur within the first 24 to 72 hours of life due to delayed parathyroid hormone response.

Hypoglycemia occurs in a few infants born to mothers with gestational diabetes, but only a small number of these infants exhibit symptoms. Hypoglycemia can last for up to 72 hours, and in rare instances, it may persist for as long as 7 days. To treat hypoglycemia, frequent feeding is often effective, although some infants may require intravenous dextrose.

Additionally, perinatal asphyxia is linked to increased irritability and raises the risk of hypoglycemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypocalcemia. Infants born under these circumstances are also at risk for:-

  • congenital anomalies
  • macrosomia
  • renal vein thrombosis
  • small left colon syndrome
  • polycythemia
  • prolonged hyperbilirubinemia

Other Options:

Option B: Beta blockers are given in symptomatic infants with Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy born to diabetic mothers.

Option C: This patient has normal glucose levels, ruling out hypoglycemia. So, glucose infusion is not required.

Option D: This patient has symptoms of Hypocalcemia. So, calcium correction should be done immediately. If hypocalcemia persists, Vitamin D & PTH levels can be checked to evaluate the cause of hypocalcemia.

questions.text: A target group is being tested by three screening tests for breast cancer as a part of a research program. The patient is considered diseased if she tests positive in all of the screening tests. Which of the following is false about this combination of screening tests?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario where the patient is considered diseased only if she is positive on all three tests, the combination of screening tests is said to be in series. The false statement is that it has high sensitivity. The net sensitivity is low for a screening test conducted in series.

The combination of two or more tests performed together can help to enhance the efficacy of detecting the presence or absence of disease. There are two principal forms of combination of tests:

Screening tests used in series:

  • If a patient is considered to have a disease when he is positive by every test conducted, then the tests are said to be in series.
  • If the patient tests negative in any one or more of the tests, they are classified as non-diseased.
  • It is thus difficult to classify a patient as diseased and easier to classify a patient as non-diseased.
  • With a decrease in sensitivity, there is an increase in the number of false negatives. This higher number of false negatives lowers the sensitivity.

Screening tests used in parallel:

  • If a patient is considered to have a disease when he is positive by any one or more tests, then the tests are said to be in parallel.  
  • Only if the patient tests negative on all the tests, they are classified as non-diseased.
  • Hence, some without disease are more likely to be wrongly classified into the diseased group, but many without disease are correctly excluded.
  Tests in Series Tests in parallel
Combined sensitivity Decreases Increases
Combined specificity Increases Decreases
Combined PPV Increases Decreases
Combined NPV Decreases Increases

Sensitivity is the ability of the test to correctly identify all individuals with the disease. It corresponds to the true positive cases out of a total diseased population.

Specificity is the ability of a test to correctly identify all individuals without the disease. It corresponds to the true-negative cases out of a total disease-free population.

The predictive tests are indicative of the validity of the tests and reflect the diagnostic value. A positive predictive value refers to the cases truly positive for the disease out of the total positive cases. A negative predictive value refers to the cases truly negative for the disease out of the total negative cases. 

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman who has not been able to conceive for the past 7 years is subjected to diagnostic laparoscopy. Findings indicate - a normal uterus, the presence of a cyst with dark brown tar-like content in the Left ovary, blackish burn-like deposits on the left round ligament & moderately dense adhesions between fallopian tubes & pouch of Douglas. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Laparoscopic findings of extensive adhesions, features suggestive of a Left ovarian chocolate cyst & endometrial deposits on the round ligament - all indicating a diagnosis of Endometriosis. Infertility in such cases of endometriosis is not responsive to medical therapy & definitive management involves Adhesiolysis + Fulguration of endometriotic deposits.

Other options:

Option A: Use of MIRENA IUCD would only reduce the menorrhagia & dysmenorrhea due to endometriosis.

Option B: NSAIDs & COC pills would only help with dysmenorrhea & can shrink the size of the endometrial deposits. They further delay pregnancy.

Option C: Hysterectomy with bilateral oophorectomy is reserved for women who have completed childbearing.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of diplopia, restricted eye movements, and inability to close the lids of his left eye. He previously sustained chemical burns to the same eye. On examination, the eye appears as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of diplopia, lagophthalmos, restricted eye movements with a history of chemical burns to the same eye and the image shown indicates a diagnosis of symblepharon.

It refers to the partial or complete adhesion of the palpebral conjunctiva to the bulbar conjunctiva. These adhesions occur when raw surfaces on two opposed areas of the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva remain in contact as they heal. The raw surfaces appear following chemical injuries, burns, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, ulcers, diphtheria, ocular pemphigus or eye surgeries.

Most patients present to resolve the cosmetic disfigurement caused as a result of this condition but can also have restricted eye movements, resulting in diplopia and an inability to close the lids, i.e. lagophthalmos.

When the bands of fibrous tissue subsequently formed between the lid and the globe involve the fornices, it is called symblepharon posterior. When they are present anteriorly, it is called symblepharon anterior. Sometimes, the lids may be completely adherent to the globe, in a condition called total symblepharon.

This condition is mostly managed surgically. The attachments are released and the raw areas are covered with a conjunctival, buccal mucous membrane or amniotic membrane grafts. A therapeutic contact lens or symblepharon ring may also be used to separate the raw surfaces.

The prevention of symblepharon by the early and frequent use of a glass rod or therapeutic bandage contact lens is of the utmost importance.

Other options:

Option A: Ankyloblepharon involves the presence of adhesions between the margins of the two lids.

Option B: Blepharophimosis is a condition where the palpebral fissure appears to be smaller than normal.

Option D: Ectoprion refers to the outward turning of the lid margin. Patients present with epiphora as the primary symptom, especially when the lower lid is involved. Other symptoms include local irritation, discomfort and mild photophobia when associated with chronic conjunctivitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is detected by TLR-5 (Toll-like Receptor 5)?
questions.solution:
TLR 5 (Toll-like Receptor 5) can recognize the flagellin in bacteria.

In humans, ten TLRs have been found that have unique microbial recognition patterns. They are as follows

  • TLR 1 and 6 detect diacyl peptides.
  • TLR 2 recognizes various ligands like lipoteichoic acid expressed by the gram-positive bacteria.
  • TLR 3 engages double-stranded viral RNA in viral replication.
  • TLR 4 is specific for gram-negative lipopolysaccharide.
  • TLR 5 can recognize the flagellin in bacteria.
  • TLR 7 and 8 interact with single-stranded RNA in viral replication.
  • TLR 9 binds to both viral and bacterial DNA.
  • TLR 10 is an orphan receptor.

Related Pearl: Innate and Adaptive Immunity

Innate immunity

Adaptive immunity

Immediate maximal response

Lag phase between exposure and maximal response

Non-specific

Highly pathogen-specific

Limited diversity

Extensively diverse

No memory

Memory present

Subsequent exposure → Amplified response

Receptors: Pattern-recognition receptors

Receptors: T-cell and B-cell receptors

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic woman was admitted for right knee arthroplasty. On the 7th postoperative day, she developed a fever and cough with purulent, blood-tinged sputum. Her chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following would be the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the chest-Xray showing lobar consolidation with bulging fissure sign are suggestive of late-onset hospital-acquired pneumonia most likely caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae.

K. pneumoniae causes lobar pneumonia in alcoholics and diabetics. The patient characteristically presents with fever, dyspnea, and a productive cough with red currant jelly sputum.

Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or nosocomial pneumonia is a lower respiratory infection that presents clinically 2 or more days after hospitalization and was not there at the time of admission. It can further be classified as:

  • Early-onset HAP, which occurs within 4-5 days of admission and is commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Enterobacter species, Escherichia coli, etc.
  • Late-onset HAP occurs >5 days after hospital admission and is usually caused by gram-negative bacteria like Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Klebsiella spp, and Acinetobacter baumannii.

Pneumonia caused by Klebsiella species shows the following classic chest X-ray findings:

  • Upper lobe consolidation - classically on the right side.
  • Cavitation
  • Bulging fissure sign - expansive lobar consolidation and inflammatory exudates cause the lower border of the upper lobe to bulge. It can also be seen with space-occupying lesions of the lung, such as pulmonary hemorrhage, lung abscess, and tumor. 

The following image shows a bulging fissure sign.

 

Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be used for treatment and include third-generation cephalosporins and beta-lactam antibiotics with beta-lactamase inhibitors. Nosocomial infection with Klebsiella is difficult to treat in many situations as they produce extended-spectrum beta-lactamase and are resistant to many antibiotics.

Other options:

Option B: Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common causative agent of community-acquired pneumonia.

Option C: Legionella pneumophila causes community-acquired pneumonia and early-onset hospital-acquired pneumonia.

Option D: Coxiella burnetii is the causative agent of Q-fever.

questions.text: Which of the following water-associated diseases is wrongly matched?
questions.solution:
Cholera is a water-borne disease.

Water-related diseases are classified as:

Category

Examples
Water-borne diseases

Caused by ingestion of water contaminated by human or animal feces, or urine containing pathogenic bacteria or viruses

e.g.: Cholera, typhoid, amebic and bacillary dysentery, and other diarrheal diseases
Water-washed diseases

Caused by poor personal hygiene

e.g.: Scabies; trachoma; flea-, lice- and tick-borne diseases, in addition to the majority of water-borne diseases (which are also water-washed)
Water-based diseases

Caused by parasites found in intermediate organisms living in water

e.g.: Dracunculiasis, schistosomiasis, and some other helminths.

 
Water-related vector-borne diseases 

Caused by vectors that breed in water

e.g.: Dengue, filariasis, malaria, onchocerciasis, trypanosomiasis and yellow fever

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with Mycosis fungoides. Which of the following is not part of the clinical phases of mycosis fungoides?
questions.solution:
The vesicle phase is not part of the clinical phases of mycosis fungoides. 

Mycosis Fungoides is a lymphoma of helper T-cells. Three clinical stages of mycosis fungoides are recognised:

  • Patch phase (pre-mycotic phase): Barely palpable, minimally erythematous, pigmented, well-defined patches. It may have geographic shapes. There may be cigarette paper atrophy and poikiloderma.
  • Plaque phase: Some areas of the lesion become infiltrated, and this may be associated with itching.
  • Tumor phase: Firm to hard nodules usually appear on the plaques but may arise de novo (tumor d’emblee). Nodules may ulcerate. The tumour stage is usually rapidly progressive.

The image given below shows phases seen in mycosis fungoides.

Histological hallmarks include:

  • Sézary-Lutzner cells - cells with cerebriform nuclei (infolded/ hyper-convoluted nuclear membrane).
  • Pautrier's microabscesses are collections of atypical lymphocytes in the epidermis. Tumour cells invade the epidermis as single cells or small clusters.
  • Epidermotropism - the invasion of the tumour cells into the epidermis.

The image given below shows histological markers seen in mycosis fungoides:

Variants: Sezary syndrome is an erythrodermic variant of Mycosis fungoides. It consists of a triad of:  

  • Generalized cutaneous erythema (erythroderma) and oedema with extreme pruritus.  
  • Lymphadenopathy.
  • Sezary cells (abnormal lymphocytes with large convoluted nuclei) circulating in the blood.

questions.text: A patient underwent total laryngectomy for laryngeal cancer. Identify the modality of voice production involved in the device shown in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The modality of voice production shown in the given image is the electrolarynx.

The electrolarynx produces vibrations that are transmitted through the skin towards the throat. The sound generated is converted into low-pitch speech by the vocal tract—palate, tongue, and teeth. The advantages are that is easy and quick to learn, while the disadvantages are that the voice is monotonous and requires constant occupation of one hand.

Other options:

Tracheoesophageal prosthesis (option A) - The exhaled air from the trachea is diverted to the oesophagus via a device that connects the trachea and oesophagus. It has a one-way valve, which prevents food from entering the trachea. A variety of tracheoesophageal prostheses are available, including the Provox, Blom-Singer, and Panje devices.

 

Oesophageal speech (option D) - The patient is trained to swallow air and slowly release it into the pharynx. 6-10 words can be spoken in a rough manner before re swallowing the air.

A transoral pneumatic device (option B) is an artificial larynx used in those who fail to learn oesophageal speech. The vibrations generated in a rubber diaphragm are carried by a plastic tube into the back of the oral cavity. Here the sound is converted into speech by modulators. It uses expired air from the tracheostome to vibrate the diaphragm.

questions.text:
A patient presented with a passage of cola-colored urine and abdominal pain. Flow cytometry of the blood of a patient revealed the following findings? Which of the following can be used in the management?

Data of the Patient in Red
Data of Normal individual in Black
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the history of the passage of cola-colored urine and abdominal pain with the flow cytogram showing a population of red blood cells deficient in both CD55 and CD59 is suggestive of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). Eculizumab can be used in the management of PNH.

Есսlizumаb is a monoclonal antibody that binds to complement protein C5, preventing cleavage into C5a and C5b. Blocking the formation of C5b inhibits the subsequent formation of MAC.

Other options

Option B: Emicizumab is used in the management of hemophilia A.

Option C: Rituximab is used in the management of CLL

Option D: Trastuzumab is used in the management of breast cancer.

Flow cytometry 

Flow cytometry is used to identify cellular antigens expressed by tumors that arise from blood-forming tissues. These include B-cell and T-cell lymphomas and leukemias as well as myeloid neoplasms. An advantage of flow cytometry over immunohistochemistry is that multiple antigens are assessed simultaneously.

Below is the explanation of how to interpret flow cytometry results:

Interpretation of results:

  • Quadrant 1- Cells marked in green: -VE for A antigen, +VE for B antigen
  • Quadrant 2- Cells marked in purple: -VE for both the antigens.
  • Quadrant 3- Cells marked in yellow: +VE for both the antigens.
  • Quadrant 4- Cells marked in red: +VE for A antigen, -VE for B antigen

questions.text:
Assertion (A): In tumour lysis syndrome (TLS), there is a decrease in serum calcium levels.
Reason (R): The release of excessive phosphate from lysed tumour cells leads to the formation of insoluble calcium phosphate complexes, reducing serum calcium.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation for A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation for A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, but R is true

questions.solution:
In Tumour Lysis Syndrome(TLS), rapid tumour cell lysis releases large amounts of intracellular contents, including phosphate. Excessive phosphate binds to serum calcium, forming insoluble calcium phosphate complexes, leading to hypocalcemia. This is a key feature of TLS pathophysiology.

Electrolyte imbalances in TLS: 

  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hypocalcemia

TLS is a potentially life-threatening emergency and usually occurs 12-48 hours after initiating chemotherapy. It can also happen before starting chemotherapy in patients with a heavy tumour burden.

The metabolic abnormalities can cause arrhythmias, cardiac arrest, and acute kidney injury. Treatment chiefly involves adequate hydration to increase the glomerular filtration rate. This allows the excretion of the metabolites associated with tumour lysis.

questions.text: What is the use of Langelier's index?

choices.text: To assess the quality of air by measuring concentrations of pollutants
To assess quality of water by estimating hardness, total dissolved solids, alkalinity & pH
To assess quality of soil for viability of growing crops
To assess quality of milk by estimating the coliform count in sample

questions.solution:
The quality of water with respect to its corrosive/ scale-forming potential is given by the Langliers saturation index (SI). This index depends on :

  • Water temperature
  • Total dissolved solids
  • Alkalinity / pH
  • Calcium hardness

Interpretation:

  • SI between -0.3 and +0.3: Water is considered stable (neither corrosive nor scale-forming).
  • SI < -0.3: Water is corrosive, dissolving materials such as pipes and surfaces.
  • SI > +0.3: Water is scale-forming, which deposits minerals on surfaces.

This index is used in industrial water systems, such as boilers and cooling towers, to prevent damage caused by corrosion or scaling. It helps maintain infrastructure and water quality in municipal water supply systems.

Other Options:

Option A: Air quality is typically assessed using indices like the Air Quality Index (AQI).

Option C: Tests such as soil fertility tests and soil texture analysis are used to determine if the soil is suitable for agriculture.

Option D: Tests like the Methylene Blue Reduction Test (MBRT), Standard Plate Count (SPC), and Resazurin test are used in milk quality assessment.

questions.text: The test below depicts the presence of which of the following defect in the left eye?
questions.solution:
The test shown is the uncover test. There is the abduction of the left eye on uncovering it (refixation movement is abduction) which suggests left esophoria. 

Uncover test: This is used to detect heterophoria (latent squint). The test is performed for both near and distant as follows.

  • The patient fixates on a distant target straight ahead.
  • The examiner covers an eye for 2-3 seconds and the cover is then removed.
  • If the covered eye had deviated, a re-fixation movement is observed on being uncovered.
  • The following are the possible results based on the re-fixation movements of the eye.
Movement of the eye Suspected defect
No movements Orthophoria

Adduction

(Nasal recovery)

 Exophoria
Abduction Esophoria
Downward Hyperphoria
Upward Hypophoria
  • The speed and smoothness of the recovery are noted as well as evidence of the strength of motor fusion.
  • The test is then repeated for the opposite eye.

Cover Test: This is used to detect heterotopia (manifest squint). Light is first shone and corneal reflections are observed. This is done to assess fixation in the deviating eye. The procedure for testing using an accommodative target and for distance is as follows.

  • The patient is asked to fixate a target straight ahead.
  • The eye in which deviation is not suspected is covered first. For example, if a right eye deviation is suspected, the left eye is covered.
  • Any movement of the right eye to take up fixation is noted.
  • The following are the possible results:
Movement of the eye Suspected defect
No movements Orthotopic/ Heterotopia of the covered eye
Adduction Exotropia
Abduction Esotropia
Downward movement Hypertropia
Upward movement Hypotropia

The test is then repeated for the opposite eye.

Classification of Strabismus 

  • Pseudostrabismus—Apparent squint
    • Pseudo esotropia
    • Pseduo exotropia
  • Heterophoria—Latent squint
    • Esophoria: Convergent
    • Exophoria: Divergent
    • Hyperphoria: Deviation upwards
    • Hypophoria: Deviation downwards
    • Cyclophoria: Rotation around AP axis
  • Heterotropia—Manifest squint
  • Concomitant
    • Amount of deviation remains constant in all directions of gaze.
    • Esotropia: Convergent
      • Infantile
      • Accommodative
      • Sensory
      • Consecutive
    • Exotropia: Divergent
      • Congenital
      • Primary
      • Secondary: Sensory deprived
      • Consecutive
    • Hypertropia: Vertical squint
  • Incomitant
    • Amount of deviation varies in different directions of gaze
      • Paralytic squint
      • Restrictive squint
      • A and V pattern heterotropia

 

Related Pearl: Cover tests in ophthalmology

Cover–uncover test:

  • To detect the presence of heterophoria: Latent squint
  • One eye is covered with the occluder, and the other eye is made to fix an object.
  • In the presence of heterophoria, the eye under the cover will deviate.
  • When the cover is removed, the eye under the cover will return back to its normal.
  • This movement is observed.
  • The direction of movement determines the type of heterophoria.

Direct Cover test:

  • Confirms the presence of manifest squint.
  • Differentiates apparent squint from a manifest squint.
  • The patient is asked to fixate on the point light.
  • The normal-looking eye is covered.
  • In manifest squint, the uncovered eye will move in the opposite direction to take fixation.
  • In apparent squint, there will be no movement of the uncovered eye.

Alternate cover test:

  • In the below image, the patient has right exotropia with left eye fixating.
  • Both eyes move each time the cover alternates from one eye to the other.
  • It reveals if the squint is unilateral or alternate.
  • It differentiates between concomitant and paralytic squint.

questions.text: All of the following cause a left shift of the oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve except -
questions.solution:
Body temperature of 39 degrees celsius (hyperthermia) causes a right shift of the oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve. 

The oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve is a plot of the partial pressure of O2 and the % saturation of Hb with O2. It is normally sigmoid in shape. If the oxygen haemoglobin dissociation curve is shifted to the right, it means that the affinity of Hb for O2 has become less which favours O2 delivery. This means a higher P50, means higher PO2 is required to maintain 50% saturation (R - Right shift Releases oxygen). If the curve is shifted to the left, it means that affinity has increased for O2 ( which favours O2 binding ) i.e. lower P50 value. ( L-Left shift Leashes oxygen )

 Causes for the right shift of the oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve are:

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - metabolically active tissues utilize O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis
  • Growth hormone, thyroid hormone, androgen - by increasing 2,3 DPG
  • Sickle cell anaemia - reduced affinity for O2
  • Exercise

Causes for the left shift of the oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve are:

  • ↑ pH (alkalosis)
  • ↓ PCO2
  • ↓ 2,3-DPG
  • ↓ Temperature 
  • HbF
  • Carboxyhemoglobin

Bohr's effect - The decrease in O2 affinity of haemoglobin when the pH of the blood falls.

Haldane effect - Increased capacity of deoxygenated haemoglobin to bind and carry CO2.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with complaints of high fever and night sweats. His area is endemic for malaria. His blood sample is being investigated and two types of smears have been prepared as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Thick film is to identify parasite species
Both the films are used to identify parasite species
Thin film is used to find parasite when it is scanty
Thick film is used to find parasite when it is scanty

questions.solution:
In the given image, A is a thin smear and B is a thick smear. B/ Thick smear is used to find the malarial parasite when it is scanty. This is because more volume of blood is being scanned in the thick smear.

Both types of smears are made during microscopy for malaria detection. Thick smear is used to detect infection and estimate parasite concentration.Thin smear is used to identify particular infecting species of Plasmodium.

Microscopy has high sensitivity and specificity, therefore it is the best method for diagnosis of malaria.

questions.text: A 22-year-old mother delivers her baby at home in a rural village. During the delivery, no clean or sterile practices were followed, and the newborn did not receive any immediate medical care. Approximately 24 hours after birth, the baby is brought to the emergency department with severe respiratory distress, grunting, and poor feeding. The infant appears lethargic, with a weak cry, and a pale, mottled skin. Which of the following statements is not accurate in the context of managing early-onset neonatal sepsis?

choices.text: Ampicillin is generally included in the empirical treatment of neonatal sepsis
Antibiotics can be initiated even without waiting for the culture report
Lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid analysis is warranted even in the absence of neurological symptoms
Urine culture is mandatory to detect bacterial colonization or infection

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests early-onset neonatal sepsis. Urine culture is optimally obtained after 72 hours of life and is not beneficial for diagnosing early-onset sepsis. It is primarily indicated for evaluating late-onset sepsis.

Early-onset neonatal sepsis (EONS) occurs within the first 72 hours of life. It presents with neurological symptoms (e.g., drowsiness, lethargy, seizures), respiratory distress (e.g., tachypnea, grunting), poor perfusion, and gastrointestinal issues (e.g., poor feeding, abdominal distension).

A septic screen is an initial step in evaluating suspected neonatal sepsis and typically includes:

  • Complete Blood Count (CBC): Leukocytosis or leukopenia with a left shift.
  • C-reactive protein (CRP) and Procalcitonin: Elevated levels may indicate infection.
  • Blood Culture: Gold standard for detecting bacteremia.
  • CSF Analysis: Mandatory even without overt neurological symptoms to rule out meningitis.
  • Chest X-ray: If respiratory symptoms are present.

Empirical antibiotic therapy should begin immediately without waiting for culture results. Ampicillin (for Listeria and Enterococcus) and gentamicin (for gram-negative coverage) are standard choices. Cephalosporins are avoided due to Listeria resistance. The identification and antibiotic susceptibility of the causative organism guide definitive therapy for neonatal sepsis. The choice of antibiotics and the duration of treatment depend on the specific pathogen isolated and the site of the infection.

questions.text:
Match the following clinical images with the corresponding diagnoses.
  1. Nevus of Ito
  2. Congenital melanocytic nevus
  3. Nevus of Ota
  4. Becker nevus
questions.solution:
Option B has the correctly matched set of images and diagnoses.

1 Nevus of Ito
2 Congenital melanocytic nevus
3 Nevus of Ota
4 Becker nevus

Image 1- shows a unilateral blue-greyish hyperpigmented macule on the shoulder, which is suggestive of nevus of Ito. It affects the acromioclavicular region and upper chest. It is distinguished from the nevus of Ota by its location in the area innervated by the posterior supraclavicular and lateral cutaneous brachial nerves. 

Image 2 shows a dark blackish pigmented lesion over the back of an infant, which is suggestive of congenital melanocytic nevus. Congenital melanocytic nevi are benign, pigmented, melanocytic nevi present at birth. Lesions are dark at birth and are usually palpable with increased surface markings. It has a slightly higher predisposition in females.

Image 3 shows bluish-brown pigmentation around the eye. This is nevus of Ota. It is a dermal melanocytosis that mainly affects the sclera and skin around the eyes. They are generally distributed along with the ophthalmic and maxillary divisions of the trigeminal nerve. It is commonly seen in females. 

Image 4 shows a large, pigmented hairy patch on the shoulder, which is suggestive of Becker nevus. Becker nevus is an epidermal melanocytic nevus. It is classically seen as a hyperpigmented, brownish patch over the scapular area on the back, shoulders, outer arms, and chest. It is usually associated with hypertrichosis and sometimes with acne. It is more common among males. It has an onset around adolescence, when there is an increased sensitivity to androgens.

questions.solution:
