questions.text: Identify the type of surgery shown in the image given below and the condition in which it is performed.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Blalock–Taussig shunt, an aortopulmonary shunt procedure involving a Gore-Tex conduit anastomosed side to side from the subclavian artery to the homolateral branch of the pulmonary artery. Blalock–Taussig shunt is performed in patients with Tetralogy of Fallot.

It augments pulmonary blood flow, decreases hypoxia, improves linear growth, and improves the vascularity of the pulmonary arteries. Sometimes, the shunt is brought directly from the ascending aorta to the main pulmonary artery, known as the central shunt.

Post-operative complications include:

  • Chylothorax
  • Diaphragmatic paralysis
  • Horner syndrome
  • Cardiac failure

The original Blalock-Taussig shunt was performed via direct anastomosis of the subclavian artery to the pulmonary artery. Long-term problems associated with it, like absent radial pulse and arm length discrepancy, are rarely seen with the current procedure.

The Blalock-Taussig shunt is a palliative systemic-to-pulmonary artery shunt and is usually reserved for patients with comorbidities, such as other major congenital anomalies or prematurity, that would make the full repair a higher-risk option.

Name of the surgery Used in Connects
Blalock–Taussig shunt (BS) Tetralogy of Fallot Subclavian artery to pulmonary artery
Waterston's shunt (WA) (option A) Tetralogy of Fallot Ascending aorta to right pulmonary artery

Pott's shunt (PD) (option B)

Pulmonary hypertension

 Descending aorta to left pulmonary artery
Glenn shunt (option C) Tricuspid atresia, Hypoplastic left heart syndrome Superior vena cava to pulmonary artery

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient complains that he feels he is no longer in control of his body and thoughts. He says he hears his own thoughts aloud a short time after thinking them, for the last two years. He stopped going to college 6 months ago because he feels everyone can hear his thoughts and know what he is thinking all the time. Examination reveals disorganized speech. He has no history of drug abuse. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of loss of control of body and thoughts, thought broadcasting, disorganized speech and delusions is suggestive of schizophrenia.

The loss of control of the body and thoughts is known as the passivity phenomenon. The patient being able to hear his thought for the last two years is known as thought echo which is a form of auditory hallucination. The feeling that everyone can hear his thoughts is called thought broadcasting which is a disorder of thought process. All these signs point towards the diagnosis of schizophrenia.

Schizophrenia is a disorder comprised of a group of characteristic symptoms like delusions, hallucinations, negative symptoms, disorganized lifestyle, and continuous signs of these disturbances for at least 6 months. 

Dopamine excess is believed to play an important role in the development of the disease. A genetic component is also suspected to be contributory.

The symptoms are mainly divided into positive or negative symptoms. The positive symptoms include hallucinations, delusions, and motor disturbances. The negative symptoms include anhedonia, alogia, flattening of affect, apathy, and poverty of speech.

DSM-5 criteria for schizophrenia:

A. ≥2 of the following symptoms of which at least one of these is either 1, 2, or 3:

  1. Delusion
  2. Hallucinations
  3. Disorganized speech
  4. Grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior
  5. Negative symptoms

B. Level of functioning in one or more major areas of functioning such as work or social life is markedly below the level it used to be before the onset of the disturbance.

C. Continuous signs of disturbance for at least 6 months.

D. Schizoaffective disorder and depressive or bipolar disorder with psychotic features have been ruled out.

E. Disturbance cannot be explained by substance abuse or any other medical condition.

F. If there is a positive history of autism spectrum disorder or a communication disorder since childhood, diagnosis of schizophrenia is made only if the delusions or hallucinations are very prominent.

Anti-psychotics are the mainstay of treatment. They mainly act by antagonizing the postsynaptic dopamine receptors in the brain. Psychosocial therapy also plays an important role and can augment clinical improvement. Some cases may require short stays at the hospital either for patient safety or for stabilization of medications.

There are several factors that affect the prognosis of schizophrenia:

Good prognosis Bad prognosis
Late/acute onset Early/insidious onset
Mood disorder symptoms Withdrawn, autistic behavior
Family history of mood disorders  Family history of schizophrenia
Positive symptoms Negative symptoms
Married Single, divorced or widowed
  Neurological signs and symptoms
  Many relapses

Other options:

Option A- Schizoaffective disorder can be diagnosed when manic or depressive syndrome develops concurrently with major symptoms of schizophrenia. 

Option B- Schizophreniform disorder is described as acute psychiatric symptoms as in schizophrenia that were reactive and occurred in persons with relatively normal personalities that last at least 1 month but less than 6 months. 

Option D- Delusional disorder is characterized by the presence of one or more non-bizarre delusions (false beliefs that are possible but not true) lasting for at least one month. There is no significant impairment in functioning apart from the delusions.

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

Differential diagnosis of DSM-5 psychotic disorders

Psychotic disorder

 Criteria for diagnosis
Brief psychotic disorder

Sudden onset and a full return to function

Duration: > 1 day and < 1 month
Schizophreniform disorder

Same symptoms as schizophrenia and functional decline not required

Duration: > 1 month & < 6 months
Schizophrenia

Requires functional decline

At least 6 months (includes at least 1 month of active symptoms, can include prodromal and residual periods)
Schizoaffective disorder

With concurrent mood episode. Active-phase symptoms of schizophrenia with at least a 2 weeks of lifetime history of delusions or hallucinations in absence of prominent mood symptoms
Delusional disorder

One or more delusions for > 1 month

No other psychotic symptoms and normal functioning apart from the direct impact of delusions
Shared psychotic disorder (folie a deux)

Development of delusions in a person who is in a close relationship (ex: spouse, child) with someone who has a delusional disorder (the inducer)

 

Related Pearl: Symptoms of schizophrenia

Positive symptoms Negative symptoms
Hallucination
Delusion
Bizarre motor acts
Flattening of affect
Anhedonia
Alogia
Apathy
Paucity of thought
Poverty of speech
Common in acute schizophrenia Common in chronic schizophrenia
Hyperactivity of the dopaminergic system in the mesolimbic system Hypoactivity of the dopaminergic system in the mesocortical system
Respond to most typical and atypical antipsychotics Respond better to atypical antipsychotics

questions.text: A neurosurgeon uses the following forceps to hold the fascia and galea aponeurotica during craniotomy. Identify it.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Allis' tissue forceps. It is used to hold skin flaps, fascias, fibrous tissue, aponeurosis, galea, and bladder wall. Delicate structures like bowel or vessel walls are avoided due to the risk of tearing. So, Allis' forceps can be used to hold the fascia and galea aponeurotica during craniotomy, to hold skin flaps and bladder wall, and to hold the vaginal wall during hysterectomy.

 Identifying points:

  • The distal blades are not opposing each other.
  • The tip has teeth in each blade that are opposing.
  • The proximal part has a ratchet/lock.  

Other important forceps used in surgery: 

i) Lane’s tissue-holding forceps

  • Stout and thick distal blades, with an oval fenestra in each blade
  • Opposing tooth in the tip
  • Lock in the proximal part

Uses:

  • Hold bulky and tough structures, hold lymph nodes

ii) Babcock’s forceps:

  • The distal part of the distal blade is curved with a triangular fenestra which allows soft tissues to bulge out.
  • The tip is non-traumatic with transverse serrations on it.
  • It has got a lock in the proximal part
  • Used to hold any part of the bowel, fallopian tube, appendix, ureter, cord, etc.

iii) Kocher’s hemostatic forceps:

Opposing tooth in the tip and serrations in the distal blades.

Uses:

  • Hold pedicles, tough structures, cut ends of muscles
  • Hold ribs during rib dissection, hold gauze for blunt dissection, and hold resected bowel. 

iv) Lister’s sinus forceps 

  • Used for blunt dissection.
  • During Hilton's method of abscess drainage to break the bacterial loculi.
  • Used for inserting or removing packing in the sinus cavity.

v) Sponge-holding forceps: 

  •  Clean skin with a swab dipped in antiseptic solution during all operations
  • Removing laminated membrane and the daughter cysts during operation of hydatid cyst.
  • Hold the fundus and Hartmann’s pouch of gall bladder during cholecystectomy
  • Swab an abscess cavity.
  • To hold the cervix during cerclage

vi) Desjardin’s choledocholithotomy forceps: 

  • Used for bile duct stone removal. It may also be used during the removal of kidney, ureteric, or bladder stones.

This is a long and slender instrument. There are finger bows but no catch. The shaft is curved. The blades are small, without serrations, and fenestrated centrally. 

vii)  Cord holding forceps typically used to hold spermatic cords.

viii)  Pile holding forceps used to hold hemorrhoids.

questions.text: Large quantities of which of the following hormones stimulates the maternal thyroid gland during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The hormone hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) stimulates the maternal thyroid gland during pregnancy.

Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is a hormone secreted in pregnancy. It is a glycoprotein similar in structure to LH, FSH, and TSH. It is produced by the syncytiotrophoblast of the placenta. hCG maintains the corpus luteum for secretion of estrogen and progesterone till 13 to 17 weeks after conception and plays a role in maintaining early pregnancy. 

The maternal thyroid hormone is stimulated by large quantities of hCG. Acidic isoforms of hCG stimulate thyroid activity, and more basic isoforms stimulate iodine uptake. The LH-hCG receptor is also expressed by thyrocytes, which suggests that hCG stimulates thyroid activity via the LH-hCG receptor. 

hCG can be detected in the blood by radio-immunoassay as soon as 8 to 9 days after ovulation. Its level peaks at 10 to 12 weeks of pregnancy and then falls by the 16th to 20th week. It remains at this low level for the rest of the pregnancy. 

In pregnancy, both hormones estrogen and progesterone are secreted in large quantities by the placenta. Estrogen levels rise steadily throughout pregnancy. However, from the seventh month onwards, progesterone secretion remains constant. Thus, the estrogen-to-progesterone ratio increases towards the end of pregnancy, as depicted by the estrogen curve crossing the progesterone curve towards the latter half of pregnancy.

Prolactin rises to a peak just adjacent to parturition.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented with pain and swelling in the knee joint. The physician advised for the examination of synovial fluid from the knee joint on polarized light microscopy, which showed needle-shaped crystals. What is the composition and birefringence pattern shown by these crystals?

choices.text: Monosodium urate crystals with negative birefringence
Calcium pyrophosphate crystals with negative birefringence
Calcium oxalate crystals with positive birefringence

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the presence of needle-shaped crystals in synovial fluid point towards the diagnosis of gouty arthritis. It is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals (MSU), which are needle-shaped and show negative birefringence on polarized light microscopy.

The below image shows negative birefringent needle-shaped crystals seen in gout.

Other options:

Option A- Calcium apatite crystals can occur in areas of tissue damage (dystrophic calcification) and in hypercalcemic or hyperparathyroid states (metastatic calcification). Clumps of these crystals may appear as intra- or extracellular nonbirefringent globules or aggregates that stain purplish with Wright’s stain and bright red with alizarin red S.

Option C- Calcium pyrophosphate crystals (rhomboid-shaped) deposition is seen in pseudogout. These crystals are rod-shaped or rhomboid-shaped and are weakly positive or nonbirefringent crystals.

Option D- Calcium oxalate crystals (CaOx) are seen in chronic renal failure. These crystals can be deposited in visceral organs, blood vessels, bones, and joints. The synovial fluid analysis will show the presence of variable-shaped crystals (commonly bipyramidal crystals are seen) with variable birefringence to polarized light.

NOTE:

Though pseudogout is the condition in which the knee joint is most commonly involved, gout can also involve the knee joint.

Below image shows the crystals seen in pseudogout.

Related Pearl: Difference between Gout and Pseudo-gout

Finding

Gout

Pseudogout

Crystal composition

Monosodium urate

Calcium pyrophosphate

Shape

Needle like

Rhomboid

Birefringence pattern

Negative

Weak positive

Most commonly affected joint

1st MTP

Knee

X-ray findings

Periarticular erosions with overhanging margins

Chondrocalcinosis

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with repeated episodes of red-eye, eye pain, and blurred vision. The image of his eye is given below. What is the finding seen in the image?
questions.solution:
In this patient with repeated episodes of red-eye, eye pain, and blurred vision, there is a nodule on the pupillary edge of the iris prompting suspicion of uveitis and making it likely that it is a Koeppe nodule.

Anterior uveitis is the inflammation of the anterior portion of the uveal tract consisting of the iris and anterior ciliary body. It is most often associated with HLA-B27 positive conditions such as Behcet disease and sarcoidosis. Patients usually present with ocular pain, circumcorneal congestion, photophobia, etc.

Anterior uveitis is characterized by: 

  • Koeppe nodules - lymphocytic infiltrates at the pupillary margin
  • Busacca nodules - lymphocytic infiltrates at collarette 
  • Keratic precipitates (KP) - proteinaceous deposits on the corneal endothelium. These are pathognomonic for anterior uveitis. Types of KP's include - 
    • Mutton fat type - seen in granulomatous uveitis
    • Granular type - seen in non-granulomatous uveitis
  • Aqueous flare - diffuse inflammation with exudates in the anterior chamber. It is the earliest sign of non-granulomatous uveitis

The exudates can also pour out into the posterior chamber causing the iris to adhere posteriorly to the lens. When the adhesions organize to become fibrous, it becomes firm and is known as posterior synechiae.  A dilating/mydriatic agent causes the remaining pupillary portions, that have not become attached, to dilate irregularly giving the classic appearance mentioned above. 

Cycloplegics such as atropine and homatropine and steroids are the mainstay of treatment. Complications such as complicated cataracts, secondary glaucoma, and phthisis bulbi (soft and atrophic eye) can be seen. 

Other options:

Option A: Brushfield spots refer to small white speckles on the peripheral iris that are arranged in a concentric ring. They are seen in Down’s syndrome and may sometimes be a normal finding in blue eyes. The image below shows Brushfield spots.

Option C: Lisch nodules are small well-defined nodules that are seen in neurofibromatosis. They are present bilaterally and appear as clear, yellow, or brown elevations above the iris surface.

Option D: Busacca nodules are present on the iris stroma. They are seen in granulomatous uveitis.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents to the outpatient department with fever, epigastric discomfort, progressive weight loss, arthralgia, and foul-smelling diarrhea for the past 6 months. There is no relation between the abdominal pain and his bowel movements. He was started on a restrictive diet, which showed no improvement. His biopsy is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is whipple disease which is caused by a gram-positive actinomycete, named Tropheryma whipplei.

Whipple's disease is a chronic multisystem disorder caused by a gram-positive bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. It presents as 

  • Diarrhea
  • Steatorrhea due to malabsorption caused by impaired lymphatic transport.
  • Weight loss
  • Arthralgia
  • Central nervous system problems
  • Cardiac problems

The morphologic hallmark of whipple disease is a dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria. Macrophages contain periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant granules that represent lysosomes stuffed with partially digested bacteria.

Other options:

Option A: Irritable bowel syndrome presents with recurrent abdominal pain that may be - 

  • related to defecation
  • associated with a change in frequency 
  • associated with a change in appearance

Despite having these symptoms, the endoscopy and microscopic examination are normal in patients with irritable bowel syndrome.

Option C: Cystic fibrosis is a congenital disorder due to a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene located on chromosome 7. It leads to abnormal transport of chloride and bicarbonate ions in the lungs, gastrointestinal tract, pancreas and reproductive tract. It presents as

  • Lungs - recurrent respiratory infections. 
  • Pancreas - exocrine pancreatic insufficiency causing fat malabsorption and steatorrhoea. 
  • Reproductive tract - infertility due to absent vas deferens.

Option D: Celiac disease is an autoimmune gluten-induced enteropathy where there is an excessive inflammatory response to gluten and its breakdown product, gliadin. This leads to inflammatory infiltration of the lamina propria which subsequently impairs various nutrient absorption.

Clinically, it presents as a malabsorption syndrome with diarrhea, abdominal pain, and marked weight loss. Microscopic findings show

  • Villi atrophy
  • Villi flattening
  • Crypt hyperplasia
  • Increased intraepithelial T lymphocytes

Symptoms usually subside with a gluten restricted diet.

Image: Microscopic image of celiac disease

Related Pearl: Investigations in Malabsorption Syndrome

The following are the general tests for malabsorption:

Disorder Investigation
Fat malabsorption

Quantitative: 24h fecal fat >7g

Qualitative: Sudan III staining

C14 Triolein breath test

Fecal steatocrit
Carbohydrate malabsorption

D-xylose test

Lactose hydrogen breath test
Protein malabsorption C13 egg-white breath test

The following are the specific tests for malabsorption:

Disorder Investigation
Celiac disease

Anti-tissue transglutaminase (anti-tTG)

Anti-endomysial antibodies

Mucosal biopsy showing villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, lamina propria infiltrates, and normal mucosal thickness.
Whipple's disease Mucosal biopsy showing PAS +ve macrophages in lamina propria
Pancreatic insufficiency

Fecal elastase

Fecal chymotrypsin
Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO)

Due to Enterobacter or Pseudomonas - jejunal aspirate >103 CFU

Due to other organisms - jejunal aspirate >105 CFU

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents, who are concerned that he frequently bumps into objects, especially in dim lighting. They have also noticed that his eyes sometimes appear misaligned. What instrument will he use to check the red reflex?
questions.solution:
The red reflex is seen with a direct ophthalmoscope.

The red reflex is the reddish-orange reflection seen when light is shined into the eye, typically using an ophthalmoscope. It occurs due to light reflecting off the retina’s blood-rich choroid layer. A normal red reflex indicates a clear visual pathway from the cornea to the retina. 

A direct ophthalmoscope examines the fundus of the eye, including the retina and optic disc. It provides a magnified, upright image, allowing for detailed assessment of eye conditions. It is commonly used to check the red reflex, helping detect conditions like cataracts and retinoblastoma in children. While it is portable and easy to use, its small field of view limits comprehensive retinal evaluation compared to indirect ophthalmoscopy.

A white, dull, or asymmetric reflex may indicate leukokoria (white reflex). Leukokoria or white pupillary reflex warrants immediate ophthalmologic evaluation and is seen in a variety of pathologic conditions, including:

  • Congenital Cataract
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Retinopathy of prematurity ( Retrolental fibroplasia)
  • Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous
  • Coats Disease
  • Toxocara endophthalmitis

Other Options:

Option B: Indirect Ophthalmoscope is used for examining the peripheral retina and fundus with a wide field of view.

Option C: Slit Lamp is used for detailed examination of the anterior segment of the eye, including the cornea, lens, and anterior chamber.

Option D: Maddox Rod is used in the evaluation of ocular alignment and binocular vision, particularly for detecting and measuring phorias and tropias.

Related Pearl: Difference between direct and indirect ophthalmoscopy

FEATURE DIRECT OPHTHALMOSCOPE  INDIRECT OPHTHALMOSCOPE
Condensing lens Not required Required
Examination distance As close to the patient's eye as possible At an arm's length
Image Virtual, Erect Real, Inverted
Magnification 15 times 4-5 times
Illumination Not so bright, so not useful in hazy media Bright, so useful in hazy media
Area of the field in focus About 2 disc diameter About 8 disc diameter
Stereopsis Absent Present
Accessible fundus view Slightly beyond equator Up to ora serrata
Examination through hazy media Not possible Possible

questions.text:
Match the following drugs with their indication.
Drug Indication
i. Plecanatide a. Opioid-induced constipation
ii. Naldemedine b. Chronic Idiopathic Constipation (CIC) in adult
iii. Tenapanor c. Irritable bowel syndrome with constipation  
iv. Telotristat d. Severe diarrhea due to Carcinoid tumors.

choices.text: i - a, ii - b, iii - d, iv - c
i - d, ii - a, iii - c, iv - b
i - c, ii - a, iii - b, iv - d
i - b, ii - a, iii - c, iv - d

questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are i - b, ii - a, iii - c, iv - d.

  Drug Indication
i. Plecanatide b) Chronic Idiopathic Constipation (CIC) in adult 
ii. Naldemedine a) Opioid-induced constipation
iii. Tenapanor c) Irritable bowel syndrome with constipation  
iv. Telotristat d) Severe diarrhea due to Carcinoid tumors. 

Plecanatide is a synthetic analog of uroguanylin and acts via activation of guanylate cyclase-C, promoting increased secretion of chloride and bicarbonate into the intestinal lumen. This agent is approved for the treatment of chronic idiopathic constipation in adults at a dose of 3 mg daily. The most common adverse reaction is diarrhea. 

Naldemedine, a derivative of naltrexone, is a peripheral opioid antagonist. It is approved for the treatment of opioid-induced constipation in adult patients with chronic noncancer pain; the dose is 0.2 mg/day orally. Common adverse reactions are abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and gastroenteritis. It is contraindicated in cases of known or suspected GI obstruction and may precipitate opioid withdrawal.

Tenapanor is an inhibitor of isoform 3 of the Na+-H+ exchanger (NHE) expressed in the GI tract. It reduces sodium absorption, increasing intestinal fluid volume and motility. This agent is approved for the treatment of constipation-predominant IBS in adults at a dose of 50 mg orally twice daily. Diarrhea, abdominal distension, flatulence, and dizziness are the most frequent side effects. It is contraindicated in children under 6 years old and not advised in older children up to 18 years of age.

Telotristat inhibits tryptophan hydroxylase, the rate-limiting enzyme in serotonin biosynthesis, reducing serotonin-induced diarrhea in carcinoid syndrome.

questions.text: As a part of cancer treatment, the patient is advised to undergo stereotactic radiotherapy using Cyberknife. Which of the following types of radiation is used in the given modality?
questions.solution:
Cyberknife is a Linear Accelerator (LinAc) attached to a robotic arm, which uses X-rays. 

Teletherapy refers to treating a condition (usually cancer) with radiation emitted from a distant source.  LinAc and Cobalt 60 are the most commonly used teletherapy modalities. 

LinAc uses X-rays instead of gamma rays (or radioisotopes). Unlike usual X-rays, LinAc increases the speed of electrons by using acceleration wave guides (synchronised radio-frequency electromagnetic fields) instead of directly accelerating potential differences. This LinAc, if mounted on an electronic robotic arm for precise therapy, is known as a Cyberknife. It is used in inoperable cranial lesions as stereotactic radiotherapy. 

Cobalt 60 undergoes beta-decay and emits 1.25 MeV (average) gamma rays, which penetrate deeper tissues while sparing skin. In a Gamma knife, multiple cobalt sources(around 201) with varying apertures are arranged in a pattern to focus on the single isocentre. The gamma knife is mainly used to treat inoperable intracranial lesions.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to a hospital. The mother provides a medical history of seizures, episodes of vomiting and diarrhoea, and inability to gain weight. She has taken the child to multiple hospitals, prompting excessive testing. On examination by the physician, all the investigations are within normal limits. What best describes this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes Factitious disorder by proxy, also known as Munchausen syndrome by proxy.

The most common case of factitious disorder by proxy involves a mother who deceives medical personnel into believing that her child is ill. Here, the affected person intentionally produces physical signs or symptoms in another person who is under his care. One apparent purpose of the behavior is for the caretaker to indirectly assume the sick role.

In battered baby syndrome, there is a purposeful delay in seeking medical attention despite serious injury, but in this case, the mother has visited multiple hospitals to lead excessive testing on the child. Therefore, this scenario is more of a factitious disorder by proxy and less of the battered baby syndrome. The injuries are inflicted by the mother not as a result of child abuse but to gain medical attention (primary gain).

Option B: Battered baby syndrome (Caffey's syndrome) is also known as child abuse syndrome, non-accidental injury of childhood, and maltreatment syndrome in children. A battered child is one who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of non-accidental violence produced by a parent or guardian; there may also be deprivation of nutrition, care, and affection. 

Option C: Munchausen's syndrome/Factitious disorder involves feigning illness or injury and going from hospital to hospital for unnecessary investigations and treatment. It is seen in the adults themselves.

Option D:  Malingering refers to mimicking a physical or clinical finding for financial/personal gain. However, factitious disorder has only one motive - seeking and attaining medical attention.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus presents to the casualty with complaints of acute chest pain. He dies after 5 hours of admission. Arrange the histological changes of his heart in sequence, starting from the earliest to the latest.

(i) Early phagocytosis of dead cells by macrophages

(ii) Variable waviness of fibres

(iii) Well-established granulation tissue

(iv) Interstitial neutrophilic infiltrates

(v) Increased collagen deposition with decreased cellularity
questions.solution:
ii-iv-i-iii-v (Option D) represents the correct sequence of histological changes in the heart of the patient.

This patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes had acute chest pain and died of cardiac arrest. This patient most likely had a myocardial infarction. The sequence of changes is seen in the histology of myocardial infarction depends on the time from the infarct. 

Definitive histological changes are first seen on light microscopy at around  4 hours since infarct. From 0.5 hrs to 4 hours, electron microscopy shows Sarcolemmal disruption, and mitochondrial amorphous densities, and light microscopy may show variable waviness of fibers.

After 4 hours, early coagulation necrosis with edema and hemorrhage may be seen on light microscopy. Contraction band necrosis with early neutrophilic infiltrate is seen from 12-24 hours.

Interstitial neutrophilic infiltrate is seen from 1-3 days.

Early phagocytosis of dead cells by macrophages occurs from Days 3 - 7. Granulation tissue is well-established between Days 10 -14. Collagen deposition with scar formation is seen from 2-8 weeks.

Related Pearl: The Temporal Evolution of the Morphologic Changes in Acute MI

Gross Features

Microscopy features

0-1/2 hr

None

EM: Relaxation of myofibrils; glycogen loss; mitochondrial swelling

LM: None

Irreversible Injury

None

EM: Sarcolemmal disruption; mitochondrial amorphous densities

LM: Usually none; variable waviness of fibers at border

4-12 hr

12-24 hr

LM: Ongoing coagulation necrosis, pyknosis of nuclei, myocyte hypereosinophilia, marginal contraction band necrosis, early neutrophilic infiltrate

questions.text: The epidemiological triad is given below. In which stage of the natural history of the disease does interaction between these occur, and what type of prevention can be implemented at this stage?
questions.solution:
The interaction between the agent, host, and environment occurs in the pre-pathogenesis stage, and primary prevention is implemented at this stage.

Natural history of disease describes the progression of a disease in an individual in the absence of treatment and is divided into two phases: a period of pre-pathogenesis and a period of pathogenesis.

  Pre-pathogenesis Pathogenesis 
Onset Occurs before the onset of the disease in humans.
Interaction between the agent, host, and environment occurs in this phase.		 It begins when the disease process has been triggered.
Clinical Stage It starts with appropriate exposure to or accumulation of factors sufficient for the disease process to begin in a susceptible host. Subclinical stage: the disease is present but asymptomatic (incubation or latency period).
Clinical stage: Symptoms manifest, and the disease progresses to recovery, disability, or death. 
Prevention Primary Prevention: 
  • Health Promotion: Encouraging healthy behaviors (e.g., balanced diet, physical activity).
  • Specific Protection:  Vaccination, avoiding risk factors (e.g., smoking cessation).
  • Secondary prevention: early diagnosis and treatment to halt disease progression
  • Tertiary prevention: rehabilitation is used to reduce disability and improve quality of life.

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention

Level

Secondary

Tertiary

Specific causal or risk factors

Late stage of disease

Reduce the incidence of disease

Reduce prevalence by shortening duration

Reduce number and impact of complications

Actions

Inhibition of emergence of socio-economic, environmental and behavioural conditions

Protection of personal and community health by eliminating risks

Early detection and intervention to minimize disability

Soften the impact of long-term disease and disability, minimize suffering

Modes of Intervention

Health education

Health promotion and specific protection

 

Diagnosis and treatment

Disability limitation and rehabilitation

Targets

questions.text: The micrograph of a section of a diseased liver, stained with Masson’s Trichrome stain,  is given below.  The arrow points to:
questions.solution:
The arrow in the above micrograph of the diseased liver points to areas of fibrosis containing collagen that is stained blue by Masson’s trichrome stain. 

The liver has a prominent (centrilobular) macrovesicular steatosis (white/clear round/oval spaces) and mild fibrosis (blue). The hepatocytes are stained red.

The differential diagnoses of centrilobular macrovesicular hepatic steatosis are:

  • Diabetes
  • Obesity
  • Alcohol

questions.text: A forensic expert explains to you that precipitin tests help in species identification. The Precipitin test is not useful for which of the following samples?
questions.solution:
Precipitin test is not performed on urine and fecal samples.

The precipitin test is used to identify the species from which the sample has been isolated. Its forensic importance is for the determination of evidence of crime.

Samples used for precipitin test are:

  • Human hair is fine, and thin, has a narrow medulla, and shows positive precipitin test. 
  • Human serum contains protein, which forms flocculation with specific antihuman serum. Here, a positive reaction is even possible with 1/1000 dilution of sample serum. Specific antiserum is made to react with the seminal fluid. A positive test will confirm human origin. 
  • Saliva: Detection of salivary stains is important in cases of strangulation, hanging, smothering, sexual offenses, theft, etc. Precipitin test can be used for species specification in saliva samples.

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: A patient was admitted for consumption of a whole packet of ferrous sulfate tablets. ABG analysis showed pH - 7.30, Na+ = 144 mEq/L, Cl- = 102 mEq/L, HCO3- = 16 mEq/L, PaCO2 = 30 mmHg. What is the likely metabolic abnormality?

choices.text: High anion gap metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation
High anion gap metabolic acidosis with respiratory alkalosis

questions.solution:
The pH indicates acidemia (pH < 7.35). Both low HCO₃⁻ (16 mEq/L) and low PaCO₂ (30 mmHg) suggest primary metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation. The likely metabolic abnormality in this patient of iron overdose is high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Iron overdose commonly causes high anion gap metabolic acidosis due to the accumulation of lactic acid and iron metabolites. Severe poisoning can lead to shock, hypoperfusion, and lactic acidosis.

This acid-base disorder is determined by calculating the anion gap and evaluating the delta ratio and respiratory compensation is calculated by Winter's formula.

1. The anion gap (AG) is calculated as:

AG = [Na+] – ([Cl-] + [HCO3-])

       = 144-(102+16)

       = 26 mEq/L (normal AG = 8-12 mEq/L); confirms high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA).

2. The delta ratio (to check for mixed disorders) is calculated as:

Delta Ratio = (Measured AG - Normal AG) / (Normal HCO₃⁻ - Measured HCO₃⁻) {Assuming Normal AG = 10 mEq/L and Normal HCO₃⁻ = 24 mEq/L}

                      = (26 - 10) / (24 - 16) = 2, which suggests HAGMA.

Delta ratio values:

  • 1-2 = pure HAGMA.
  • < 1 = HAGMA + normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA) 
  • > 2 = HAGMA + metabolic alkalosis (e.g., due to vomiting or diuretics).

3. Winter's formula for expected PaCO₂ in metabolic acidosis:

Expected PaCO₂=(1.5×HCO3−​)+8±2

                            =(1.5×16)+8= 32±2 mmHg

The actual PaCO₂ is 30 mmHg, which falls within the expected compensatory range of 30-34 mmHg. This indicates adequate respiratory compensation for metabolic acidosis; no additional respiratory alkalosis exists. 

The mnemonic MUDPILES can help remember HAGMA causes:

  • Methanol poisoning (formic acid accumulation)
  • Uremia (chronic kidney disease causing retained organic acids)
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)
  • Propylene glycol (found in antifreeze, IV medications)
  • Iron or Isoniazid overdose
  • Lactic acidosis (shock, sepsis, tissue hypoxia)
  • Ethylene glycol poisoning
  • Salicylates (aspirin toxicity, causing lactic acid and ketoacids)

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

questions.text:

1. Dabigatran A. Vitamin K
2. Apixaban B. Protamine sulfate
3. Unfractionated heparin C. Andexanet alfa

questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man has an extreme and irrational fear of heights and prefers to live on the ground floor. The thought of attending an event on the terrace of a hotel brings about intense anxiety. What are the defense mechanisms involved in this condition?
  1. Displacement
  2. Dissociation
  3. Avoidance
  4. Symbolization
  5. Reaction formation
questions.solution:
Defense mechanisms involved in this scenario are displacement, avoidance, and symbolization - 1,3,4 (Option A).

The clinical scenario of extreme fear of heights points toward acrophobia and the defense mechanisms involved in phobias are displacement, symbolization, and avoidance.

A phobia can be described as a fear that is irrational and out of proportion to the stimulus. Defense mechanisms mediate an individual's reaction to emotional conflicts and stressors. In displacement, the conflict or emotions are displaced from the actual cause to a less threatening, irrel­evant object or situation. 

The primary source of the conflict may have a direct associative connec­tion with the phobic object or situation that symbolizes it. This object is something the person can avoid and this protects the person from the anxiety attached to the original object or idea, which is the defense mechanism of symbolization.

The phobic situation or the object is usually something that the person can avoid. With the defense mechanism of avoidance, the person can escape the anxiety associated with it. 

Behavioral therapy is the most effective treatment for phobias. Insight-oriented therapy, virtual therapy, and exposure therapy are also used for the treatment of phobic disorders and specific phobias. β-receptor blockers can be used for the treatment of specific phobias, particularly if it is associated with panic attacks. Benzodiazepines can also be used but the chronic nature of the disease limits its effect. Paroxetine and sertraline can be used to manage social anxiety. 

Dissociation is the splitting of mental contents in clusters from conscious awareness. This allows the individual to support two contradictory truths while not being aware of them. An extreme manifestation of this mechanism is seen in dissociative identity disorder. 

Reaction formation is an unconscious defense mechanism in which the person develops a wish or impulse that is a direct antithesis to the ones that are harbored consciously or unconsciously. It develops against impulses that are unacceptable to the ego.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms that operate in various diseases

  • OCD - reaction formation, undoing
  • Phobia - displacement
  • Neurosis - repression
  • Grief - denial
  • Borderline personality - Splitting
  • Schizophrenia - projection
  • Enuresis - Regression

 

 

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is the Irwin-Moore sign seen in?
questions.solution:
Irwin-Moore sign is seen in chronic tonsillitis. In this sign, when pressure is applied to the anterior pillar, it expresses frank pus/cheesy material.

The classical signs of chronic tonsillitis are:

  • Irwin-Moore sign- tonsils are tiny, but pressure on the anterior pillar expresses frank pus or cheesy material.
  • Flushing of anterior pillars compared to the rest of the pharyngeal mucosa is a vital sign of chronic tonsillar infection.
  • Enlargement of jugulo-digastric lymph nodes even in the absence of acute infection is a reliable sign of chronic tonsillitis. During acute attacks, the nodes enlarge further and become tender.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with fissured tongue and cheilosis. Investigations showed reduced glutathione reductase activity. Among the following co-factors of enzyme complexes, which one is most affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario suggests riboflavin/vitamin B2 deficiency. Both FAD and FMN require riboflavin for their synthesis. Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

The active form of riboflavin is Flavin mononucleotide(FMN) and Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide (FAD). FMN is present in Complex I of ETC and FAD is present in Complex II in ETC. FAD-dependent enzymes include succinate dehydrogenase, pyruvate dehydrogenase, alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, xanthine oxidase, and acyl CoA dehydrogenase

Riboflavin is synthesised in the body by intestinal flora. Dietary sources rich in riboflavin are liver, dried yeast, egg, and whole milk. Fish, whole cereals, legumes, and green leafy vegetables are also good sources of riboflavin. Riboflavin is light-sensitive. Hence, riboflavin supplementation may be required during phototherapy for hyperbilirubinemia 

Clinical features of riboflavin deficiency include the proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries (the earliest sign of riboflavin deficiency) angular stomatitis, circumcorneal vascularisation, cheilosis, magenta-coloured tongue, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis. 

Other options:

Options B and C: NAD+ and NADP+ are derived from niacin.

Related Pearl: Biochemical Assay for Vitamin Deficiency State

Vitamin

Assay and test

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine)

RBC Trans-ketolase

Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin)

RBC glutathione reductase

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine)

RBC transaminase

Vitamin B9 (Folic acid)

FIGLU excretion/Histidine load test

Vitamin B12 (Cobalamine)

Serum methyl malonate level

questions.text: A woman treated for cervical cancer comes to the OPD for follow-up along with her 27-year-old daughter. The doctor advises the daughter to undergo a routine screening test for cervical cancer via a PAP smear. Which of the following is not true about the instrument shown below used for the same?

choices.text: Samples both endo- and ectocervical epithelia simultaneously
It is preferred for making a liquid based cytological study
Five rotations in the opposite direction are recommended
The tip is broken off and transported to the laboratory

questions.solution:
The given image shows a Cytobroom. Five rotations in the same direction are recommended.

Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. As per guidelines, screening should start at age 21. Women aged 21-29 should have a Pap smear every 3 years, while women aged 30-65 should have HPV and Pap co-test every 5 years.

Patients should abstain from vaginal intercourse, douching, tampon use, and intravaginal medications for a minimum of 24 to 48 hours before the test.

Procedure:

  • The patient is put in a dorsal position, and Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced
  • A broom simultaneously samples both endo- and ectocervix
  • The longer central bristles are inserted into the endocervical canal and collect cells there
  • The shorter bristles by the flank splay out over the ectocervix with gentle pressure during rotation
  • Five rotations in the same direction (Option C) are recommended since reversing direction may cause loss of cellular material
  • Broom devices are favored for liquid-based Pap testing.

Two liquid-based cytology (LBC) Pap tests are FDA approved- SurePath & ThinPrep. These use the tips of broom & cytobrush that are broken off and sent to the laboratory in the liquid medium for SurePath.

questions.text: A 30-year-old factory worker who is a known case of Meniere's disease is undergoing a surgical intervention for which you are to assist the ENT surgeon. After a post-aural incision, the underlying bony structure is exposed and dissected. The surgeon then asks you for an instrument to retract and hold the mastoid flaps in place. Which of these would you pick?
questions.solution:
The instrument required to retract and hold mastoid flaps is the Jansen self-retaining mastoid retractor shown in image 4, used in endolymphatic sac decompression surgery.

The first step in endolymphatic decompression surgery involves cortical mastoidectomy via a post-aural approach. After exposing and dissecting the mastoid, a mastoid retractor is used to hold the mastoid flaps in place. Mollison’s or Jansen’s self-retaining mastoid retractor may be used after incision and elevation of flaps.

Meniere’s disease (endolymphatic hydrops) is characterised by recurrent rotational episodes (vertigo), tinnitus and fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss.

Surgical procedures for Meniere’s disease include conservative procedures like decompression of the endolymphatic sac, endolymphatic shunt operation, sacculotomy (Fick’s operation) or destructive procedures like vestibular neurectomy and labyrinthectomy.

In this case, it is desirable to recommend a procedure that offers vertigo control with maximum hearing preservation (conservative procedure like endolymphatic decompression surgery)

Other options:

Image 1 shows Lempert’s endaural retractor. It is useful in an endaural approach. The lateral blades retract flaps and a central blade with holes retracts the temporalis muscle. The body of the retractor can be fixed to this central blade by its hole.

Image 2 shows Doyen’s mouth gag. It is used in tonsillectomy.

Image 3 shows Lempert’s endaural speculum. It is used to spread open the auditory meatus when giving an injection or for an endaural incision. It is like a Vienna model nasal speculum but curved.

questions.text: Which of the following factors inhibit lipoprotein lipase activity?
questions.solution:
ANGPTL3(Angiopoietin-like 3) is the factor that inhibits lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity.

ANGPLT3 inhibitor will increase the activity of Lipoprotein lipase. Familial hypertriglyceridemia (Fredrickson type 1) is characterized by LPL deficiency, causing increased triglycerides and chylomicrons. Therefore, increasing the activity of LPL by inhibiting ANGPTL3 has become an attractive pharmacological target. The drug approved by the FDA, Evinacumab (ANGPTL3 inhibitor) is used for the treatment of Homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia.

Other Options

Option A: ApoC2 is a cofactor for LPL. It is not an inhibitor of LPL.

Option B: ApoB100 is a lipoprotein synthesized in the liver and is part of VLDL, LDL, and IDL, not chylomicrons.

Option C: PCSK9 is another target for treating familial hypercholesterolemia. It internalizes LDL receptors --> Decreased uptake of LDL by liver --> Increased LDL in Circulation. PCSK9 inhibitors, Alirocumab and Evolocumab are used for familial hypercholesterolemia.

Note - Deficiency of ANGPTL3 causes a phenotype called Familial combined hypolipidemia, whose discovery led to this as a targetable factor.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate way to discard an expired cytotoxic drug?
questions.solution:
Expired cytotoxic drugs and items contaminated with cytotoxic drugs are to be returned to the manufacturer or supplier for incineration. They need to be subjected to incineration or encapsulation or plasma pyrolysis at a temperature of 1200 degrees Celsius.

In incineration, the biomedical waste material is exposed to a very high temperature inside the incinerator, converting the material into ash. This method is used to dispose of human and animal anatomical waste, soiled waste (contaminated dressings, plaster casts, cotton swabs), expired or discarded medicines, microbiological and clinical laboratory waste, etc. It is expensive and is generally used only by very large establishments. The types are rotary kiln, pyrolytic incinerator, and single chamber incinerator. Image of an incinerator is shown below.

Other options : 

Option A : Autoclaving is a method of heat sterilization. The autoclave is a device that uses steam under pressure to sterilize linen, instruments, laboratory ware, media, pharmaceutical products, aqueous solutions, surgical instruments, cardiac catheters, and implants.

Option B : Disinfection with sodium hypochlorite is performed for broken or discarded glass, including medicine vials and ampoules, unless tainted with cytotoxic wastes.

Option C : Disposal by deep burial is permitted only in rural areas which lack common bio-medical treatment facilities. Permission from the concerned authority is needed and guidelines issued by the central pollution control board should be followed. It is primarily used for the disposal of human and animal waste as well as soiled waste.

Related Pearl: Biomedical waste disposal

 Type of Waste

Contaminated waste tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles and fixed needle syringes with their needles cut), vacutainers with needles cut, and gloves.

Hydroclaving

And later, Energy recovery/Plastics to diesel or fuel oil/road-making

Not to be sent to landfill

(puncture-proof, leak-proof containers)

Treatment and Disposal Options

Needles, syringes with fixed needles, needles from needle tip cutter or burner, scalpels, blades, or any other contaminated sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. This includes both used, discarded, and contaminated metal sharps

encapsulation

 Note: Ash from the incineration of biomedical waste shall be disposed of at a common hazardous waste treatment and disposal facility. However, it may also be disposed of in a municipal landfill, if the toxic metals in incineration ash are within the regulatory quantities as defined under the Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008 as amended from time to time.

questions.text: A 30-year-old diver presents with joint pain, dizziness, and nausea after completing a deep-sea dive. The symptoms began shortly after surfacing and progressively worsened. On examination, an itchy, erythematous,  poorly demarcated patch was seen on the trunk. What is the definitive treatment for this condition?

choices.text: Aspiration of gas emboli from the affected joints

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests Decompression sickness. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT), which facilitates the absorption of nitrogen bubbles and reduces tissue damage, is the most appropriate definitive treatment for decompression sickness.

In HBOT, the increased atmospheric pressure and high concentration of oxygen help to reduce nitrogen bubble size, promote nitrogen elimination, and enhance tissue oxygenation. HBOT helps to alleviate the symptoms, such as joint pain and neurological dysfunction.

Decompression sickness is a condition that develops when there is a sudden drop in pressure around an individual. Under high pressure, gases get compressed, and their solubility increases. When a person is in a high-pressure zone for a long time, an increased amount of nitrogen gets dissolved in their tissues. If they suddenly return to a lower pressure zone, the gases escape from a dissolved state and form bubbles. These bubbles are almost entirely made of nitrogen. The bubbles can plug many small blood vessels in different tissues leading to severe pain in the tissues. 

Clinically, the patient presents with an erythematous, poorly demarcated patch, often itchy, or a more clearly circumscribed, reticular rash with cyanotic discolouration (known as cutis marmorata or livedo racemosa). It is usually present on the trunk and has a proximal distribution. Other symptoms that can be seen are cough, dyspnoea, limb pain, confusion, visual disturbances, hearing loss, nausea and vomiting.

Option A: Although fluid resuscitation is helpful for general support in decompression sickness, they do not address the underlying cause of the condition (i.e., nitrogen bubble formation). HBOT is the definitive treatment.

Option C: While corticosteroids may be used in some inflammatory conditions, they are not the first-line treatment for decompression sickness. 

Option D: Aspiration of gas emboli might be useful for air embolism caused by lung trauma or other conditions. However, in decompression sickness, gas emboli are typically nitrogen bubbles, and aspiration is not an appropriate treatment.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to OPD with a history of the lump in the left breast. On clinical examination, the size of the lump in the left breast is 9×10 cm with no discharge and no axillary lymphadenopathy.  The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump is shown in the image. Which of the following is not true about this condition?

choices.text: Axillary dissection is done in malignant type
They present as large, sometimes massive with bosselated surface
They remain mobile on the chest wall

questions.solution:
The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture which is suggestive of phyllodes tumor. Axillary dissection is not done if malignant transformation occurs because the lymphatic spread is rare.

Phyllodes tumors usually occur in women over the age of 40 years but can appear in younger women.Phyllodes tumor is mostly benign even though it is also called as cystosarcoma phyllodes or as serocystic disease of Brodie. They are usually mobile over the chest wall despite their large size. Histologically, there is a wide variation with some of low malignant potential and others having a higher mitotic index.

Treatment of phyllodes tumor:

  • Benign type- Enucleation or wide local excision
  • Massive tumors, recurrent tumors and malignant type- Mastectomy

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman complains of progressive hearing loss, which aggravated during pregnancy. Pure tone audiometry reveals a Carhart's notch and she is diagnosed with otosclerosis. Identify the procedure done for this patient's condition.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a stapedotomy procedure performed in the middle ear.

It can be identified as a stapedotomy procedure by the following features in the image given:

  • The footplate of the stapes is not removed
  • The prosthesis is placed by creating a hole in the footplate of the stapes

Stapedotomy is the excision of the superstructure of stapes and drilling a hole in the footplate & placing a piston in the hole. It is done to bypass the immobile stapes using a piston which will take over the function of conducting sound.

Contraindications for Stapedotomy:

  • Only hearing ear
  • Positive Schwartze sign
  • Otitis externa
  • Meniere’s disease: can damage the inner ear while drilling a hole in the footplate
  • Young children
  • Professional athletes, pilots, construction workers, and divers: Sudden changes in pressure can displace the piston and cause vertigo.
  • Those who work in noisy surroundings: Surgery makes them more vulnerable to noise-induced hearing loss.

Otosclerosis is a primary disease of the bony labyrinth where foci of irregularly placed spongy bone replace part of the normally dense enchondral layer of the bony otic capsule. It is more commonly seen in females between 20-30 years of age and the hearing loss is aggravated during pregnancy and menopause.

Clinically, patients present with painless progressive bilateral conductive hearing loss and paracusis willisii (patient hears better in noisy surroundings as other people raise their voices to be heard). 

Tuning fork tests and audiometry will reveal the presence of conductive hearing loss. The bone conduction curve may show a dip, which is maximum at 2000Hz, known as Carhart’s notch.

The image shown below shows Carhart's notch.

Other options:

Options B and C: Stapes mobilization and Lempert’s fenestration operation are older procedures seldom performed these days.

Option D: Stapedectomy involves complete removal of the anterior and posterior portions of the footplate, leaving the membrane below the footplate intact. Now the oval window with its overlying membrane is covered with a piece of fascia and the prosthesis is placed over this.

questions.text: You are assisting your consultant in theatre for an excision of a soft tissue sarcoma when he asks you the most common location where this condition arises. What would your response be?
questions.solution:
The most common location of the soft tissue sarcoma is the lower limb.

Sarcomas are a group of neoplasms that arise predominantly from cells of the embryonic mesoderm. Incidence of soft-tissue sarcoma:

Lower limb (Commonest site) > Upper limb > Trunk > Retroperitoneum > Head and neck.

Most primary soft tissue sarcomas originate in an extremity. The thigh is the most common site in the body

Most sarcomas are soft tissue sarcomas, but other types of sarcoma include bone sarcomas (osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, and rare bone tumours like chordoma, angiosarcoma, and leiomyosarcoma of bone) and Ewing’s sarcoma/peripheral primitive neuroectodermal tumour.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman collapses suddenly at home. Paramedics arrive within 10 minutes to find the patient unresponsive, apneic, and pulseless. High-quality CPR is initiated immediately. The cardiac monitor shows the following rhythm. After confirming pulselessness and continuing CPR, which of the following statements is/are true regarding the management of this patient?

  1. The first-line medication is atropine to increase heart rate.
  2. The next immediate step is to deliver a defibrillation shock.
  3. Epinephrine should be administered as soon as possible.
  4. Hypoxia and hypovolemia are reversible causes of Pulseless Electrical Activity.
  5. Mechanical ventilation should be started with high tidal volumes.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of no palpable pulse despite the organized electrical activity on the monitor is suggestive of Pulseless Electrical Activity (PEA). Prompt administration of Epinephrine and identification of reversible causes is critical in managing PEA. 

1) Atropine is not recommended for PEA, as bradycardia is not the underlying issue. 

2) Defibrillation is not indicated for non-shockable rhythms like PEA. Instead, the focus should be on high-quality CPR and administering epinephrine.

3) Epinephrine is the first-line drug for non-shockable rhythms like PEA and asystole to improve coronary and cerebral perfusion.

4) Hypoxia and hypovolemia are common reversible causes of Pulseless Electrical Activity. The reversible causes are commonly remembered as the “H’s and T’s” (e.g., hypovolemia, hypoxia, tension pneumothorax).

5) While ventilation is crucial, high tidal volumes can lead to barotrauma and worsen the patient's condition. It's better to use controlled, lower tidal volumes with adequate PEEP, especially in a resuscitative context.

The complete ACLS (Advanced Cardiovascular Life Support) algorithm is given below:

 

Related Pearl: Reversible Causes of Cardiac Arrest

  • 5 H’s:
    • Hypovolemia
    • Hypoxia
    • Hydrogen ion (acidosis)
    • Hypokalemia or hyperkalemia
    • Hypothermia
  • 5 T’s:
    • Tension pneumothorax
    • Tamponade (cardiac)
    • Toxins
    • Thrombosis (pulmonary)
    • Thrombosis (coronary)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came to the hospital with vomiting. He was prescribed metoclopramide, following which he developed spasms of facial muscles, difficulty in speech, and torticollis. Which of the following drugs is indicated for the treatment of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient has developed symptoms of dystonia due to metoclopramide. Diphenhydramine is used in drug-induced dystonia.

Metoclopramide has dopamine receptor antagonist, 5HT4 agonist, and 5HT3 antagonist properties. It is indicated in patients with gastroparesis and is also used in reducing nausea and vomiting that often accompany GI dysmotility syndromes.

Dopamine receptor antagonist property is responsible for extrapyramidal symptoms. The dystonic reaction is one of the extrapyramidal symptoms. Features include spasms of muscles of the tongue, face, neck, and back. It can be treated with diphenhydramine or benztropine.

Other extrapyramidal symptoms include parkinsonian-like symptoms that may occur several weeks after initiation of therapy. It responds to treatment with anticholinergic or antihistaminic drugs and reverses on discontinuation of metoclopramide. Tardive dyskinesia can develop in patients treated for a prolonged period with metoclopramide.

Other options:

Option A: Phenelzine is a monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitor. It inhibits MAOA and MAOB to prevent the breakdown of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin. It is used in the treatment of major depression. The major adverse effects include weight gain, sexual dysfunction, and hypertensive crisis if taken along with tyramine-containing foods/ beverages.

Option C: Chlorpromazine is a dopamine receptor antagonist and is classified under typical antipsychotics. They are noted to improve the positive symptoms of schizophrenia and acute mania. The major adverse effects are extrapyramidal side effects, sedation, weight gain, hypotension, metabolic adverse effects, and photosensitivity.

Option D: Prochlorperazine is a dopamine receptor antagonist which is used as an anti-emetic. It is mainly used in motion sickness. The main adverse events are extrapyramidal symptoms including dystonia, cardiac effects, and hypotension.

Related Pearl: Extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic drugs

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man with a history of COPD is on treatment with ipratropium bromide, formoterol, and fluticasone. He continues to have exacerbations regularly. A new drug recently approved by the FDA is added to his treatment regimen. This drug inhibits both PDE3 and PDE4. What is this new drug?

PDE - Phosphodiesterase
questions.solution:
Ensifentrine is the recently FDA-approved drug that inhibits PDE 3 & PDE4 and can be used in the further management of COPD in this patient. 

Ensifentrine is a dual inhibitor of the PDE3 and PDE4 enzymes. PDE3 primarily hydrolyzes the cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) but can also hydrolyze cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP). PDE4 hydrolyzes cAMP only. Inhibition of PDE3 and PDE4 results in the accumulation of intracellular cAMP and cGMP levels.

Ensifentrine can reduce symptoms in patients and has an additive effect when used in combination with LAMA. It is currently available only in inhaler preparations. The most common adverse reactions include back pain, hypertension, urinary tract infections, and diarrhea.

Other options: 

Option A: Riociguat is a guanylyl cyclase stimulator used for Pulmonary arterial hypertension.

Option B: Vardenafil is a PDE 5 inhibitor used to treat Erectile dysfunction.

Option D: Roflumilast is an oral nonselective PDE4 inhibitor used in severe COPD.

questions.text: In a flood-hit area, the authorities intensified measures for vector control. In which part of the disaster cycle is the vector management included?
questions.solution:
Vector control is a part of the rehabilitation part of the disaster management cycle.

Rehabilitation includes measures that lead to the restoration of pre-disaster conditions. These measures include water supply restoration, food safety, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, and vector control. Control programs for vector-borne diseases should be intensified in the emergency and rehabilitation periods, especially in areas where such diseases are known to be endemic. Of special concern are dengue fever and malaria (mosquitoes), leptospirosis and rat bite fever (rats), typhus (lice, fleas), and plague (fleas).

Disaster management includes three aspects:

1. Disaster impact and response: Immediate actions taken after a disaster to manage mass casualties and reduce further harm. It includes search and rescue, first aid, triage, and field care.

2. Rehabilitation or recovery: Focuses on restoring pre-disaster conditions by taking steps such as:

  • Water supply restoration
  • Basic sanitation and personal hygiene
  • Food safety measures
  • Vector control

3. Mitigation: Long-term measures to prevent hazards from becoming disasters or reduce their effects.
Includes structural modifications, disaster risk reduction strategies, and environmental policies.

4. Preparedness: These are actions taken before a disaster to ensure readiness. It includes training, drills, emergency stockpiling, and early warning systems.

questions.text: An infant is brought with the following lesion on the scalp. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows cup‐shaped crusts/scutula around hair follicles, which is suggestive of favus.

Kerion is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis. The most common causative organisms of kerion are Trichophyton verrucosum and Trichophyton mentagrophytes. In severe cases, there may be pus along with sinus formation. It presents as an inflammatory mass with thick crusting and matting of hair.

Note: Scarring alopecia is seen in favus and kerion while non-scarring alopecia is seen in ectothrix and endothrix.

Ectothrix is a mild inflammatory type in which dull grey-coated broken hairs are seen.

Endothrix is a non-inflammatory type in which black dots form around swollen hair shafts. 

Tinea capitis is of four types: 

Type of Infection  Causative fungus 
Endothrix (infection inside shaft)
  • Trichophyton tonsurans
  • T. violaceum
  • T. schoenleinii
  • T. yaoundei
  • T. soudanense
Ectothrix (infection outside shaft)
  • Microsporum audouinii
  • M.canis
  • M.equinum
  • M.ferrugineum
Favus 
  • T. schoenleinii
Kerion 
  • T. verrucosum
  • T. mentagrophytes

Other Options:

Option D: Seborrheic dermatitis, or cradle cap in infants, presents with greasy, yellow scales, often without hair loss. Below is an image of the same.

questions.text: All the following are indications of Tc 99m DMSA renal scintigraphy except _______.

choices.text: Direct measurement of glomerular filtration rate

questions.solution:
Direct measurement of GFR is done using Tc 99m DTPA, not Tc 99m DMSA. 

Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) is a radiopharmaceutical agent used to evaluate renal structure and morphology. It is an ideal agent for the assessment of the renal cortex as it binds to the sulfhydryl groups in proximal tubules at the renal cortex with longer retention than other agents. It gives a static image.

The main use of Tc-99m DMSA is in assessing differential renal function and detection of renal scarring and pyelonephritis, especially in the pediatric population.

Indications for Tc-99m DMSA examination:

  • Assessment of differential renal function 
  • Assessment for focal parenchymal defects
  • Confirmation of acute pyelonephritis
  • Differentiating a multicystic dysplastic kidney from a hydronephrotic kidney
  • Assessment of renal function in children with cystic renal disease
  • Assessment of which kidney to biopsy in patients with bilateral renal involvement
  • Assessment of focal defects in a hypertensive child
  • Assessment of DRF in children undergoing abdominal radiotherapy where the kidneys are in the therapy field
  • Assessment of functioning renal tissue in children having bilateral Wilms’ tumor where renal conservation surgery is planned.

Note: Tc-99m DTPA (diethylene-triamine-pentaacetate) is cleared only via glomeruli with no tubular excretion. Hence it is used for direct measurement of GFR.

questions.text: What does the Gettler test estimate in a case of antemortem drowning?
questions.solution:
The Gettler test is used to determine whether a person drowned antemortem. It measures the chloride content in the blood from both sides of the heart.

Normally, the chloride content is equal in the right and left chambers of the heart. In freshwater drowning, due to hemodilution, the chloride content is decreased on the left side of the heart by 50%. In saltwater drowning due to hemoconcentration, the chloride content is increased in the left side of the heart by 30-40%. 

Freshwater drowning:

  • Freshwater is hypotonic to plasma.
  • It is rapidly absorbed into the bloodstream through alveoli, causing hemodilution.
  • This leads to hyponatremia and hyperkalemia due to red blood cell lysis.
  • Increased blood volume and hyperkalemia cause arrhythmias.

Saltwater drowning:

  • Saltwater is hypertonic to plasma.
  • It draws fluid from the bloodstream into the alveoli, causing pulmonary edema.
  • Blood volume decreases, causing hemoconcentration, increased chloride levels, and hypotension.
  • Hypernatremia is seen, but not hyperkalemia, as red blood cells shrink in this environment.

questions.text: Which the following is false regarding Ohngren's line?

choices.text: Tumors situated above the line tends to be more aggressive
It is used to demarcate zones for surgical incision
It is used for prognostic evaluation of carcinoma of maxillary sinus
It extends from medial canthus of eye to the angle of mandible

questions.solution:
Ohngren's line is not used to demarcate zones for surgical incision.

Ohngren's line is an imaginary plane drawn, extending between the medial canthus of the eye to the angle of the mandible. It is used to classify carcinomas of the maxillary sinus into two categories:

  • Above the line (supra-structure tumors): More aggressive, and associated with a worse prognosis.
  • Below the line (infra-structure tumors): Less aggressive, more localized, and have a better prognosis.

questions.text: A 40 -year-old patient came with deformities, swellings, and pain in multiple areas of the limbs, her X-rays of the hands are given below. On examination, her skin doesn't have any hemangiomas. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above radiograph shows multiple tumors affecting the bones of the hand with soft tissue swellings and calcification which is suggestive of multiple enchondromatosis. Multiple enchondromas when present without hemangiomas is called Ollier disease. 

Enchondromas are benign bone tumors of hyaline cartilage which arise from the medullary canal.

Ollier disease is a rare condition in which many cartilaginous tumors appear in the large and small tubular bones and in the flat bones. It is caused by the failure of normal endochondral ossification.

Note: Enchondromatosis with hemangioma of the overlying soft tissue constitutes Maffucci’s syndrome.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with excessive weight gain, easy bruising, striae, and glucose intolerance. After an appropriate workup, she is diagnosed with an adrenocortical adenoma, with a hormone secreted by a zone marked as B. Identify the given hormone -
questions.solution:
In the above image, structure marked B is Zona fasciculata. Glucocorticoids are secreted from the Zona fasciculata. 

Zona fasiculata secretes:

  • Glucocorticoids
  • Cortisol
  • Corticosterone

Other structures marked are as follows:

A – Zona glomerulosa (just underneath the eosinophilic connective tissue)

C – Zona reticularis (cells arranged in the form of irregular cords giving rise to the reticular pattern)

D – Adrenal Medulla
