questions.text: A middle-aged man with a history of diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease is admitted to ICU with sepsis. Blood cultures reveal Candida albicans. His creatinine clearance is 30mL/min, and he has a central venous catheter placed. A complete blood count reveals slightly raised white blood cells. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Echinocandins, such as caspofungin, micafungin, or anidulafungin, are the initial treatment for systemic candidiasis in non-neutropenic adults.

They are the preferred choice due to their effectiveness and lack of nephrotoxicity, as the patient in this case has a known chronic kidney disease. If the patient becomes clinically stable, he can be switched to Fluconazole. 

Echinocandins inhibit 1,3-β-D-glucan synthesis, which is an essential component of the fungal cell wall and is required for cellular integrity.

Other options :

Option A: Fluconazole is an alternative to the first-line therapy of an echinocandin and is recommended as a step-down therapy, provided the patient’s isolate is susceptible to the azole group. This option is recommended for non-critical patients, and, given the patient’s critical status and central line, this is not preferred.

Option B: Amphotericin B can be used as an alternative option in neutropenic patients, but caspofungin is preferred due to its less toxic effect.

Option D: Griseofulvin is used in the treatment of dermatophytic infections.

questions.text: A man was stuck inside a building that caught fire. He died of suffocation due to smoke. Burn injuries were minimal. Which of the following postmortem changes is likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
The person died of suffocation due to smoke. This indicates carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning, which causes cherry-red postmortem hypostasis.

Victims of smoke inhalation are affected by carbon monoxide poisoning. Carbon monoxide has a higher affinity to haemoglobin as compared to oxygen and hence the amount of haemoglobin available for oxygen transport is markedly reduced. It can cause anaemic hypoxia. The binding of CO to haemoglobin results in cherry-red discolouration.

Other options:

Option A- Greenish-blue postmortem hypostasis is seen in poisoning due to hydrogen sulphide poisoning.

Option B- Pugilistic attitude is seen when muscle proteins are coagulated at high temperatures. Since this person did not die of burn injuries, a pugilistic attitude will not be seen.

Option D- Rigor mortis is not delayed. On the contrary, it may have a rapid onset because of heat.

Related Pearl: Color of Postmortem Hypostasis in Various Conditions

questions.text: An autopsy of a man who died due to a gunshot was done in which two bullets were found in his body. External examination revealed only one entrance wound. Which of the following mechanisms may help explain this?
questions.solution:
In certain cases, when a bullet fails to expel upon firing, a subsequent shot may cause both the original lodged bullet and the second bullet to enter the body through the same entry point. This phenomenon is referred to as a tandem or piggyback bullet.

The presence of an excess number of bullets compared to the observed entrance wounds can be attributed to factors such as weapon malfunctions, defective ammunition, prolonged non-usage of the loaded firearm, or exposure to extreme environmental conditions like high temperature or humidity. It is possible for the bullets to either separate within the body or before reaching the intended target.

Related Pearl: Types of bullets:

1. Ricochet bullet: Bullet first strikes an intermediate object and then after being reflected strikes the target. It produces a key hole entry wound .

2. Yawning bullet: Travels in an irregular fashion.

3. Tandem (Piggy Back) Bullet Effect: Two bullets are ejected one after the other; first bullet failed to leave the barrel and is ejected by subsequently fired bullet. This occurs due to defect in the weapon or due to faulty ammunition or with loaded firearms unused for several years. Tandem cartridge (also called duplex cartridge) is a single cartridge containing two bullets. 

 

4. Frangible bullet: Fragments on hitting the target.

5. Dum Dum bullet: Tip is chiseled out, fragments extensively on impact.

6. Tumbling bullet:  Rotates end on end during its motion. This produces an atypical entry wound .  

7. Souvenir bullet:  Bullet left in the body for a long time and covered with dense fibrous connective tissue.

8. Tracer bullet: This type of bullet leaves a visible mark or trace while in flight so that the gunner can observe the strike of shot. Rear portion of bullet is filled with mixture of barium nitrate, strontium nitrate and powdered magnesium which is ignited by the burning powder. Mixture burns and sheds red sparks which makes the projectile visible to naked eye which enables shooter to make aiming corrections.

9. Incendiary bullet: It is filled with white phosphorous and ignites the target.

From left to right : Blank with frangible wooden bullet, ball, tracer and incendiary bullets

questions.text: An obese patient with traumatic brain injury is shifted to the emergency OT and an 18G cannula is secured in the distal forearm. Inj Thiopentone 3 mg/kg is administered in incremental doses through the cannula and 50 mL of fluid is rushed. However, the eyelash reflex is still present. On checking, a diffuse swelling is seen extending from the cannulated site to the level of the elbow. Which of the following is most likely in this scenario?

choices.text: Lower flow rate through a narrow cannula

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with failed intravenous induction followed by forearm swelling is indicative of failed intravenous cannulation and extravasation of administered fluid.

Peripheral intravenous (IV) cannulation is the most common procedure done in acute settings. IV cannula gauge sizes range from 14G or orange (widest bore) to 24G or yellow (narrowest bore). The smaller the gauge size, the larger the bore size and the faster is the flow rate.

Selection of an appropriate size cannula is essential to prevent complications. Wider-bore cannulas are preferred for blood transfusions, correction of hypovolemia, and electrolyte imbalances. Complications of IV cannulation include:

  • Failure
  • Damage to surrounding tissues like arteries, nerves
  • Hematoma formation
  • Bleeding at the insertion site
  • Inadvertent arterial cannulation
  • Extravasation into surrounding tissue
  • Thrombophlebitis
  • Cellulitis
  • Dislodgement
  • Systemic complications like vasovagal syncope, anaphylaxis, allergic reactions

Other Options:

Option A: Accidental arterial injection of Thiopentone can lead to local toxicity due to the formation of crystals. It results in acute pain, vasospasm, thrombus formation, and tissue necrosis. The intra-arterial injection can cause pain and swelling distal to the cannulated artery. In the given scenario, the swelling is seen proximal to the cannulated site till the elbow.

Option C: 18G is a wide-bore cannula with a flow rate of 103 mL/min.

Option D: Thrombophlebitis usually develops 12-36 hours after cannulation. It is associated with acute pain, swelling, erythema, and a palpable, tender cord on the cannulated vein.

questions.text:
Open vial policy is applicable for which of the following vaccines?
  1. BCG
  2. DPT vaccine
  3. Oral Polio vaccine
  4. MR vaccine
  5. Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine
questions.solution:
Among the given vaccines open vial policy is applicable for the DPT vaccine, Oral Polio vaccine, and Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine.

Open vial policy applies to DPT, TT, Hepatitis B, Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV), Liquid Pentavalent, PCV, and injectable IPV.
It does not apply to Measles/MR, BCG, or Japanese Encephalitis (JE) vaccines.

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one immunization session for up to four weeks provided

  • The expiry date has not passed.
  • Vaccines are stored strictly under an appropriate temperature range both during transportation & storage at cold chain points.
  • The vaccine vial septum has not been submerged in water or contaminated in any way.
  • An aseptic technique has been used to withdraw all doses.
  • The vaccine vial monitor (VVM), has not reached the discard point.

Ensure all open vials have recorded the date and time of opening. All vials (open or unopened) should be transported in a zipper bag in the vaccine carrier and recorded in the stock register. Well-sealed conditioned ice packs should be used in vaccine carriers and water should not be allowed to accumulate where vaccine vials and diluents are stored.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true of the baroreceptor reflex pathway?

1. Rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) is inhibited by gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA).
2. Caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM) releases GABA.
3. Nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) releases GABA.
4. RVLM releases GABA.
questions.solution:
The correct statements are 1, 2.

RVLM (Rostral ventrolateral medulla) is inhibited by GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) and CVLM (Caudal ventrolateral medulla) releases GABA.

Baroreceptors are stretch receptors in the walls of the heart and blood vessels. Baroreceptors are stimulated by the stretching of the walls of the respective vessels when there is an increased volume or pressure in the vessel. They are important in the immediate management of blood pressure. 

The afferents from the baroreceptors activate NTS which in turn activates CVLM. The CVLM, on activation, releases gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) which is inhibitory to the RVLM. The RVLM is the major excitatory source of the sympathetic nervous system. As it is inhibited, there is sympathetic inhibition thus reducing the blood pressure.

The NTS also simultaneously activates the vagal motor neurons causing bradycardia.

 

The receptors of arterial circulation include the carotid sinus, which is present in the adventitia of the internal carotid artery just above the bifurcation of the common carotid. Afferent nerve innervation is by a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve called the carotid sinus nerve.  Aortic arch - present in the adventitia of the walls of the arch of the aorta. Afferent innervation is by the vagus nerve called the aortic depressor nerve.

The receptors of low-pressure system/ cardiopulmonary receptors are atrial receptors and pulmonary circulation receptors.

Atrial receptors are present in the walls of the right and left atria near the opening of the superior and inferior vena cava and pulmonary veins.

questions.text:
The possible clinical manifestations of a patient whose MRI is as shown.
  1. Dissociated sensory loss
  2. Loss of touch vibration with sparing of pain and temperature
  3. Muscle wasting
  4. Bowel bladder dysfunction
  5. Cape-like distribution of sensory deficit
questions.solution:
The MRI shows a hyperintense area in the spinal cord, which strongly suggests syringomyelia, the formation of a fluid-filled cavity (syrinx) within the spinal cord. 

Syringomyelia occurs due to damage to spinothalamic tract fibers crossing the anterior commissure. It is often associated with Chiari malformation Type I, trauma, or tumors. Patients present with:

  • Dissociated sensory loss: Loss of pain and temperature with preserved touch and vibration.
  • Sensory loss over the nape of the neck, shoulders, and arms (cape-like distribution)
  • LMN dysfunction due to anterior horn cell compression leads to muscle wasting, weakness, and hyporeflexia in the upper extremities.
  • Autonomic dysfunction: Bowel and bladder dysfunction in advanced cases

questions.text: A child is brought to the casualty following a snake bite. Basic resuscitative measures were initiated and a 20-minute whole blood clotting time test performed is as shown below. Which of the following snakes could have presumably bitten this child?
questions.solution:
The result of the 20-minute whole blood clotting test, as shown in the image in the question, can be labelled as not clotted. This leads us to assume that this child was probably bitten by a saw-scaled viper, a vasculotoxic snake.

The 20-minute whole blood clotting test (20WBCT) is a bedside test used to detect coagulopathy caused by vasculotoxic snake venom. This test helps determine the presence of venom-induced consumption coagulopathy (VICC), a condition in which the venom depletes clotting factors, leading to non-clotting blood.

The 20WBCT is based on the fact that whole blood generally clots when exposed to a glass surface. To perform this test, draw 2–3 mL of fresh venous blood into a clean and dry glass test tube. Leave the blood undisturbed at room temperature for 20 minutes. Tilt the tube gently to check if the blood has clotted. Clotted blood suggests no vasculotoxic effect. Non-clotted blood suggests venom-induced coagulopathy, often due to viper bites.

Other options:

Option A: Sea snake venom is myotoxic. The main presentation is generalized rhabdomyolysis, which has no effect on the 20 WBCT.

Options B and D: Bites of Elapidae, such as Cobras, Common Kraits, Mambas, and Coral Snakes, generally result in neurotoxic effects in the patient, having no effect on the 20 WBCT. 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of snake venom

Snake Toxicity Main features

Viperidae

  • Saw-scaled viper

  • Anticoagulant effect: widespread bleeding

Hydrophidae (sea snakes) are now considered a subfamily of Elapidae

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presents with complaints of pruritus, easy fatiguability, and right upper quadrant discomfort. Laboratory investigations show elevation of GGT & ALP and the presence of anti-mitochondrial antibodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A perimenopausal age group female presenting with fatigue, pruritus, elevated GGT & ALP, and antimitochondrial antibody positivity points to a diagnosis of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC). 

Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) is characterized by chronic, non-suppurative inflammatory destruction of small- and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts. It shows strong female preponderance. Most of the patients are asymptomatic; symptomatic patients present with fatigue out of proportion to the extent of liver disease or the age of the patient. Pruritus is another common complaint. On examination, jaundice and other complications of chronic liver disease such as hepatosplenomegaly and ascites may be seen, but may not be common. 

Laboratory findings show a cholestatic pattern of liver enzyme elevation, with increased levels of GGT and ALP. Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are present in 95% of the patients with PBC. A liver biopsy is relevant in the setting of AMA-negative disease and would demonstrate florid duct lesions/ granulomas. Ursodeoxycholic acid is the first-line treatment early in the disease course. It has been shown to slow the progress of the disease. Liver transplantation is the treatment of choice for patients with decompensated liver disease due to PBC.

Other Options:

Option B: Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by the presence of p-ANCA, not A anti-mitochondrial antibody.

Option C: Autoimmune Hepatitis may present with fatigue, pruritus, ⬆️ AST, ⬆️ ALT. It is often positive for anti-smooth muscle antibodies.

Option D: Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis involves the fatty infiltration of the liver in non-alcoholics and usually presents with elevated liver enzymes (⬆️ AST, ⬆️ ALT) in obese individuals.

Related Pearl: Differences between primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and primary biliary cholangitis (PBC)

questions.text: During the autopsy of a farmer who died from insecticide poisoning, also known as "plant penicillin," a kerosene-like smell was noted in the stomach contents. This poisoning is managed by?
questions.solution:
The autopsy findings of the farmer showed a kerosene-like smell due to endrin poisoning (also known as "plant penicillin”). There is no specific antidote for this poisoning, and the management is supportive.

Endrin is an organochloride pesticide that causes neurotoxicity. Symptoms typically appear within 1–6 hours of exposure. The early symptoms include salivation, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Severe symptoms develop with dilated pupils, restlessness, hyper irritability, tremors, clonic and tonic convulsions, mental confusion, and coma.

Postmortem findings include a kerosene-like smell from the mouth and stomach contents with signs of asphyxia. Treatment is supportive as there is no specific antidote. Supportive measures include maintaining the airway and breathing and managing seizures with anticonvulsants like diazepam or phenobarbital.

Other options:

Option A: Atropine plus pralidoxime is used in organophosphorus poisoning, which involves a cholinergic crisis.

Option B: Sodium thiosulfate plus sodium nitrite is used to treat cyanide poisoning.

Option C: Physostigmine is used in anticholinergic toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following contributes to the development of the main pancreatic duct during the embryological development of the pancreas?

choices.text: Dorsal duct and distal portion of ventral duct
Ventral duct and distal portion of dorsal duct
Dorsal duct and proximal portion of ventral duct
Ventral duct and proximal portion of dorsal duct

questions.solution:
The main pancreatic duct of Wirsung is formed by the ventral duct and distal portion of dorsal pancreatic ducts during the embryological development of the pancreas.

Steps in the development of the pancreas:

  1. The pancreas begins as two separate buds, the dorsal and ventral buds. The dorsal pancreatic bud is situated in the dorsal mesentery and the ventral pancreatic bud is located near the bile duct.
  2. As the duodenum rotates to the right and assumes a C-shape, the ventral pancreatic bud moves dorsally. The ventral pancreatic bud moves behind and below the dorsal pancreatic bud.
  3. The dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds eventually fuse to form the complete pancreas.
  4. The ventral bud contributes to the formation of the uncinate process and the inferior part of the head of the pancreas. The dorsal bud gives rise to the rest of the pancreatic gland.
  5. The main pancreatic duct (of Wirsung) is formed by the ventral pancreatic duct and the distal part of the dorsal pancreatic duct. The proximal part of the dorsal pancreatic duct may either be obliterated or persist as the accessory pancreatic duct (of Santorini).
  6. The main pancreatic duct enters the duodenum at the major papilla, while the accessory duct (when present) enters at the minor papilla.
  7. Around the third month of fetal life, pancreatic islets develop from the parenchymal pancreatic tissue and spread throughout the pancreas.
  8. Insulin secretion begins around the fifth month of fetal life. Glucagon and somatostatin-secreting cells also develop from the parenchymal cells of the pancreas.
  9. The visceral mesoderm surrounding the pancreatic buds gives rise to the connective tissue of the pancreas.

In some cases, there is a failure of fusion of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic ducts leading to a condition called pancreatic divisum (pancreas divisum). In these patients, pancreatic drainage is accomplished mainly through the minor papilla (via the dorsal pancreatic duct) as the dorsal pancreatic duct remains separate from the ventral pancreatic duct.
The minor papilla is much narrower than the major papilla, making it less capable of handling the large volume of pancreatic secretions. This can result in incomplete drainage, leading to obstruction and, eventually, recurrent pancreatitis.

The annular pancreas is due to the failure of the complete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud. During development, a ring of pancreatic tissue surrounds the second or third part of the duodenum.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions show a secular trend?
  1. Coronary heart disease
  2. Polio
  3. Lung cancer
  4. Diabetes
  5. Influenza
  6. Measles
questions.solution:
Coronary heart disease, Polio, Lung cancer & Diabetes show a secular trend. Measles shows a seasonal trend and influenza shows a cyclic trend.

Secular trend describes the occurrence of disease over a prolonged period, usually years. Even though it may have short-term fluctuations, there is a tendency for the disease occurrence to change consistently in a particular direction or a definite movement in one direction.

Examples of the secular trend include coronary heart disease, lung cancer, and diabetes, which have shown a consistent upward trend in incidence as well as prevalence, in developed countries. Similarly, there has been a consistent decline in the diseases such as tuberculosis, typhoid fever, diphtheria, and polio.

Seasonal trends reflect seasonal changes in disease occurrence following changes in environmental conditions that enhance the ability of the agent to replicate or be transmitted. For example, measles (usually occurs in early spring), varicella, etc. Non-infectious conditions like hay fever and snake bites may also show seasonal variations.

Cyclic trend is shown by some diseases that occur in cycles spread over short periods of time which may be, days, weeks, months, or years.  Examples include the influenza pandemic, which is known to occur at intervals of every 7–10 years due to antigenic variations.

questions.text:
A female patient presents with fatigue. Her lab results and peripheral blood smear are given below. Calculate the Mentzer index and identify the type of anemia.

RBC: 3 million/mm3
MCV: 30 fL
MCH: 21 pg
MCHC: 24g/dL
questions.solution:
The Mentzer index (MCV/RBC count) is 30/3=10 . The peripheral smear findings (hypochromic microcytic anemia, target cells, basophilic stippling, fragmented red cells) and a Menter Index of <13 are indicative of thalassemia. 

The Mentzer index is the ratio of MCV (mean corpuscular volume) to RBC count. It is used to differentiate between iron-deficiency anemia and β-thalassemia trait. MCV and MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin) are low in both iron deficiency anemia and thalassemia. RBC count may be normal in thalassemia, whereas it is reduced in iron deficiency anemia. The Mentzer index is <13 in thalassemia minor syndrome.

RBC indices Definition Normal range Significance
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) MCV defines the size of the red blood cells. It is given by the formula PCV/RBC (fL). 80-97 fL

Increased: Macrocytic anemia(Megaloblastic anemia) 

Decreased: Microcytic anemia (Iron deficiency anemia, thalassemia)
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) MCH quantifies the amount of hemoglobin per red blood cell. It is given by the formula hemoglobin/RBC (pg). 27-31 pg

Increased: Macrocytic anemia

Decreased: Microcytic anemia
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) MCHC indicates the amount of hemoglobin per unit volume. It is given by the formula hemoglobin/PCV (g/dL). 32-36 g/dl

Increased: Hereditary spherocytosis

Decreased: Microcytic anemia
Red cell distribution width (RDW) RDW represents the coefficient of variation of the red blood cell volume distribution (size) and is expressed as a percentage. 11.5-14.5%

Increased: Iron deficiency anemia, Megaloblastic anemia

Normal: Thalassemia

 
 
Thalassemia is a hemoglobinopathy that arises due to deficient synthesis of the globin chains. Depending on the chain affected, it is classified into α-thalassemia and β-thalassemia. There is a deficit in the synthesis of HbA with an elevation of HbA2 and HbF levels in β-thalassemia. Hb Electrophoresis, HPLC  (High-Performance Liquid Chromatography), and DNA diagnosis to detect β-thalassemia mutations aid in diagnosing thalassemia.
 
Blood transfusions are administered every 3-4 weeks to maintain a pretransfusion hemoglobin level of 9.5-10.5 g/dL. Oral iron chelation to prevent iron toxicity is also recommended. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is the only definitive therapy. Antenatal counseling and heterozygote screening can be used to prevent this condition. 

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old athlete performs two types of exercises, as given below. Which of the following accurately describes these exercises?

Exercise 1: Lifting a 10-kg weight through a range of motion (elbow flexion)

Exercise 2: Contracting the biceps without moving the elbow joint.

choices.text: Exercise 1 is isometric, exercise 2 is isotonic
Exercise 1 is isotonic, exercise 2 is isometric

questions.solution:
In the first exercise, a muscle shortens against a constant weight. This is an isotonic contraction, and the muscle tension remains the same. In the second exercise, a muscle contracts without a change in its length. This is an isometric contraction and the tension increases during contraction. So, exercise 1 is isotonic, exercise 2 is isometric.

Muscle contraction is of two types: isometric and isotonic. In isometric contraction, the length of the whole muscle does not change, while the tension increases. This is due to the lengthening of the elastic and viscous elements present in series with the contractile mechanism of the muscle. During isometric contraction, displacement is zero, and hence, work done is zero [Work done is the product of force and displacement in the direction of force generated].

Isotonic contraction results in a decrease in muscle length while maintaining constant tension throughout contraction. The work done during isotonic contraction is positive as displacement i.e. shortening of the muscle occurs in the direction of the force generated.

  Concentric isotonic Eccentric isotonic Isometric
Length of muscle Decrease Increase Same
Tension Same Same Increase
Movement Against resistance With resistance Nil
Peak tension: Amount of resistance More More Less
Example Biceps during the upward phase of the exercise Biceps during the downward phase of the exercise When biceps is holding the weight still

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy is brought to the paediatrician for a routine check-up. There is a history of mild developmental delay and physical examination reveals coarse facies and multiple blue-grey patches on the lower back and buttocks. The child also has a slightly enlarged liver and mild joint stiffness. Given the clinical presentation, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this child?

choices.text: Perform a liver biopsy to assess the histopathological findings
Order an enzyme assay for branched chain alpha keto acid dehydrogenase
Order a urine test for glycosaminoglycans (GAG)

questions.solution:
The presence of coarse facial features, development delay, multiple blue-grey patches (known as Mongolian spots), and hepatomegaly suggest mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS). The most appropriate next step is to test for urinary glycosaminoglycans (GAG).

Mucopolysaccharidoses are inherited, progressive disorders caused by pathogenic mutations in genes that encode the lysosomal enzymes responsible for breaking down glycosaminoglycans. They are characterised by intellectual disability and mesenchymal abnormalities such as musculoskeletal defects. Though Mongolian spots are mostly benign, extensive Mongolian spots may be associated with mucopolysaccharidosis. 

Urinary excretion of glycosaminoglycans (GAG) by 2D electrophoresis is a useful screening test for diagnosing mucopolysaccharidosis. Specific enzyme assays and DNA analyses confirm the diagnosis. Enzyme replacement therapy is available for types I, II, IV, VI, and VII and should be initiated after the diagnosis is confirmed.

Option A: An invasive procedure like Liver biopsy for assessing histopathology is not required in the diagnosis of mucopolysaccharidosis.

Option B: Estimation of plasma phenylalanine levels is done for assessment of phenylketonuria, which is characterised by profound, irreversible intellectual disability, microcephaly, epilepsy, behavioural problems, and musty odour.

Option C: Enzyme assay for branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase is done for Maple Syrup Urine Disease, which is characterised by ketonuria, irritability, and poor feeding followed by deepening encephalopathy manifesting as lethargy, intermittent apnea, opisthotonus, and stereotyped movements such as “fencing” and “bicycling” by age 4-5 days.

questions.text: During thyroidectomy, the surgeon accidentally damages the nerve marked in the image below. The marked nerve is derived from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above image is the left recurrent laryngeal nerve. The recurrent laryngeal nerve arises from the 6th pharyngeal arch.

The recurrent laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve and supplies all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx, except for the cricothyroid (external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve).

The image given below shows the nerves of the neck.

 

Recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis can be unilateral or bilateral. The right recurrent laryngeal nerve is more commonly affected than the left in thyroid surgeries due to its variable relation with the inferior thyroid artery. During thyroid surgeries, the recurrent laryngeal nerve can be identified in Beahrs triangle, which is bounded by recurrent laryngeal nerve on one side, common carotid artery, and inferior thyroid artery on the other two sides.

Postoperatively, the injury can go unnoticed or the patient may complain of mild hoarseness in the voice. This hoarseness is because the paralyzed muscle cannot close the glottis during phonation.

Note: Overall, the most common nerve affected in thyroid surgeries is the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve because of its close relationship with the superior thyroid artery.

The image below shows Beahrs' triangle.

Treatment Wait & watch (palsy with least consequences) Tracheostomy, lateralization Wait & watch, medialization Tracheostomy + Epiglottopexy

Guide: \ is normal moving cord; | is paramedian; [ is cadaveric.

questions.text:
Match the following inclusion bodies with the respective disease conditions in which they may be seen.
A. Torres bodies 1. Granuloma inguinale
B. Levinthal-Cole-Lillie bodies (LCL bodies) 2. Trachoma
C. Miyagawa’s granulocorpuscles 3. Psittacosis
D. Halberstaedter-Prowazek bodies 4. Yellow fever
  5. Lymphogranuloma venereum
questions.solution:
The correct pairs are as follows:

  1. Torres bodies - Yellow fever
  2. Levinthal-Cole-Lillie bodies (LCL bodies) - Psittacosis
  3. Miyagawa’s granulocorpuscles - Lymphogranuloma venereum
  4. Halberstaedter-Prowazek bodies - Trachoma
  5. Donovan bodies - Granuloma inguinale 

Inclusion bodies are structures with distinct sizes and shapes that are seen in infected cells under light microscopy. 

Torres bodies are amorphous eosinophilic nuclear inclusions associated with yellow fever, a disease caused by the Flavivirus.

The Miyagawa corpuscles are inclusion bodies seen in lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). They are intracytoplasmic microcolonies of Chlamydia trachomatis seen on microscopy of the aspirated material from the buboes.

Levinthal-Cole-Lillie bodies are inclusion bodies of Chlamydia psittaci seen in infected cells including alveolar macrophages from patients suffering from psittacosis. They are present in cell cultures also. Distinguishing features from inclusion bodies of C. trachomatis are that they are more diffuse and irregular and are not stained by iodine.

Halberstaedter-Prowazek (HP) bodies are demonstrated in conjunctival scrapings of patients with trachoma, after staining by Giemsa, Castaneda, or Macchiavello methods. They stain well with iodine as they contain glycogen. 

Related Pearl: Inclusion bodies seen in various conditions/diseases

1. Bacterial Inclusion Bodies

2. Viral Inclusion Bodies

questions.text:
During palpation of the spleen in a patient, you observe that the spleen is enlarged medially and downward. Which of the following structures influence this pattern of splenic enlargement?
  1. Phrenicocolic ligament
  2. Phrenicosplenic ligament
  3. Gastrosplenic ligament
questions.solution:
Enlargement of the spleen is directed downward and medially due to the phrenicocolic ligament.

Ligaments of the spleen are reflections of the parietal peritoneum in the left upper quadrant. They include:

  • Gastrosplenic ligament - runs from the greater curvature of the stomach and encloses the spleen. Its outer layer detaches to form the rest of the splenic ligaments that continue posteriorly as dorsal mesogastrium. It includes short gastric and left gastro-omental branches of the splenic artery and their corresponding veins.
  • Splenorenal ligament - runs up to the splenic hilum and encloses Splenic blood vessels with the tail of the pancreas in its inferior portion.
  • Phrenicocolic ligament - extends from the left colic flexure to the adjacent parietal peritoneum. Its downward traction during mobilization of left colic flexure in surgery can lead to splenic capsular rupture and bleeding (Surgical trauma is the most common cause of splenectomy).
  • Phrenicosplenic ligament - attaches the upper part of the spleen to the diaphragm. It is a part of the greater omentum.

In the case of a pathologically enlarged spleen, phrenicocolic ligament directs a medial extension rather than a direct descent. 

The gastrosplenic ligament encloses the spleen from the medial aspect and doesn’t play a role in descent. The phrenicosplenic ligament is the peritoneal attachment of the diaphragm to the spleen and is related superiorly to the spleen which again doesn’t play any role in downward descent.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old female patient had undergone a Pap smear test whose reports show LSIL (Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion). What would be the next step of management in the given scenario?

HPV- Human Papilloma Virus

LLETZ- Large loop excision of the transformation zone
questions.solution:
HPV testing is the next step of management in a woman aged ≥ 30 years whose Pap smear cytology report shows LSIL.

In women aged ≥ 30 years with cytology showing LSIL, HPV-testing is done. If HPV test comes positive, further management is with colposcopy with biopsy. If the HPV test comes negative, both the Pap smear test and HPV test (co-testing) are repeated after one year. 

If either the HPV test or the cytology report comes positive after one year, a colposcopy with biopsy will be done. Whereas a negative report warrants another co-testing at 3 years. Co-testing at 3 years will be followed by 5 yearly routine screening or colposcopy with biopsy based on the results.

However, LSIL in women < 30 years will be further proceeded by annual repeat cytology for two years. 

Cytology

(Betheseda

system) 

 Age Management
ASCUS < 30 years Annual repeat cytology for 2 years
ASCUS ≥ 30 years

HPV testing, Cytology at 1 year
LSIL < 30 years Annual repeat cytology for 2 years
LSIL ≥ 30 years HPV testing

ASC-H 

HSIL

 < 30 years

Colposcopy ± biopsy

ASC-H/ HSIL

 ≥ 30 years

Colposcopy with cervical biopsy and endocervical assessment

ASCUS - Atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance

LSIL - Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

ASC-H - Atypical squamous cells: cannot exclude High grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

HSIL - High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

Mild dysplasia/CIN-I can be treated with ablation, if persisting for more than 2 years. CIN-II and III are usually managed with therapeutic conization, Loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP), ablation of the transformation zone, etc.

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with an annular arrangement of vesicles on his trunk and upper thighs. His mother is concerned, and you perform a direct immunofluorescence study, which shows the following pattern. What is the first-line drug for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation, which includes annular vesicles (arranged in a string-of-pearls or crown-of-jewels pattern) on the trunk and thighs, along with linear IgA deposits seen on direct immunofluorescence, is characteristic of linear IgA disease. The drug of choice for the above condition is Dapsone.

Linear IgA disease is a blistering autoimmune skin disorder in which IgA antibodies deposit in a linear pattern along the dermo-epidermal junction (DEJ). The characteristic triad of clinical features includes tense blisters, vesicles, and annular erythema. Blister formation is caused by subepidermal splitting and neutrophilic infiltrate in the papillary dermis, forming microabscesses. 

Management involves:

1. First line:

  • Dapsone
  • Topical steroids (with or without oral prednisolone)

2. Second line:

  • Sulfa drugs like Sulfapyridine/ sulphamethoxypyridazine are alternatives to dapsone
  • Anti‐inflammatory antibiotics like doxycycline (with or without nicotinamide)

3. Third line:

  • Mycophenolate
  • IVIG
  • Immunoadsorption

The image below shows a string of pearls in the Linear IgA disease:

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2
Epidermo-lysis bullosa acquisita Tense bullae and erosions  Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear  Type VII collagen

 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain and the USG of his gall bladder appears as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
USG showing comet-tail artefacts in the gallbladder suggests adenomyomatosis of the gallbladder.

Adenomyomatous hyperplasia of the gall bladder is also known as cholecystitis glandularis proliferans. It is characterized by gall bladder wall thickening due to epithelial and smooth muscle hyperplasia along with cystic epithelial invagination into the wall, referred to as Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses. Most common location of these are in the fundus of the gall bladder and the sinuses often contain stones. 

On USG, the characteristic findings are a thickened gallbladder wall showing bright echoes arising from the cystic spaces with ‘comet-tail’ ring-down artefacts as seen in the image below.  

The comet-tail artifact is caused by the cholesterol crystals trapped within the Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses causing reverberation(large number of reflected waves).

Other options:

Option A: An ultrasound scan in acute cholecystitis demonstrates a distended gallbladder with a thickened wall of >3 mm, pericholecystic fluid, the presence of gallstone( when it is due to associated cholelithiasis), and the sonographic Murphy's sign. Gallbladder distension (diameter >5 cm), pericholecystic fluid, gallbladder wall striations, and, occasionally, wall hyperemia on Doppler examination may also be seen in USG. 

Option B: On USG, gallbladder polyps are small echogenic foci adherent to the gallbladder wall and do not cast any acoustic shadow. They are often found in a non-dependent portion and the lack of mobility can be used to distinguish them from gall bladder stones.

Option D: In cholelithiasis gallbladder stones appear as echogenic foci producing posterior acoustic shadows.
