questions.text: An obstetrician elicits a reflex by performing a procedure for labour induction on a patient as depicted in the image below. What type of homeostatic feedback mechanism is associated with this reflex?
questions.solution:
The procedure done in the image above to induce labour is the stripping of membranes which elicits the Ferguson reflex. Ferguson's reflex is associated with a positive feedback mechanism.

Stripping/Sweeping of membranes refers to the digital separation of the chorioamniotic membranes from the lower uterine segment and cervix wall. It is associated with an increase in blood levels of prostaglandin F2α metabolite, also known as dinoprost. 

Positive feedback is a type of feedback in which the initial stimulus triggers a response that deviates further from the original state.

The fetal ejection reflex (Ferguson reflex) is a phenomenon in which mechanical stretching of the internal cervix enhances uterine activity. Oxytocin is released as the fetal head presses on the uterine cervix, which further enhances uterine contraction. This finally helps in the delivery of the fetus by facilitating fetal head descent. It is an example of a positive feedback mechanism.

Other options:

Option A: Negative feedback mechanism- If the activity of a particular system is increased, the controller system initiates the negative feedback mechanism, which prevents overactivity and ensures normal homeostasis (e.g., baroreceptor reflex). 

Option B: Feedforward control also called anticipatory control (option C), is that which makes an anticipatory or adaptive response without a specific stimulus. This is seen in body temperature regulation where thermoregulatory responses are initiated by the hypothalamus before the changes in environmental temperature change the core body temperature. Thus, shivering in response to a cold environment is an example of feedforward control.

questions.text:
Match the following drugs with the targets of their actions.
1. Rituximab A. HER2
2. Ipilimumab

B. CTLA-4
3. Trastuzumab C. PD-1
4. Pembrolizumab D. CD20
questions.solution:
The correct pairs are 1-D, 2-B, 3-A, 4-C.

1. Rituximab D. CD20
2. Ipilimumab B. CTLA-4
3. Trastuzumab A. HER2
4. Pembrolizumab C. PD-1

Rituximab is a chimeric murine/human monoclonal IgG1 antibody that acts against CD20 B­-cell surface antigen. It is approved as a single agent for relapsed indolent lymphomas and significantly enhances response and survival when used in combination with chemotherapy for the initial treatment of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.

Ipilimumab is a fully humanised IgG1 monoclonal antibody that inhibits cytotoxic T lymphocyte-Associated Protein-4 (CTLA-4). It is approved for the treatment of late-stage melanoma.

Trastuzumab is a humanised IgG1 monoclonal antibody that blocks the extracellular domain IV of HER2 (human epidermal growth factor receptor 2). It is approved for HER2-overexpressing breast and gastric cancer. 

Pembrolizumab acts by inhibiting PD-1 (programmed cell death protein 1) and was used for the treatment of advanced melanoma. Now, the FDA has approved the use of pembrolizumab for any cancer with mismatch repair (MMR) deficiency or high microsatellite instability (MSI-H).

questions.text: The below image shows the anterior view of the left scapula. What is the type of epiphysis shown by the part of scapula marked as "X"?
questions.solution:
The part of the scapula marked as "X" in the above image is the coracoid process. It fuses by an atavistic type of epiphysis.

The atavistic epiphysis is phylogenetically an independent bone in lower animals that becomes fused to another bone in man.

Examples:

  • The coracoid process is fused to the scapula in humans but is a separate bone in four-legged animals
  • Os trigonum or lateral tubercle of talus

The coracoid process arises from the upper border of the neck of the scapula, and it projects forward and slightly laterally. Attachments at the coracoid process include 

  • The conoid portion of the coracoclavicular ligament 
  • Pectoralis minor 
  • Medial end of coraco-acromial ligament
  • Coracohumeral ligament 
  • Glenocorocoid ligamnet 
  • Coracobrachialis muscle

The tip of the coracoid process lies approximately 2.5 cm below the clavicle, immediately lateral to the infraclavicular fossa, and can be palpated below the clavicle.

Parts of the scapula are given in the image below.

Related Pearl: Types of Epiphysis

There are four types of epiphysis.

Pressure epiphysis

  • Articular and assist in the transmission of weight
  • Found in regions of the bone that are under pressure during movement or locomotion
  • Examples: Head of the humerus, Head of the femur, Condyles of femur and tibia

Traction epiphysis

  • Non-articular and do not transmit weight
  • Provide attachment to one or more tendons that exert traction on the epiphysis
  • Traction epiphyses ossify later than pressure epiphyses
  • Examples: Greater and lesser tubercles of the humerus, and greater and lesser trochanters of the femur

Atavistic epiphysis

  • An independent bone in lower animals but in humans has fused to another bone
  • Examples: Coracoid process is fused to the scapula in humans but is a separate bone in four-legged animals

Aberrant epiphysis

  • Deviations from the normal and are not always present
  • Example: Epiphysis at the head of the first metacarpal and at the base of the other metacarpal bones

questions.text: All of the following structures form a boundary of the Myopectineal orifice of Fruchaud, except?
questions.solution:
External oblique muscle do not form a boundary of the Myopectineal orifice of Fruchaud.

The myopectineal orifice is an osseo-myo-aponeurotic tunnel. It is bounded:

  • Medially by the lateral border of the Rectus sheath.
  • Above by the arched fibers of the Internal oblique and Transversus abdominis muscle.
  • Laterally by the Iliopsoas muscle.
  • Below by the Pecten pubis and fascia covering it.

Clinical significance: It is a relatively weak portion of the abdominal wall that is divided by the inguinal ligament. It is through this tunnel that both femoral and inguinal hernias can occur, hence a single mesh over this orifice is curative for both of them.

Note: The inguinal ligament runs through the myopectineal orifice and does not form its boundary. It divides the myopectineal orifice into two regions: the suprainguinal region and the subinguinal region.

Related Pearl: The Triangle of Doom

The triangle of doom is bounded

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Apex oriented superiorly at internal ring.

The contents of the space include

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

questions.text: The posterior wall of the lesser sac is related to:
questions.solution:
The posterior wall of the lesser sac is related to the left suprarenal gland.

The lesser sac is a cavity lined with peritoneum and connected to the greater sac(main peritoneal cavity) by the epiploic foramen.

Superiorly, the peritoneum of the posterior wall of the lesser sac covers the following structures (from below upwards):

  • Pancreas
  • Upper pole of the left kidney
  • Left suprarenal gland
  • Abdominal aorta
  • Coeliac trunk
  • Diaphragm

Inferiorly, the posterior wall of the lesser sac is formed by the anterior layer of the posterior sheet of the greater omentum which covers the transverse mesocolon.

Related Pearl: Relations of epiploic foramen and lesser sac

Relations of epiploic foramen:

Anterior
  • Hepatoduodenal ligament containing hepatic artery, portal vein, and common bile duct

Posterior
  • Inferior vena cava
  • Right suprarenal gland
  • Body of T12 vertebra

Superior
  • Caudate lobe of the liver

Inferior
  • 1st part of duodenum

 

Relations of lesser sac:

Anterior
  • Caudate lobe of liver
  • Lesser omentum
  • Stomach
  • First 2 layers of the greater omentum

Posterior

Structures forming the stomach bed:

  • Pancreas
  • Splenic artery
  • Left kidney and suprarenal gland
  • Commencement of abdominal aorta and coeliac artery
  • Left crus of the diaphragm
  • Splenic flexure of the colon
  • Transverse mesocolon

Superior
  • Reflection of the peritoneum from the esophagus to the diaphragm

Inferior
  • Continuation of 2nd and 3rd layers of the greater omentum

questions.text: A 28-year-old lady, G2P1L1 with previous normal vaginal delivery comes to the clinic at 37 weeks of gestation for a routine check-up. On examination, the cervix is 50% effaced and 1cm dilated. AFI = 20cm, estimated fetal weight =2.5kg, the fetal head is well flexed and in breech presentation on the Ultrasound abdomen. All of the following management plans can be offered to her except?

choices.text: Schedule elective LSCS at 39 weeks of gestation
Allow progression to vaginal delivery with breech presentation

questions.solution:
This is a case of a G2P1L1 woman presenting for a routine antenatal visit at 37 weeks gestation and the fetus is in breech. All management plans can be offered to her except Emergency LSCS.

At present the patient is not in labor, given the absence of pain & cervix being only 50% effaced and 1cm dilated. With adequate Amniotic fluid, a well-flexed head (frank breech- effective cervical dilator) and no other comorbidities - an External cephalic version can be attempted given the gestational age. Previous history of normal vaginal delivery rules out contracted pelvis/ CPD. So, she can be allowed to progress to vaginal delivery spontaneously by breech presentation. Elective LSCS may be planned at 39 weeks to avoid risk to the mother & fetus.

The indications for LSCS in breech include:

  • Estimated fetal weight <1.5 or >3.5 kg
  • Hyperextended head (stargazing fetus)
  • Footling presentation (risk of cord prolapse)  
  • Suspected contracted pelvis or severe IUGR
  • Any associated obstetric or medical complications

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR) is correct?

choices.text: Symmetric IUGR - Occurs in late gestation
Asymmetric IUGR - Ponderal index of more than 2

questions.solution:
The correct statement is Symmetric IUGR has reduced cell number.

Symmetric IUGR is due to fetal causes like genetic anomalies and the onset is during the first trimester of pregnancy (Option A). Asymmetric IUGR is usually due to maternal causes, mainly the disorders of uteroplacental insufficiency. They usually start later in pregnancy (2nd or 3rd trimester).

IUGR, now known as Fetal growth restriction, is a prenatal diagnosis to describe a fetus who fails to reach in-utero growth potential.

Option B- Ponderal index (PI) is useful to distinguish between symmetric and asymmetric IUGR.  PI more than 2 is found in symmetric IUGR, whereas asymmetric IUGR babies have PI less than 2.

Option C- Asymmetric IUGR has a normal head circumference, reduced weight and low to normal length. Head circumference, length and weight- all are reduced in symmetric IUGR

questions.text: A woman with HIV was brought in to the emergency ward after an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. An MRI  revealed multiple enhancing lesions. A stereotactic biopsy of the lesion was done and the image is given below. Which of the following test can be used for the diagnosis of the organism?
questions.solution:
The above image (showing lymphocytes, macrophages, and eosinophils surrounding the toxoplasmosis bradyzoites encased in cysts with a cyst wall) and the case scenario suggest that the most likely diagnosis is cerebral toxoplasmosis. Sabin Feldman dye test is a serological test done for the detection of antibodies against Toxoplasma.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an opportunistic infection commonly found in the setting of HIV-associated immunosuppression and usually occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <200/μL. Toxoplasmosis of the CNS produces brain abscesses, which are found most often in the cerebral cortex (near the grey-white junction) and deep grey nuclei.

  • Acute lesions exhibit central necrosis, petechial hemorrhages surrounded by acute and chronic inflammation, macrophage infiltration, and vascular proliferation. Both free tachyzoites and encysted bradyzoites may be found at the periphery of the necrotic foci.
  • Chronic lesions consist of small cystic spaces containing scattered lipid and hemosiderin-laden macrophages that are surrounded by the gliotic brain.

Sabin Feldman dye test is a serological test done for the detection of antibodies against Toxoplasma. IIF, IHA, and CFT (component fixation test) are also used for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis. The dye test remains positive throughout life, while CFT becomes negative soon after acute infection. ELISA is most commonly used and IgM and IgG antibodies are estimated separately.

Standard treatment is sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine & leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks.

Primary Prophylaxis:

  • Prior toxoplasmic encephalitis and CD4+ T cell count <200/μL: Sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin
  • TOXO IgG antibody positive and CD4+ T cell count <100/μL : Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX)
  • The drug of choice for toxoplasmosis in pregnancy is spiramycin.

Other options:

Option A: Casoni’s test is used for Hydatid cysts.

Option B: Bachman test is used for Trichinellosis.

Option D: Montenegro test is used for Leishmaniasis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a mature cataract was planned for phacoemulsification surgery. Identify the wrong step from the given options below.
questions.solution:
Can-opener capsulotomy is not a part of phacoemulsification surgery. It is commonly used in extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) technique.

The preferred method for cataract surgery involves phacoemulsification-assisted extracapsular cataract extraction combined with foldable posterior chamber intraocular lens implantation in a bag. 

Step 1 - Small clear corneal incision. 
Step 2 - Continuous curvilinear capsulorrhexis: circular opening is made in the anterior capsule of the lens to access the cataract.
Step 3 - Hydro dissection: Fluid is injected beneath the anterior capsule to separate the lens from the capsular bag, facilitating its rotation and manipulation.
Step 4 - Hydro delineation: Fluid is injected between the nucleus and the epinuclear substance to help in separating the cortical matter from the nucleus.
Steps 5 and 6 - Phacoemulsification: Indicates the divide and conquer technique for removing the nucleus.
Step 7 - Removal of the cortical lens matter using an irrigation-aspiration technique.
Step 8 - Implantation of a foldable lens.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

 

Related Pearl: Different extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) techniques

Conventional ECCE

  • Incision: 10 to 2 o'clock
  • Anterior capsulotomy
    • Can opener’s technique
    • Envelope technique
    • Continuous circular capsulorrhexis

Manual SICS

  • Incision: 4-6 mm
  • A self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel incision is made.

Phacoemulsification

  • Incision:1.5–2.4 mm
  • Phacoprobe and foldable IOL is used
  • Sutureless surgery is possible with self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel or clear corneal incision.

questions.text: A man sustains a fall on the outstretched hand and develops swelling & pain over the dorsum of the wrist. X-ray findings are shown below. Which of the following tests is diagnostic of this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of a fall on an outstretched hand and the X-ray findings point towards scapholunate dissociation and it is diagnosed by Watson's test.

A fall on the outstretched hand resulting in swelling & tenderness over the dorsum just distal to Lister’s tubercle, with the X-ray showing lunate still in its original position while the rest of the carpals dislocated around it, points to a diagnosis of scapholunate dissociation. In the X-ray, the scaphoid may appear foreshortened, with a typical cortical ring sign. In the lateral view, the lunate is tilted dorsally and the scaphoid anteriorly. The scaphoid and lunate lose their normal relationship, the scaphoid flexes and the lunate extends, resulting in a scapholunate angle > 60 degrees and this is known as Dorsal Intercalated Segmental Instability (DISI).

Diagnosis is by Watson's test - pushing backward on the scaphoid tubercle is very painful and, if performed while moving the wrist radialwards and ulnarwards, it can elicit a clunk.

Other options:

Option A: Phalen’s test is used in the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome. Sensory symptoms like tingling, pain, and numbness elicited by holding the wrist fully flexed for less than 60 seconds indicate carpal tunnel syndrome.

Option B: The Eichoff test is when the examiner grasps and ulnar deviates the hand when the person has their thumb held within their fist. If sharp pain occurs along the distal radius, it indicates De Quervain's synovitis.

Option D: Durkan test is where one applies direct pressure over the carpal tunnel (median nerve) between the thenar and hypothenar eminence for 30 seconds. A positive test indicates any numbness, pain, or paresthesia along the median nerve territory. 

The X-ray below shows Scapholunate dissociation. The red arrow denotes the increased gap between the scaphoid and the lunate.

questions.text: A 22-year-old football player is tackled sideways during a game & he sustains injury to his left knee. Subsequently, he develops pain and swelling over the left knee and has to be removed from the game. The X-ray is shown below. Which of the following ligaments is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of this footballer with an X-ray showing a fracture near the edge of the lateral tibial condyle, near the iliotibial tract or capsule, suggests a Segond fracture.

It is widely associated with anterior cruciate ligament injury, along with medial collateral ligament tear, medial meniscus tear, and posterolateral corner injury. Both the iliotibial tract and the anterolateral ligament may be involved in the segond avulsion. It is commonly seen in anteromedial dislocations and high-grade varus knee injuries, as occurs in sports like football, netball, rugby, etc. The presence of synovial fluid prevents clot formation and promotes recovery of the fracture & ligamentous injury. Hence, surgical/ arthroscopic reconstruction is the most widely practised treatment, followed by extensive rehabilitation.

Lateral tibial condyle fracture is not associated with posterior cruciate ligament, lateral meniscus, or lateral collateral ligament injury. Injury to the medial femoral condyle results in a Pellegrini Stieda lesion - associated with a medial collateral ligament tear.

questions.text: A study was conducted among the postgraduate students in a medical college to find out the time taken by them to complete various tasks in different clinical departments. Which management technique is being applied for this analysis?
questions.solution:
The management technique that is being applied for the above study is work sampling.

Work sampling is a quantitative management technique.

Work sampling refers to systematic observation and recording of the activities of one or more individuals. It is done at predetermined or random intervals. It mainly includes analyzing the type of activities performed and the time needed to perform the same.

These studies have been done on doctors, nurses, pharmacists, and laboratory technicians. This technique can find the appropriateness of the current staff, job description, and training. This may standardize the methods of performing activities and determine the manpower needed in an organization.

Management is the purposeful and effective use of resources such as manpower, materials, and finances for the fulfillment of a pre-determined objective. They consist of four basic activities: planning, organizing, communicating, and monitoring.

Management techniques are of two types:

Quantitative methods

Methods based on behavioral sciences
  • Cost-Benefit analysis
  • Cost-Effective analysis
  • Cost-Accounting
  • Input-Output analysis
  • Model
  • Systems analysis
  • Network analysis
    • Program Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)
    • Critical Path Method (CPM)
  • Planning–Programming–Budgeting System (PPBS)
  • Work sampling
  • Decision making
  • Organizational design
  • Personnel management
  • Communication
  • Information systems
  • Management by objectives (MBO)

Other options:

Option A: Cost-effective analysis is a management technique in which the economic benefits of any program are compared with the cost of the program. The benefits are expressed in terms of the results achieved. (Eg: number of lives saved or number of days free from disease).

Option C- Critical pathway method is a type of network analysis technique. The longest path in the network is called the critical path. If any delay in activity along the critical pathway, the entire study will be delayed.

Option D- Input-output analysis is an economic technique to analyze the amount of input needed to produce a unit amount of output. In the health field, input refers to all health service activities that consume resources (manpower, money, materials, and time). Output refers to useful outcomes such as cases treated, lives saved, or inoculations performed.

Related Pearl: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male presents with a history of progressive shortness of breath over the last year. He has no history of smoking or occupational exposure. Auscultation reveals fine bilateral crepitations. His pulmonary function tests are given below. High-resolution CT of the chest shows basal predominant subpleural reticulations, honeycombing, and no ground-glass opacities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

FEV1: 2.1 L (72% predicted)

FVC: 2.4 L (58% predicted)

DLCO: 55% predicted

DLCO: Diffusing Capacity of the Lungs for Carbon Monoxide
questions.solution:
The given scenario, involving a patient with progressive dyspnea, a restrictive lung pattern on PFTs, and HRCT findings of basal predominant fibrosis with honeycombing without ground-glass opacities, suggests that the most likely diagnosis is usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP).

The patient’s pulmonary function tests (PFTs) reveal a restrictive lung pattern characterized by a reduced FVC (2.4 L, 58% predicted) and a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio (2.1 L/2.4 L = 87.5%), which indicates that the lungs cannot fully expand. Additionally, the severely reduced DLCO (55% predicted) suggests impaired gas exchange due to parenchymal damage. These findings and the clinical presentation strongly support a diagnosis of usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP).

Usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) is a chronic fibrotic lung disease characterized by progressive dyspnea and dry cough. It is commonly associated with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). PFTs show a restrictive pattern (↓ FVC) with a severely reduced DLCO, indicating impaired gas exchange due to fibrosis. HRCT Findings include honeycombing and reticulations in a basal, subpleural distribution, which are classic for UIP. The absence of ground-glass opacities differentiates it from other interstitial lung diseases.

Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) is a chronic, progressive, and ultimately fatal lung disease characterized by fibrosis and scarring of lung tissue, leading to declining lung function and respiratory failure. Pirfenidone and Nintedanib slow disease progression by reducing fibrosis. Management is Oxygen therapy, pulmonary rehabilitation, and symptom management (e.g., antitussives for cough).

Other options:

Option B: Desquamative interstitial pneumonia, (ΗRCT) shows ground glass opacities without the peripheral reticular opacities, characteristic of UΙP.

Option C: Nonspecific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) is also a restrictive lung disease. On imaging, it usually presents with diffuse ground-glass opacities and uniform interstitial thickening. Honeycombing is not typical of NSIP.

Option D: Pleural fibrosis is an extrapulmonary cause of restrictive lung disease and would not explain the parenchymal changes (reticulations and honeycombing) seen on HRCT.

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text: What is the action of the muscle supplied by the structure marked in the image?
questions.solution:
The arrow in the given image shows the trochlear nerve (CN IV). It is identified easily as it is the only cranial nerve to emerge from the dorsal surface of the brainstem. It supplies the superior oblique muscle. The actions carried out by the superior oblique muscle are intorsion, depression, and abduction. 

  • Lateral rectus is supplied by the abducens nerve (CN VI).
  • Medial rectus and inferior oblique are supplied by the oculomotor nerve (CN III).

Related Pearl: Structures passing through skull foramina

Opening Transmits
Optic canal
  • Optic nerves
  • Ophthalmic arteries
Superior orbital fissure
  • Lacrimal nerve (V1)
  • Frontal nerve (V1)
  • Nasociliary nerve (V1)
  • CNs III, IV, VI
  • Superior ophthalmic vein
  • Inferior ophthalmic vein
Foramen rotundum
  • Maxillary division of CN V (V2)
Foramen ovale
  • Mandibular division of CN V (V3)
  • Accessory meningeal artery
  • Lesser petrosal nerve
  • Emissary veins
Foramen spinosum
  • Middle meningeal artery
  • Nervus spinosus
  • Middle meningeal vein
Foramen lacerum
  • Deep petrosal nerve
  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • Emissary vein
Carotid canal
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Venous and sympathetic plexus around artery
Jugular foramen
  • Inferior petrosal sinus
  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • CNs IX,X & XI
  • Sigmoid Sinus continuing as IJV 
  • Middle meningeal branch of occipital artery
Hypoglossal canal
  • Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)
Foramen magnum
  • Osseo-ligamentous (anterior) compartment: 
    • Apical ligament and tip of dens
    • Upper band of cruciate ligament
    • Membrana tectoria
  • Neuro-vascular (posterior) compartment:
    • Lower end of the medulla oblongata with meninges
    • Fourth part of vertebral artery surrounded by sympathetic plexus of nerves
    • Spinal roots of accessory nerves
    • Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
    • Tonsil of cerebellum.
 

 

Related Pearl: Extraocular Muscles and Their Actions

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with a thin white vaginal discharge. Which of the following options does not belong to Amsel's criteria for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis?

choices.text: Presence of epithelial cells with bacteria adhered around them.
White milky non viscous discharge adherent to vaginal wall.
Fishy odour when mixed with 10% KOH

questions.solution:
The pH of discharge more than 4.5 is included in Amsel's criteria for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis.

Bacterial vaginosis occurs due to an alteration in the normal vaginal flora, specifically the lactobacilli. Lactobacilli are responsible for maintaining vaginal pH and reducing the growth of other pathogenic bacteria. In this condition, the number of lactobacilli is reduced, resulting in an increase in the number of pathogenic organisms like Gardnerella vaginalis, Haemophilus vaginalis, Mobiluncus, and Mycoplasma hominins.

It is diagnosed using Amsel's criteria:

  • White milky non-viscous discharge adherent to the vaginal wall.
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Amine-like odor on adding KOH - Potassium hydroxide (whiff test positive)
  • Presence of clue cells (>20% of cells) which are epithelial cells with bacteria adhered around them.

Metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or clindamycin cream (2%) applied intravaginally daily at bedtime for 7 days can be used to treat bacterial vaginosis.

The images given below show clue cells:

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis

Candidal vaginitis
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomonas vaginalis Candida albicans
Aetiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual transmission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: Test shown in the image is useful for the detection of ________________
questions.solution:
The test shown in the photograph is rapid plasma reagin test used to detect Treponema pallidum.

RPR test is one of the nonspecific tests  commonly used to screen the population for syphilis. The RPR test measures IgM and IgG antibodies to lipoidal material released from damaged host cells as well as to lipoprotein-like material, and possibly cardiolipin released from the treponemes.

Antigen used in RPR Test:

RPR antigen contains cardiolipin, lecithin, cholesterol, 10% choline chloride, EDTA, charcoal etc in buffer. The test uses the VDRL antigen containing fine carbon particle ,which makes result more clear cut and evident to naked eye.

Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete bacillus. It is a sexually transmitted infection. Intrauterine transmission can lead to congenital syphilis.

It shows corkscrew motility which can be demonstrated by darkfield microscopy. 

Treponema can be stained by silver impregnation methods. 

  • Fontana's method is used on smear
  • Levaditi's method is used for tissue sections

The clinical manifestations of syphilis include:

Primary syphilis: The typical primary chancre usually begins as a single painless papule that rapidly becomes eroded and usually becomes indurated, with a characteristic cartilaginous consistency on palpation of the edge and base of the ulcer.

Inguinal lymphadenopathy is bilateral and may occur with anal as well as with genital chancres. The chancre generally heals within 4–6 weeks (range, 2–12 weeks), but lymphadenopathy may persist for months.

Secondary syphilis: The various features include mucocutaneous or cutaneous lesions and generalized nontender lymphadenopathy. macular, papular, papulosquamous, and occasionally pustular syphilides. Other features of secondary syphilis include sore throat, fever, weight loss, malaise, anorexia, headache, and meningismus. Ocular findings associated with secondary (or later/ unknown-stage) syphilis include pupillary abnormalities and optic neuritis as well as the classic iritis or uveitis.

Latent syphilis: Early latent syphilis is limited to the first year after infection, whereas late latent syphilis is defined as that of 1 year’s duration (or of unknown duration). T. pallidum may still seed the bloodstream intermittently during the latent stage, and latent syphilis in a pregnant woman may infect the fetus in utero. 

Neurosyphilis:  The major clinical categories of symptomatic neurosyphilis include meningeal, meningovascular, and parenchymatous syphilis.

Cardiovascular syphilis: Cardiovascular involvement results in uncomplicated aortitis, aortic regurgitation, saccular aneurysm (usually of the ascending aorta), or coronary ostial stenosis.

Congenital syphilis: The earliest manifestations of congenital syphilis include rhinitis, or “snuffles”; mucocutaneous lesions, bone changes, including periostitis detectable by x-ray examination of long bones; hepatosplenomegaly,  lymphadenopathy , anemia
, jaundice,  thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis.

Serologic tests for syphilis recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC):

  1. Screening or diagnosis (RPR or VDRL),
  2. Quantitative measurement of antibody to assess clinical syphilis activity or to monitor response to therapy (RPR or VDRL)
  3. Confirmation of a syphilis diagnosis in a patient with a reactive RPR or VDRL test (FTA-ABS, TPHA, EIA/CIA)

Treatment of syphilis is with 2.4 million units of intramuscular benzathine penicillin.

Related Pearl: Syphilis - Diagnostic Serology

Nontreponemal tests (VDRL, RPR)

VDRL- Venereal disease Research Laboratory test

RPR- Rapid Plasma Reagin test

  • Quantitative tests(titres)
  • Reagin antibody tests; based on cardiolipin antigen
  • VDRL can be used to test CSF whereas RPR cannot be used
  • RPR does not require preheating of serum unlike VDRL
  • VDRL requires light microscope for interpretation whereas RPR can be read macroscopically
  • Decrease in titers confirms treatment
  • Sensitivity of RPR(86%)>VDRL(76%) in primary syphilis

Treponemal Tests

FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

TPI-Treponema pallidum immobilization test

TPPA-Treponema pallidum particle agglutination assay

TPHA-Treponema pallidum haemagglutination test

EIA-Enzyme-linked ImmunoAssay

  • Detect antibody to treponemal antigens
  • Qualitative tests
  • Greater sensitivity in early infection
  • Positive even after treatment hence cannot be used to detect reinfection.
  • First test to be positive: FTA-ABS
  • Most specific: TPHA,TPPA, EIA

questions.text: A 26-day-old infant is brought to the casualty with increased work of breathing for the past 4 days.  On examination, the patient has tachypnea, tachycardia, and an oxygen saturation of 88% in room air. A chest X-ray and CT scan are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypoxia (SpO₂ 88%), combined with imaging findings of hyperinflation with herniation into the contralateral lung field, strongly suggest Congenital Lobar Emphysema (CLE).

Congenital Lobar Emphysema (CLE) occurs when one or more lobes of the lung become overinflated due to bronchial obstruction or vascular compression. This leads to lung hyperinflation, which causes respiratory distress in the affected infant. CLE commonly affects the left upper lobe. Surgical resection of the affected lobe is required.

Other options:

Option A: Pulmonary Hypoplasia typically shows decreased lung volume with smaller lung fields and flattened diaphragms. The affected lung or lungs will be disproportionately smaller than normal and might appear less aerated. Below is an image of left lung pulmonary hypoplasia.

Option C: Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH) shows gas-filled bowel loops in the thorax with mediastinal shift, while CLE shows overinflated lung segments rather than abdominal contents. Below is an X-ray of CDH:

Option D: Pyopneumothorax shows a gas-fluid level with a thick pleural lining. Patients typically have a fever, chest pain, and signs of infection, unlike CLE, which is non-infectious and congenital. Below is an X-ray of pyopneumothorax:

questions.text:
A microbiologist is about to run a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay on the serum of a patient suspected to have a Herpes simplex virus infection. Choose the correct sequence of steps done in PCR.
  1. DNA extraction
  2. Denaturation
  3. Annealing
  4. Extension
questions.solution:
Option D (1-2-3-4) is correct. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) involves the following steps: DNA extraction from the organism, DNA amplification (denaturation, annealing, extension), and gel electrophoresis of the amplified product.

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is a rapid automated method for the amplification of specific DNA sequences (or genes).

Steps:

  1. DNA extraction from the organism
  2. Amplification of the extracted DNA in a thermocycler where it is subjected to repeated cycles. Each cycle has three steps:
    1. Denaturation - heating to separate double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) into two separate strands (ssDNA)
    2. Annealing - addition of primer which anneals or attaches to the target ssDNA
    3. Extension - addition of free nucleotides to the growing end of the primer by DNA polymerase 
  3. Gel electrophoresis of the amplified product

Types of PCR:

  • Reverse transcriptase PCR- The enzyme reverse transcriptase (RT) is used to synthesize a complementary copy of DNA (cDNA) from RNA and this cDNA is then used as a template for PCR.
  • Real-time PCR- This helps quantify the PCR and gives an estimate of the pathogen DNA load in the specimen. It uses fluorescent dyes or specific DNA probes. It is also known as qPCR (Quantitative PCR)
  • Multiplex PCR- Primers to more than one pathogen are used simultaneously and hence multiple products are obtained. 
  • Nested PCR- It involves the sequential use of two primer sets. The first primer set is used for amplification and the amplicon obtained is then used as a target sequence for second amplification. This ensures specificity. 

The image below shows the various ingredients involved in PCR.

questions.text: Masaoka staging system is used for which tumor?
questions.solution:
Masaoka staging system is used for staging thymoma. It is based on the presence or absence of metastasis and gross or microscopic invasion of the capsule and surrounding structures. 

Masaoka staging system for thymoma:

Stage

Features

Stage I

Encapsulated tumor with no gross or microscopic evidence of capsular invasion

Stage II

Gross capsular invasion or invasion into the mediastinal fat or pleura or microscopic capsular invasion

Stage III

Gross invasion into the pericardium, great vessels, or lung

Stage IVA

Pleural or pericardial dissemination

Stage IVB

Lymphogenous or hematogenous metastasis

Management of Thymoma:

Stage I - complete surgical excision only

Stage II & III - complete surgical excision followed by radiotherapy

Stage IV & metastatic disease - neoadjuvant chemotherapy + surgery + postoperative radiotherapy

questions.text:
Which of the following structures are present in the plane marked as 1?
  1. Origin of the celiac trunk
  2. Origin of the portal vein
  3. Lower limit of the spinal cord in newborn
  4. Lower limit of the spinal cord in adults
  5. Origin of the superior mesenteric artery
questions.solution:
The structure marked "1" in the image is transpyloric plane that passes through the lower border of L1. The origin of the portal vein, the lower limit of the spinal cord in adults, and the origin of the superior mesenteric artery are present on this plane.

The transpyloric plane (Addison's plane) passes midway between the suprasternal notch of the manubrium and the upper border of the pubic symphysis. This approximately corresponds to midway between the xiphisternal joint and the umbilicus.

Posteriorly, this plane passes through the lower half of the body of the first lumbar vertebra (lower border of L1). 

Anteriorly, it intersects the costal margin at the ninth costal cartilage.

Structures present in the transpyloric plane:

Organs  Neurovascular structures 
Pylorus of stomach Origin of the superior mesenteric artery
Neck of the pancreas Origin of the renal artery
Duodenojejunal flexure Origin of the portal vein (behind the neck of the pancreas)
Fundus of the gallbladder Lower limit of the spinal cord in adults
Hilum of the left kidney (right kidney is slightly lower)  Cisterna chyli

 Other options:

  • The origin of the celiac trunk is at T12 level and
  • The lower limit of the spinal cord in newborn is at L3 level.

questions.text: A young boy presenting with hematuria was suspected to have nephritis. Further evaluation reveals sensorineural hearing loss and anterior lenticonus. His uncle has chronic kidney disease. What are the electron microscopy findings expected to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Diffuse thinning of the glomerular basement membrane
Irregular thickening and thinning of the glomerular basement membrane
Diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane
Focal thickening of the glomerular basement membrane

questions.solution:
A young boy with hematuria, sensorineural hearing loss, anterior lenticonus, and positive family history is suggestive of Alport syndrome. Electron microscopy shows irregular thickening and thinning of the glomerular basement membrane in Alport syndrome.

Alport syndrome, or hereditary nephritis is due to a gene mutation in type IV collagen. The majority have X-linked inheritance. There are no significant light microscopy changes in Alport syndrome. On electron microscopy, the glomerular basement membrane shows: 

  • Irregular foci of thickening, alternating with attenuation (thinning)
  • Pronounced splitting and lamination of the lamina densa - Basket-weave appearance  

Note: Trick for Alport Syndrome  = "Can't pee, can't see, can't hear a bee." - hematuria, eye symptoms, hearing loss

The following are the differences between Alport's syndrome and benign familial hematuria.

Features

Alport syndrome

 Benign familial hematuria
 Affected protein

α5 chain of type IV collagen (Most commonly)

 α3 or α4 chains of type IV collagen.
 Hearing Loss  Present  Absent
Ocular abnormalities  Present  Absent
Progress to end-stage renal disease Yes No
Electron microscopy

Irregular thickening and thinning of basement membrane 

Splitting and lamination of lamina densa - basket-weave appearance 

 Diffuse thinning of the glomerular basement membrane
Prognosis Poor Good

questions.text: Which of the following disease-IVP finding pair is incorrect?

choices.text: Cobra/ Adder head appearance - Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter
Fish hook / Reverse J deformity - Retrocaval ureter
Handshake sign/ Hand-holding sign - Horseshoe kidney

questions.solution:
Adder head appearance/cobra head sign or the spring onion sign is seen in the ureterocele. 

It refers to dilatation of the distal ureter, surrounded by a thin rim to the ureteric wall and bladder mucosa. It is seen in patients with an adult-type ureterocele. The cobra head appearance indicates an uncomplicated ureterocele. 

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter is associated with a goblet appearance, best visualized via a retrograde urogram.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: An elderly patient was brought to the emergency room with a severe headache. On examination, his blood pressure was 180/100 mmHg. An intracerebral bleed is suspected. Which of the following locations is the bleed most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
The most common site of hypertensive bleed in the brain is basal ganglia and putamen. Patients typically present with severe headache. The most common cause of intracerebral hemorrhages is hypertension.

Following are the usual locations of ICH: 

  •   Basal ganglia hemorrhage (especially the putamen)
  •   Thalamic hemorrhage
  •   Pontine hemorrhage
  •   Cerebellar hemorrhage 

The investigation of choice in stroke is non-contrast CT.

The following image shows bleeding in the basal ganglia on a non-contrast CT brain:

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to frequent stumbling and unsteady gait that has progressively worsened over the past year. On physical examination, you notice visible dilated blood vessels in the sclera. Which of the following statements about this condition is false?

choices.text: Recurrent sinopulmonary infections are common in affected children
IgA levels are typically increased in children with this condition
There is an increased risk of malignancies associated with this condition
It occurs due to chromosomal instability with rearrangements between chromosomes 7 and 14

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with an unsteady gate with dilated blood vessels in the sclera is suggestive of ataxia telangiectasia in this child. Ataxia-telangiectasia is characterized by decreased levels of immunoglobulin A (IgA). 

Ataxia-Telangiectasia (A-T) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATM (Ataxia-Telangiectasia Mutated) gene on chromosome 11q22.3. The ATM gene encodes a serine/threonine kinase essential for DNA damage repair, particularly in homologous recombination and cell cycle checkpoint control. Mutations in ATM lead to defective homologous recombination, causing chromosomal instability (random translocations, especially between chromosomes 7 & 14), increased sensitivity to radiation, and accumulation of DNA damage.

Clinical features include progressive cerebellar ataxia (Unsteady gait, frequent falls, dysarthria), Oculocutaneous Telangiectasia, and Immunodeficiency (predominantly IgA and IgG2 deficiency)- increase the patient's susceptibility to recurrent sinopulmonary infections and increase the risk of developing malignancies, including B-cell lymphomas, T-cell leukemias, and various solid tumors.

Diagnosis is by detection of Elevated α-fetoprotein (AFP), Low serum IgA and IgG2, Lymphopenia, and ATM gene sequencing for confirmation.

Management is primarily supportive (antibiotics & IVIG for recurrent infections) and regular cancer screening.

questions.text: Histological image of the cerebellum is given below. What is false about the cells marked in the given image?

choices.text: These cells are arranged in a layer between the molecular and granular layers
They are the only output neurons of the cerebellar cortex
These cells are inhibitory in nature

questions.solution:
The cells marked in the above histological image are Purkinje cells and they use γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) as their neurotransmitter.

Characteristics of Purkinje cells:

  • Purkinje cells are the flask-shaped cells present in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellum.
  • The cells are evenly spaced and are arranged in a single layer.
  • A dendrite arises from the neck of each flask-shaped cell, which passes upward to enter the molecular layer, which then branches extensively to form a dendritic tree.
  • The axon of each cell passes downwards, crosses the granular cell layer to enter the white matter.
  • Axons of Purkinje cells are the only efferents of the cerebellar cortex.
  • The initial segment of the axon receives synaptic contacts from basket cell axons.
  • The main axon terminates in one of the cerebellar or vestibular nuclei.
  • Purkinje cells are inhibitory and use GABA as their neurotransmitter.

Pathological significance:

  • Negri bodies in rabies, are usually found as eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusions in the neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells.
  • Loss of Purkinje cells and granule cells is seen in ataxia-telangiectasia.
  • In patients with subacute cerebellar degeneration, there is the destruction of Purkinje cells. Some patients show circulating the PCA­1 antibody (anti­Yo) against Purkinje cells.
  • Purkinje cells and neurons in pyramidal cell layers of the hippocampus and cerebral cortex are the most sensitive neurons to hypoxia and are likely to be damaged in cases of global cerebral ischemia.

Related Pearl: Layers of the cerebellar cortex

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer. It contains stellate cells and basket cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers giving it a pale appearance in H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - It is the middle layer. It contain flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells. Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells passes through the granular layer into the white matter and synapses with the cerebellar nuclei.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells as well as Golgi cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end on the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches form the T and are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. Golgi cells receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Neurotransmitters released:

  • Stellate, basket, Golgi and Purkinje cells- GABA
  • Granule cells - Glutamate

The only output from the cerebellar cortex is inhibitory from the Purkinje cells to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with Hepatitis B and poorly controlled hypertension presents with skin lesions as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the patient most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
Uncontrolled hypertension in a Hepatitis B-positive patient with livedo reticularis (as shown in the image) is most likely due to renal artery involvement secondary to Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN). 

PAN is necrotizing arteritis of the medium and small-sized vessels. It is usually associated with Hepatitis B. PAN can affect the skin, peripheral nerves, renal vessels, mesenteric vessels, heart, and brain. Lungs are usually spared in PAN. The disease initially starts with non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, arthralgia, and myalgia. Later, depending on the artery involved, patients may develop the following symptoms:

  • Skin findings - ulcers, digital gangrene, subcutaneous nodules, and livedo reticularis (due to slowed blood flow through superficial horizontal venous plexus)
  • Renal arteries - hypertension and renal failure (No Glomerular involvement)
  • Mesenteric arteries - abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bleeding, and bowel perforation

PAN characteristically spares pulmonary arteries, rarely may involve bronchial arteries. On histopathological examination, it shows segmental, transmural necrotizing inflammation of small to medium-sized arteries, often with aneurysms or thrombosis. Acute-phase lesions show transmural inflammation with neutrophils, eosinophils, mononuclear cells, fibrinoid necrosis, and thrombosis. Older lesions develop fibrous thickening extending into the adventitia. Various stages of lesions often coexist within or across vessels, indicating ongoing injury.

There are no serological tests for PAN and diagnosis is often through biopsy of the affected organ’s blood vessels. Renal artery involvement is a common cause of mortality in these patients. Immunosuppression with Glucocorticoids and Cyclophosphamide often helps in remission in most cases.

Other options: 

Option A: Giant cell arteritis doesn't usually result in hypertension and is often associated with unilateral pulsating type of headaches in elderly females. 

Option B: Buerger’s disease involves veins and nerves as well, often presenting as a long-standing claudication type of pain in the lower extremities and is associated with smoking.

Option C: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s Granulomatosis) which often presents with manifestations of pulmonary arterial hypertension and glomerulonephritis. 

Related Pearl: Important Vasculitis with Features

Vasculitis

Predominant vessel involved

Inflammatory cells

Other features

Temporal arteritis

(Large vessel vasculitis)

Temporal, vertebral and ophthalmic arteries, aorta

Lymphocytes, and macrophages

>40 years old, polymyalgia rheumatica, granulomas, giant cells

Takayasu Arteritis

(Large vessel vasculitis)

(Medium-sized and large arteries) Aortic arch, great vessels, pulmonary artery, coronary and renal arteries

Lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils, granulomas, giant cells

Pulseless disease

 

Polyarteritis Nodosa

Small or medium-sized muscular arteries, typically involving renal and visceral vessels

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Spares pulmonary vessels, 30% of patients with  chronic hepatitis B

Microscopic polyangiitis

Capillaries, small arterioles, venules

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Necrotizing glomerulonephritism (90% of patients) and pulmonary capillaritis leukocytoclastic vasculitis

Churg-Strauss Syndrome

Medium and small arteries

 

Eosinophils (required), lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils

Associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, lung infiltrates, peripheral hypereosinophilia, and extravascular necrotizing granulomata.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented to the ENT OPD with unilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis. On endoscopy, a pale polypoidal mass was seen, and histopathological biopsy showed the following finding. What is the most common site of this tumor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with histopathological biopsy showing ribbons of thickened epithelial proliferations growing downwards into the stroma suggests a diagnosis of inverted papilloma. The most common site of inverted papilloma is the middle meatus in the lateral wall of the nose.

An inverted papilloma is a benign tumor originating from the nasal cavity's non-olfactory mucosa (respiratory mucosa), the Schneiderian membrane. HPV types 6 and 11 are believed to play a significant role in its development. This condition predominantly affects men aged 40-70.

Clinically, they are almost always unilateral and typically present with symptoms such as nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis. Due to their location and growth characteristics, these tumors can invade adjacent structures, including the sinuses and, in some cases, the orbit, necessitating careful monitoring and management. On nasal endoscopy, it presents as a pale polypoidal mass. Biopsy is essential for diagnosis.

Medial maxillectomy is the treatment of choice. It can be performed using lateral rhinotomy or a sublabial degloving approach. Radiotherapy is avoided due to the potential risk of malignant transformation.

Related Pearl: Inverted Papilloma

Inverted papilloma is also known as transitional cell papilloma or Ringertz tumor or Schneiderian papilloma. It is a common benign tumour of the paranasal sinuses. It is a premalignant condition with 10-15% chances of turning malignant.

Etiology: Human papillomavirus has been implicated in its etiology.

Origin: Arises from the lateral wall of the nose from the non-olfactory epithelium of the nose

Clinical features:

  • More common in men.
  • Predominance between 40-70 years.
  • Unilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis are the main presenting symptoms
  • It is a locally invasive tumor and can invade orbit and paranasal sinuses.
  • Proptosis, diplopia, and lacrimation can result from orbital invasion

Findings: It is seen as a pale polypoidal mass resembling a simple nasal polyp.

Investigations: A biopsy is needed for diagnosis.

Treatment: Medial maxillectomy via lateral rhinotomy or midfacial degloving approach. Radiotherapy can lead to malignancy.

questions.text: Arrange the following in descending order of Minimal alveolar concentration (MAC).
questions.solution:
The order of minimal alveolar concentration is N2O> Xenon> Sevoflurane> Isoflurane (Option B).

N2O is the only gas that has a MAC>100%. This means that even at 100% N2O concentration, it cannot cause skeletal muscle paralysis in half the population. Its MAC is 104%. Hence N2O is always combined with other anaesthetics. Xenon is an inert gas with a MAC of 73%.

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients. 

MAC of inhaled anesthetics

Anesthetic Agents

MAC (Potency)

Blood-gas coefficient (Solubility)
Halothane 0.75  2.4
Isoflurane 1.2 1.4 
Enflurane 1.7 1.9 
Sevoflurane 2 0.65 
Desflurane 6 0.42 
Nitrous oxide 104 0.47 

MAC is an indicator of potency. The lower the MAC, the higher is the potency.

questions.text: A 5-month-old child presents with mild diarrhea for the past 3 days. Today, he developed severe lethargy and had an episode of seizures. Laboratory testing reveals hypoketotic hypoglycemia. Deficiency of which of the following enzymes could produce this kind of test result?
questions.solution:
This child, with lethargy, seizures, and hypoketotic hypoglycemia, is likely to have medium-chain acyl CoA dehydrogenase deficiency.

Medium-chain acyl CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency is a disroder associated with mitochondrial fatty acid beta-oxidation. It is one of the most common inborn errors of metabolism. MCAD is an important enzyme involved in fatty acid beta-oxidation, which is important in producing ketone bodies as an energy source when blood glucose levels are low.

It is usually diagnosed at birth during routine screening for disorders of the newborn. However, sometimes, it can be detected within the first two years of life. These babies present with vomiting that progresses to lethargy and seizures triggered by mild illness. The common laboratory results seen in these patients result from a failure to synthesize ketone bodies during episodes of hypoglycemia. Hence, the child will present with hypoketotic hypoglycemia.

The diagnosis can be confirmed with a combination of biochemical and genetic testing. This illness, once diagnosed, can be easily managed with small, frequent meals to avoid a state of hypoglycemia.

Other options:

Option B: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency can result in phenylketonuria. This is an inborn error of metabolism in which phenylalanine is unable to convert to tyrosine, resulting in the accumulation of phenylalanine. This results in the characteristic 'musty' odor of the urine and body fluids. These children can also present with seizures and hyperactivity. In fact, many of the symptoms result from increased phenylpyruvate (a ketoacid) derived from the buildup of phenylalanine in this condition.

Option C: UMP synthase is an enzyme deficiency that results in orotic aciduria. This disorder is an inborn error of pyrimidine metabolism that presents with developmental delay, failure to thrive, and possibly epilepsy. Laboratory testing reveals pancytopenia.  

Option D: HMG CoA reductase is an important enzyme involved in the synthesis of cholesterol. This enzyme is targeted by statins, which are prescribed in hypercholesterolemia and in patients at risk for cardiovascular events. 

Related Pearl: Rothera's Test Procedure

Rothera's test, positive for ketone bodies.

Related Pearl: Inborn Errors of Amino Acid Metabolism and Their Associated Urine Odor

Inborn Error of Metabolism

Urine Odor
