Related Pearl: Types, Location and Properties of Fatty acid oxidation

Types of Oxidation

Location

Properties

Associated Disease

Beta oxidation

Mitochondria

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

  

Alpha oxidation

Peroxisome

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

 

Omega oxidation

Endoplasmic Reticulum

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

  

Peroxisomal Beta oxidation

Peroxisome

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents with a malignant lesion in the sigmoid colon. Preoperative evaluation reveals an elevated carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) level and no evidence of distant metastasis. After tumor resection, the pathology report indicates lymphovascular invasion. What is the next best step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Observation with regular follow-up using colonoscopy only
Targeted therapy with Bevacizumab as monotherapy

questions.solution:
The FOLFOX regimen (5-FU, Leucovorin, and Oxaliplatin) is the standard adjuvant chemotherapy for patients having colorectal cancer and high-risk features, such as lymphovascular invasion and elevated CEA levels. It significantly reduces the risk of recurrence and improves survival.

Other options:

Option A. While surveillance with colonoscopy is a crucial part of post-treatment care for colorectal cancer, it is insufficient as a stand-alone approach. The presence of lymphovascular invasion and elevated preoperative CEA levels indicates a higher risk of recurrence, necessitating systemic therapy to improve outcomes.

Option C. Radiation therapy is primarily reserved for rectal cancer to reduce local recurrence rates. It is not routinely used for colon cancer unless there is involvement of adjacent structures or other specific indications.

Option D. Bevacizumab is an anti-VEGF monoclonal antibody used in metastatic colorectal cancer in combination with chemotherapy. As monotherapy, it has limited efficacy and is not indicated in this patient, who does not have evidence of distant metastasis.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents with dysmenorrhoea, menorrhagia, and infertility. After ruling out other possible causes, the gynecologist performs a laparoscopy. The image depicts lesions seen in the pelvis during laparoscopy. Which of the following is a GnRH agonist used in this condition?
questions.solution:
Dysmenorrhoea, menorrhagia, infertility, and a chocolate cyst of the ovary (seen in the image) point towards the diagnosis of Endometriosis.  Goserelin is a GnRH agonist used for the management of Endometriosis.

GnRH agonist uses: carcinoma prostate, uterine fibroids, endometriosis, and precocious puberty. Side effects include hot flashes, decreased bone mineral density, vaginal dryness, and erectile dysfunction.

Routes of administration of GnRH agonists are 

  • Buserelin - intranasal spray and Subcutaneous implant 
  • Histrelin - subcutaneous implant
  • Goserelin - subcutaneous implant
  • Leuprolide- IM and subcutaneous implant
  • Nafarelin -nasal spray and subcutaneous implant

All GnRH antagonists are administered subcutaneously. Some GnRH antagonists are:

  • Cetrorelix
  • Degarelix
  • Ganirelix

Side effects of GnRH antagonists include hot flashes, decreased bone mineral density, vaginal dryness, and erectile dysfunction.

Gestodene is a testosterone derivative of progestogen and is used in HRT, premenstrual syndrome, and threatened abortion. Danazol is a synthetic androgen used in the treatment of endometriosis, and hereditary angioedema.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: A 68-year-old diabetic male patient presented with complaints of diminished vision. The optical coherence tomography (OCT) image is given below. Which of the following findings is likely to be seen on fundus fluorescein angiography of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and OCT image showing intraretinal cystoid spaces are suggestive of cystoid macular edema (CME). Fundus fluorescein angiography image is likely to show a characteristic flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance) in CME.

CME occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier. A petaloid pattern is seen due to dye accumulation in microcystic spaces in the outer plexiform layer.

Common causes of CME include uveitis, previous cataract surgery (Irvine-Gass syndrome), retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, retinitis pigmentosa, retinopathy of prematurity and topical prostaglandins. Macular edema and cysts may also occur due to niacin toxicity (vitamin B3).

Clinical features in the initial stage include minimal to moderate vision loss. Usually, there are no other associated symptoms. In case of persistent edema, permanent vision loss may occur.

OCT reveals a loss of the foveal depression, thickening of the retina and multiple cystoid areas in the sensory retina. On fundoscopy, the multiple cystoid oval spaces in CME appear as a  "honeycomb appearance". Optic disc swelling may be seen in some cases. A lamellar hole may occur in long-standing cases.

The image below shows the flower petal pattern in CME.

 

Other options:

Option B: A smokestack appearance is a small hyperfluorescent spot that ascends vertically like a smokestack that looks like an umbrella or a mushroom. It is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR)

 

Option C: Stars in sky appearance is seen in drusens

 

Option D: Inkblot pattern or enlarging dot appearance is a small hyperfluorescent spot that gradually enlarges in size. It is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR)

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman undergoes Total Hip Replacement surgery and is started on thromboembolic prophylaxis with unfractionated heparin. 5 days later, she develops deep vein thrombosis involving the calf veins. Complete blood count findings are given below. Which of the following drugs must be started in this patient?

WBC- 7000 /mm3
Hb- 12 gm %
Platelets - 55,000 /mm3
questions.solution:
Deep vein thrombosis and thrombocytopenia (platelet count 50,000/mm3) in a post-surgical patient on unfractionated heparin, points towards a diagnosis of Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT). Heparin should be immediately stopped and Argatroban must be started in this patient.

Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT) is a life-threatening complication of heparin. It usually occurs within 3-5 days of starting unfractionated or low molecular weight (LMW) heparin. Fondaparinux does not cause HIT. HIT results from an autoantibody directed against endogenous platelet factor 4 (PF4) in complex with heparin. This antibody activates platelets and can cause arterial and venous thrombosis. HIT diagnosis can be done by detecting levels of the Heparin-PF4 antibodies or with platelet activation assays.

Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia is managed by :

  • Stop heparin - unfractionated or low molecular weight heparin.
  • Alternative anticoagulant such as argatroban, bivalirudin, fondaparinux, or rivaroxaban can be started.
  • Platelet transfusions are not recommended for thrombocytopenia
  • Warfarin must not be administered when platelet count is low.

Other options:

Option A: Warfarin is contraindicated in HIT. It can cause a transient hypercoagulable state due to its inhibition of proteins C and S. Starting warfarin in HIT is associated with an increased risk of warfarin-induced skin necrosis.

Option B: Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor. It is not the first-line therapy for HIT.

Option D: Enoxaparin, an LMWH, is contraindicated in HIT because it can also activate PF4-heparin antibodies, worsening the condition.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man from eastern India was referred with a history of two weeks of fever which did not respond well to antibiotics. On examination, he has lymphadenopathy and abdominal distension with splenomegaly. A rapid antibody test with rk39 was found to be positive. A tissue smear from a splenic biopsy showed amastigotes. Which of the following is an oral drug that can be used to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
Miltefosine is the first oral drug against Leishmaniasis and it is registered for use in India.

Miltefosine is administered at a daily oral dose of 2.5mg/kg in two divided doses for 28 days. The side effects are short-lived and include nausea, vomiting, increased transaminases, and abnormal renal function.

This patient's clinical presentation of persistent fever, lymphadenopathy, and abdominal distension with splenomegaly along with the demonstration of amastigotes in tissue culture is suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis. A rapid immunochromatographic test to detect antibodies against rK39 recombinant antigen of L.infantum can be used on the field.

Medical therapy for leishmaniasis includes:

In most endemic regions (except in India and Mediterranian countries):

  • Pentavalent antimonial is the drug of choice (sodium stibogluconate or meglumine antimoniate) - route IV or IM
  • If the initial pentavalent antimonial fails, then amphotericin B (AmB) is used - route IV

In India and Mediterranian countries:

  • Liposomal AmB is the drug of choice - route IV infusion
  • Paromomycin (route IM) is as effective as amphotericin

Miltefosine is also the drug of choice for the treatment of post-kala azar dermal leishmaniasis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the ER after a road traffic accident, sustaining a tibial fracture. He is admitted for preoperative management but now reports increasing pain and tingling sensations in his foot. You initiate compartmental pressure monitoring. At what absolute compartment pressure should an emergency fasciotomy be performed?
questions.solution:
The safest approach for this patient with suspected compartment syndrome is to perform fasciotomy when the absolute compartment pressure is equal to or greater than 30 mm Hg. 

Compartment syndrome occurs when increased pressure within a muscle compartment compromises circulation and tissue viability. In this scenario, the tibial fracture has caused swelling and bleeding within the compartment, increasing pressure and compressing nerves and blood vessels. The patient's severe pain, tingling sensations, and worsening symptoms suggest impending tissue damage, requiring urgent fasciotomy. If untreated, it can lead to muscle necrosis, permanent nerve damage, and limb loss.

Monitoring intra-compartment pressures (ICPs) can guide management. The normal tissue compartment pressure ranges from 0 to 9 mm Hg.

Indications for fasciotomy:

  • Absolute compartment pressure ≥30 mmHg
  • Differential pressure (ΔP) (diastolic BP - compartment pressure) ≤30 mmHg

Related Pearl: Acute Compartment and Crush Syndromes

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes less than or equal to 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush Syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: A researcher is planning to conduct a cohort study to find the association between smoking and the development of bladder cancer. While considering the disadvantages of cohort studies, which of the following biases is least relevant to this type of study?
questions.solution:
Berksonian bias is least relevant to cohort studies. This bias is more commonly encountered in case-control studies due to the selection of participants based on hospital admission rates.

Cohort studies follow participants over time based on their exposure status using population-based samples. This design avoids the reliance on hospital-based data, reducing the risk of Berkson’s bias.

Disadvantages of cohort study:

  • Cannot be used for uncommon diseases
  • Require long follow-up periods and substantial resources
  • Attrition Bias: Participants may drop out over time, leading to incomplete data and skewed results.
  • Hawthorne Effect: Participants may modify their behavior due to awareness of being observed, influencing study outcomes.
  • Confounding Bias: Unmeasured variables (e.g., socioeconomic factors) can affect both exposure and outcome, distorting the results.
  • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate

Berksonian bias is a selection bias that occurs in hospital-based studies, particularly case-control studies, not cohort studies. It arises because hospitalized patients are disproportionately represented among individuals with both exposure and outcome compared to the general population.

Berksonian bias is introduced when cases and controls are selected from hospitalized patients. The likelihood of being hospitalized depends on both the disease (outcome) and the exposure being studied. This leads to an artificial association between exposure and disease that does not exist in the general population.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text: An intern records a patient’s blood pressure as 135/85 mmHg, obtaining the same reading on repeated measurements. However, the resident doctor, using an appropriately sized blood pressure cuff and following the correct method, records a value of 155/95 mmHg. How would you classify the intern’s recorded data?
questions.solution:
The blood pressure recorded by the intern is consistent when repeated on the same individual under the same conditions, so it is highly reliable. However, it was not close to the actual value of the BP measured by the resident doctor, so it has low validity.

Validity refers to how close a measured value is to the "true" or actual value. In this case, the intern’s recorded blood pressure (135/85 mmHg) is far from the actual blood pressure value of 155/95 mmHg recorded by the resident. Therefore, the intern’s measurement has low validity.

Reliability refers to the consistency or reproducibility of a measurement when repeated under the same conditions. The intern consistently obtains the same reading (135/85 mmHg) on repeated measurements, even though the value is incorrect. This indicates high reliability.

Related Pearl: Repeatability of a Screening Test

Repeatability is an attribute of an ideal screening test. It is also called reliability, precision, or reproducibility. It implies that the test must give consistent results when repeated on the same individual or material, under the same conditions.

It depends upon three factors:

A. Observer variation

  • All observations are subjected to variations.
  • Intra-observer variations or within-observer variations are when a single observer takes two measurements in the same subject, at the same time and obtained two different results.
  • Inter-observer variations or between-observer variations are when two different observers obtain different results on the same subject or material.
  • They are minimized by standardization of procedures, intensive training of observers, and making use of more observers.

B. Biological variation

  • It is also called subject variation.
  • They are due to changes in the parameters observed, variations in the perceptions of symptoms by patients, and regression to the mean where there is a tendency of values to be at either extreme of the distribution.

C. Errors relating to technical methods is due to the following:

  • Defective instruments
  • Erroneous calibration
  • Faulty reagents
  • Incorrect methods

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: A person working in the smelting industry noticed the following changes in the nails. This finding can be seen in chronic poisoning with which of the following?
questions.solution:
The image shows transverse white lines of 1 to 2mm in breadth across the nail which is called Aldrich-Mees lines and is usually seen in chronic arsenic and thallium poisoning.

Chronic Arsenic Poisoning :

  • Source: Occurs in persons engaged in smelting or refining ore or long-term exposure to arsenic compounds

Manifestations of chronic arsenic poisoning: 

System involved Symptoms
Skin Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, raindrop hyperpigmentation 
Nails Aldrich Mees Line: Transverse white lines in the fingernails 
Neurologic Polyneuritis, anesthesias, paraesthesia,
encephalopathy. 
GI tract Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss
Liver Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis
Haematologic Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis
Cardiovascular Blackfoot disease due to platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries

Diagnosis: Urinary level of > 100 mg/ 24 hours suggestive of arsenic toxicity. Blood levels and hair levels are not reliable.

Laboratory tests to detect arsenic poisoning are:

  • Marsh’s test
  • Reinsch test
  • Atomic absorption spectroscopy

Management:

  • Hemodialysis is the treatment of choice for massive arsenic poisoning.
  • Chelation with BAL(British Anti Lewisite). Penicillamine or DMSA can be used instead of BAL.
  • Gastric lavage with warm water and milk

Other options:

  • Lead poisoning is characterized by a blue line on the gums called the Burtonian line. It can also be seen in mercury poisoning.
  • Mercury poisoning is characterized by mercurial tremors or Hatters shake.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

System

Acute

Chronic

Skin

Delayed hair loss (alopecia)

Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, hyperpigmentation.

Nails

Mees’s lines in 2-3 weeks post ingestion.

Mees' lines

Neurologic

Hyperpyrexia, convulsions, tremors, coma

Encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, tremors, axonal degeneration

GI tract

Abdominal pain, dysphagia, vomiting, bloody or rice water diarrhea, mucosal erosions.

Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss

Liver

Fatty infiltration

Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis

Kidney

Tubular and glomerular changes – oliguria and uremia

Nephritic finding

Haemetologic

thrombocytopenia, impaired folate metabolism

Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis.

Cardiovascular
  • S-T wave abnormalities,
  • prolonged QT interval
  • ventricular fibrillation
  • atypical ventricular tachycardia 

There is platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries leading to blackfoot disease

Reproductive system

Maternal ingestion of inorganic

Arsenic crosses the placental barrier and infant death shortly after birth.

-Nil-

questions.text: The insulin regimen of a diabetic patient is demonstrated in the image below. The X axis represents time of the day and the y axis represents the effect of insulin. The arrows indicate the time of administration of insulin. Identify the insulin preparations marked A, B and C respectively.
questions.solution:
In the given image, A represents glulisine, B represents regular insulin and C represents NPH.

In the insulin regimen elaborated above,

  • Insulin preparation A has duration of action between breakfast and lunch - 3-4 hours . This indicates it is a ultra short acting insulin preparation - aspart, glulisine or lispro.
  • Insulin preparation B has a duration of action slightly longer than preparation A indicating it is a short acting insulin preparation - regular insulin
  • Insulin preparation C is administered twice in a 24-hour period indicating it is an intermediate acting preparation - NPH or lente.

Glargine, detemir and degludec are long acting insulin preparations mostly having once daily administration.

Related Pearl: Insulin Classification According to Duration of Action

Inhaled insulin (2-3 hours)

  • Afrezza 

Rapid acting (3-4 hours)

  • Aspart
  • Glulisine
  • Lispro

Short acting (6-8 hours)

  • Regular

Intermediate acting (10-16 hours)

  • NPH
  • Lente

Long acting (12-24 hours)

  • Detemir
  • Glargine
  • Degludec (24-42 hours)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with jerky movements of her extremities for 1 week. She has typical hand movements, which are shown in the image below. She also complains of pain in multiple joints. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals jaundice. Which of the following is the gold standard for diagnosing this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient with jaundice along with the clip showing a wing beating tremor is suggestive of Wilson's disease with decompensation. The gold standard for diagnosis is liver biopsy.

Wilsons disease:

The autosomal-recessive disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase.

Clinical symptoms:

  • Hepatitis and cirrhosis
  • Behavioral disturbances
  • Wing-beating tremor 
  • Ophthalmic characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the posterior capsule of the lens, resulting in sunflower cataract
    • KF ring 

Kayser-Fleischer ring (KF) Ring:

  • KF ring is a golden-brown ring formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea
  • Characteristically observed in Wilson's disease, but not pathognomonic
  • Does not interfere with vision
  • Present in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric symptoms
  • Present only in 30–50% of patients diagnosed in the hepatic or presymptomatic state; therefore the absence of KF rings does not exclude the diagnosis of Wilson's disease

Diagnosis:

  • Presence of KF rings
  • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels
  • Measured hepatic copper levels in liver biopsy - Gold standard
  • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion

Treatment: Recommended anti copper Drugs for Wilson's Disease

Disease Status First Choice Second Choice
Initial    

Hepatitis or Cirrhosis without decompensation

 Zinc Trientine
Hepatic decompensation    
Mild Trientine and Zinc Penicillamine and Zinc
Moderate Trientine and Zinc Hepatic transplantation
Severe Hepatic Transplantation Trientine and Zinc
Initial neurological/Psychiatric Tetrathiomolybdate and Zinc Zinc
Maintenance Zinc Trientine
Presymptomatic Zinc Trientine

questions.text: A patient was presented to the OPD with pain and deformity of the fingers. On examination, he also had pitting of nails and well-demarcated, raised, erythematous plaques with a silvery-white scale. Which of the following is not seen in the patient?

choices.text: Joint involvement in the ray pattern
A negative test result for rheumatoid factor
Radiographic evidence of juxta-articular new bone formation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of psoriatic arthritis. Distal interphalangeal joints are involved in this condition.

Psoriatic arthritis is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy commonly involving proximal and distal interphalangeal joints (PIP, DIP) and metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP).

According to the CASPAR criteria, a patient must have inflammatory articular disease (joint, spine, or entheseal) with ≥3 points from any of the following five categories: 

1. Evidence of current psoriasis, a personal history of psoriasis, or a family history of psoriasis

2. Typical psoriatic nail dystrophy observed on current physical examination

 3. A negative test result for rheumatoid factor (Option B)

4. Either current dactylitis or a history of dactylitis recorded by a rheumatologist 

5. Radiographic evidence of juxta-articular new bone formation in the hand or foot (Option C).


Features of psoriatic arthritis are :

  • Asymmetrical oligoarthritis associated with nail pitting/ onycholysis, or dactylitis, enthesitis 
  • Inflammation is prominent in the distal interphalangeal joints
  • There is dactylitis with pronounced telescoping.
  • Nail dystrophy (hyperkeratosis and onycholysis) 
  • Axial involvement may occur

The image of psoriatic arthritis of the foot, plaque psoriasis and psoriatic nail dystrophy has been given below.

Radiological features:

  • Pencil-in-cup deformity of DIP joint
  • Marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation "whiskering"
  • Small joint ankylosis
  • Ray distribution of lesions (option A)

Related Pearl: Joint Involvement in Various Arthritis

 Joint Disorders Joints Commonly Involved

Joints Commonly Spared

 Osteoarthritis

Cervical and lumbosacral spine, PIP, DIP, 1st CMC, hip, knee, 1st MTP, 

 Elbow, Wrist, Ankle, MCP 
Rheumatoid Arthritis Shoulder, Wrist, MCP, PIP, Knee, MTP  DIP 
Ankylosing Spondylitis Sacroiliac joint, intervertebral joints  
Psoriatic Arthritis PIP, DIP Ray distribution* 

*Ray distribution: Joint involvement tends to follow a pattern with all of the joints of one finger involved sparing the adjacent finger completely.

questions.text: The given image shows a cross-section of the embryo. All of the following muscles develop from the marked structure, except:
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the paraxial mesoderm which forms all the tongue muscles except the palatoglossus. Palatoglossus is a derivative of the 4th pharyngeal arch.

Paraxial mesoderm forms the dural layer of meninges, Extraocular muscles (from 3 pre-optic myotomes), and Muscles of the Tongue (via occipital somites) except for Palatoglossus. These occipital somites are innervated by pre-cervical nerves and hence all the tongue muscles are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve except for the palatoglossus (supplied by the Vagus - nerve of the 4th pharyngeal arch).

During the third week of embryological development, the process of gastrulation occurs, which refers to the formation of the three germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. This is followed by the notochord formation, which is the axial structure, which induces the formation of the neural tube above it. During the neural tube formation, some cells at the lateral border dissociate and form the neural crest cells, sometimes referred to as the fourth germ layer. 

After the formation of the notochord, which is the axial structure, the mesoderm on either side can be seen to be organized into three layers as follows:

1. Para-axial mesoderm - A thickened plate of the mesoderm close to the midline, on either side of the notochord. This forms the somitomeres and somites, which have the following derivatives: 

    • Dermatome: Forms the segmental dermis of the skin
    • Myotome: Forms the skeletal muscle
    • Sclerotome: Forms the structures along the axial skeleton including the vertebral column and ribs.

         2. Intermediate mesoderm - Longitudinal strip of mesoderm that connects the para-axial with the lateral plate mesoderm. The urinary and genital systems are derived from the intermediate mesoderm.

3. Lateral plate mesoderm - A thinner layer of mesoderm that lies laterally. This layer develops a large cavity called the intraembryonic coelom that gives rise to pericardial, pleural, and peritoneal cavities.

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Mesoderm

 

Mesoderm derivatives
Paraxial mesoderm
  • Skeletal muscles of the trunk, limbs, head, and neck
  • Extraocular muscles
  • Intrinsic muscles of the tongue
  • Bones: Vertebrae, ribs
  • Dermis of Skin
  • Duramater
Intermediate mesoderm
  • Urinary system: Kidneys, ureters, trigone of the urinary bladder
  • Dorsal part of prostatic urethra (males)
  • Gonads: Testes and ovaries
  • Genital ducts
  • Adrenal cortex
Lateral plate mesoderm
  • Bones: Sternum, limb bones
  • Serous membranes of body cavities: Pleura, pericardium, peritoneum
  • GIT layers: Lamina propria, muscularis mucosae, submucosa, muscularis externa, adventitia
  • Blood cells: Microglia, Kupffer cells
  • Cardiovascular system
  • Lymphatic system
  • Laryngeal cartilages

questions.text: A 32-year-old lady with 30 weeks of pregnancy having an obstetric index of G2P1L1 presents to the emergency department with labor pain. A senior resident started the patient on the drug ritodrine to prevent preterm labor. This drug prevents labor by acting as _________
questions.solution:
Ritodrine is a selective beta-2 receptor agonist, which is used as a uterine relaxant to prevent preterm labour.

Specific tocolytic agents are:

  • Beta 2 agonists 
    • Ritodrine
    • Isoxsuprine
    • Terbutaline
  • Calcium channel blockers: Eg. Nifedipine
  • Magnesium sulfate
  • Atosiban (oxytocin receptor antagonist)
  • Indomethacin

Related Pearl: Tocolytic agents

Drugs Examples
Calcium channel blockers
Nifedipine
Nicardipine
Verapamil
Competitive inhibition to calcium ion
 Magnesium sulfate
Cyclo-oxygenase inhibitors
Indomethacin
Sulindac
Beta mimetics
Terbutaline
Ritodrine
Isoxsuprine
Oxytocin Antagonists
Atosiban
Nitric oxide (NO) Donors

questions.text:
A 19-year-old girl, who is an alleged victim of rape was brought to you for examination. On the evaluation of the stains present over her clothes following findings as shown below were noted. What is the likely specimen detected from the stain?
  • pH: 7.4
  • Florence test: Negative
  • Kastle Meyer test: Positive
questions.solution:
A positive Kastle Meyer's (phenolphthalein) test is suggestive of a bloodstain.

This test is done by adding phenolphthalein reagent and hydrogen peroxide to the extracted stain sample. Pink or purple colour indicates a positive test. 

Other options: 

Option A: The Florence test is used for the detection of choline secreted from the seminal vesicles. Since this test is negative, the sample cannot be semen.

Option C: Tests for urine samples include detecting the presence of urea, uric acid and creatinine.

Option D: Tests for saliva samples include the Phadebas test and radial diffusion by α-amylase activity on agar gel.

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text:
A female presents to the OPD with a breast lump 2*2cm in the left upper quadrant and palpable ipsilateral matted axillary lymph nodes. She has a family history of breast & ovarian cancer and was told that she carried a gene that put her at risk of the same. Which of the following will be the treatment of choice?

MRM: Modified radical mastectomy

choices.text: MRM with sentinel lymph node biopsy

questions.solution:
This woman carrying a genetic mutation predisposing her to breast cancer, possibly BRCA 1 or 2, with a left breast lump of 2*2cm and a palpable ipsilateral matted axillary lymph node - T1N2Mx, must be managed by Modified radical mastectomy with axillary node dissection.

Special scenario management of breast cancer: 

  • For BRCA-positive or strong family history cases, mastectomy is preferred over breast-conserving therapy (BCT) to reduce the risk of recurrence and address genetic predisposition.
  • Locally advanced breast cancers with no genetic predisposition or contraindications are managed by breast conservation therapy with neoadjuvant chemotherapy, lumpectomy, and sentinel lymph node surveillance.
  • Palpable axillary lymph nodes - Axillary dissection & clearance must be done. Sentinel lymph node biopsy is contraindicated.
  • No palpable axillary lymph nodes - Sentinel lymph node surveillance & biopsy is mandated

Breast conservation surgery involves removing the tumor with a margin of normal breast tissue, called lumpectomy/ wide local excision. The tumor is then histologically examined via an intraoperative frozen section to check for positive margins. 

Absolute contraindications of BCT:

  • 1st trimester of pregnancy (may be done for some 2nd and many 3rd trimester patients who can receive radiation after delivery)
  • Multicentric lumps
  • Diffuse microcalcification
  • Extensive ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)
  • Inflammatory breast cancer

Relative contraindications of BCT:

  • Active SLE (systemic lupus erythematosus), scleroderma  
  • Large lump-to-breast ratio (>5 cm size lump)
  • Persistently positive margin (2 microscopy shows positive margins)
  • Known or suspected genetic predisposition to breast cancer (i.e., BRCA1, BRCA2), Li-Fraumeni syndrome (p53 mutation)
  • Prior radiation therapy to the chest wall or breast

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications for radical mastectomy

Indications:

  • Large, bulky tumor involving pectoralis major muscle and fascia.
  • Axillary lymph node involvement
  • Interpectoral lymph node involvement

Contraindications:

  • Non-palpable or small tumors
  • Advanced disease with distant metastasis
  • Patients who need improved cosmetic result
  • Patients who need reconstructive surgery
  • Coexisting severe systemic diseases like DM, CHF, CRF

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Breast conservation surgery (BCS)/WLE (wide local excision): Tumour removal with a 3D clearance of a 1 mm margin of normal tissue
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Skin-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope preservation and nipple-areola complex removal
  • Skin+ nipple/areola-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope and nipple-areola complex preservation
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Level I oncoplasty (volume displacement surgery): Tumour excision with wide margins followed by defect repair via dual-plane mobilisation of the breast parenchyma to maintain shape and symmetry
  • Level II oncoplasty (volume replacement surgery): Skin excision and glandular mobilisation involving >20% resection of breast volume
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + internal mammary lymph nodes dissection
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iverson) mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary and supraclavicular lymph nodes dissection
  • Super radical mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes dissection.

*Dual-plane mobilisation of breast parenchyma: Mobilisation of the dermoglandular plane and plane between breast parenchyma and pectoralis muscle.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old primigravida delivers a healthy baby vaginally at 39 weeks of gestation. The placenta has not been delivered yet. Which of the following combinations represents the correct sequence and timing of interventions for the AMTSL?

AMTSL- Active management of the third stage of labor

choices.text: Administer uterotonic after delivery of anterior shoulder, delayed cord clamping, controlled cord traction
Administer uterotonic immediately after delivery, controlled cord traction,  delayed cord clamping
Administer uterotonic after delivery of anterior shoulder, immediate cord clamping, cord traction
Delayed cord clamping, controlled cord traction,  administer uterotonic after placental delivery

questions.solution:
For the active management of the third stage of labor, 10 IU of Oxytocin (Uterotonic) is given intramuscularly after the delivery of the anterior shoulder followed by delayed cord clamping and delivery of the placenta by controlled cord traction with intermittent assessment of uterine tone.

Oxytocin is the preferred uterotonic due to minimal side effects, it can be given to all patients. It binds to oxytocin receptors on myometrial cells, increases intracellular calcium, and leads to rhythmic contractions. Other uterotonics like ergometrine, misoprostol, or carboprost are second-line options.

Controlled cord traction should only be applied with a well-contracted uterus. This protocol significantly reduces the risk of Post-partum Hemorrhage (PPH) compared to expectant management. Continued uterine tone assessment every 15 minutes for 2 hours post-delivery is recommended.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought by his mother with complaints of poor growth, weakness, abnormal gait, and bowing of the legs. He was diagnosed with vitamin D deficiency rickets. Which of the following is increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
The level of serum alkaline phosphatase is increased in this child with vitamin D deficiency rickets.

Nutritional rickets occur due to a deficiency of vitamin D. This leads to low calcium levels in the blood. To raise the serum calcium, the secretion of the parathyroid hormone rises. The parathyroid hormone tries to raise the calcium levels by :

  • Reabsorbing calcium in the kidneys and secreting phosphate in exchange leads to low phosphate levels
  • Increasing bone resorption

Lab findings:

  • Serum calcium- decreased
  • Serum phosphorus- decreased
  • Creatinine- normal
  • Alkaline phosphatase- increased
  • Urinary excretion of calcium- decreased

Related Pearl: Important Clinical Features of Rickets

Related Pearl: Biochemical parameters in metabolic bone diseases
