      ↑     ↑        ↑    ↑
Osteoporosis      N    N       N   N

Paget's disease

      N    N       N   ↑

Osteopetrosis

   ↓/N ↑/N     ↓/N   N

 ↑: Increased,  ↓: Decreased, N: Normal

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text: Which of the following shows septate hyphae as depicted in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The microscopic image above shows septate hyphae with dichotomous branching at acute angles and a typical conidiophore is characteristic of Aspergillus. 

Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common pathogenic species. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients. This can be due to prolonged treatment with steroids or retro-positive status. It starts as pneumonia, which can later spread to involve other organs. Voriconazole is used for management.

Other manifestations include allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis where central bronchiectasis is usually seen. Aspergilloma and superficial infections like otomycosis or mycotic keratitis are the other presentations.

Histopathological examination of the tissue section shows characteristic dichotomous branching at an acute angle. The hyphae stain poorly with hematoxylin and eosin, so periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) stain is used. 

Other methods for diagnosis include the detection of galactomannan (Aspergillus cell-wall component) and culture isolation. Aspergillus fumigatus grows dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black. Yellow-green colonies are seen in the case of Aspergillus flavus. Microscopic examination of colonies stained with lactophenol cotton blue would show septate hyphae and conidiophores. 

Invasive aspergillosis is treated with intravenous amphotericin B.

Other options:

Option A: Candida, the causative agent for candidiasis, appears as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. Culture colonies are creamy-white and have a yeasty odor. Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species, form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

The image given below shows candidal hyphae and chlamydospores:

 

Option B: Cryptococcus is an opportunistic fungus that is found worldwide as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings. Microscopy on Gram staining shows gram-positive round budding yeast cells. India ink preparation reveals capsulated budding yeast cells; capsules are prominent in this staining.

The image given below shows Cryptococcus neoformans stained with India ink. Note the prominent capsule.

 

Options C: Rhizopus and Mucor are zygomycetes that are responsible for mucormycosis. Non-septate, broad hyphae are seen on tissue samples stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

The image given below shows broad aseptate and irregularly-branched non-septate hyphae of Mucor.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with a BMI of 41 kg/m2 underwent a surgical procedure to reduce her weight. After a few years, she has been experiencing chronic burning pain in her chest after her meals. Her doctor has told her that this is a complication of the procedure she underwent. Which of the following could she have undergone?
questions.solution:
The patient could have undergone a Sleeve gastrectomy.

The patient's symptoms of chronic burning chest pain after her meals are suggestive of gastroesophageal reflux disease. This is one of the long-term complications of sleeve gastrectomy. In the sleeve gastrectomy procedure, the pylorus is intact and the pressure in the stomach increases leading to increased chances of reflux. Patients can also develop Barrett's oesophagus as a long-term complication. There is also a risk of becoming obese again in sleeve gastrectomy.

It is the most commonly performed bariatric surgery. 

Short-term complications include a staple leak at an angle of His, intra-abdominal bleed, and DVT/PE. The staple leak at an angle of his can present up to 30 days after the surgery and can cause sepsis. Urgent CT scans with re-laparoscopy are indicated in such cases.

The below image shows Sleeve Gastrectomy:

Biliopancreatic diversion and Duodenal switch are indicated in cases where the patient desires maximum weight loss.

The below image shows Biliopancreatic diversion:

The below image shows the Duodenal Switch:

The below image shows the Roux en Y gastric bypass:

Other options: In A, B, and C, the pylorus is not intact, and hence, the risk of reflux is lesser than sleeve gastrectomy.

questions.text:
The severity of mitral stenosis depends on the time interval between OS and which of the following points in the cardiac cycle?

OS: opening snap
questions.solution:
The time interval between point 4 and the opening snap (OS) varies inversely with the severity of the MS. The point 4 on the graph represents the closure of the Aortic valve, which corresponds to A2. 

Auscultatory findings of MS include:

  • Accentuated and slightly delayed first heart sound (S1)
  • Close splitting of the second heart sound (S2)
  • Accentuated pulmonic component of S2 (P2) when pulmonary artery pressure is elevated
  • Opening snap (OS) of the mitral valve following the aortic component of S2 (A2):
    • Audible during expiration at or just medial to the cardiac apex
  • Mid-diastolic murmur following OS:
    • Low-pitched, rumbling
    • Heard best at the apex with the patient in the left lateral position
    • Accentuated by mild exercise
    • Duration of the murmur correlates with the severity of the stenosis
    • Reappears or becomes louder during atrial systole in patients with sinus rhythm (presystolic accentuation)
  • Soft systolic murmurs heard at or medial to the apex (signify mixed mitral valve disease with regurgitation)

The pressure-volume loop represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. This loop represents the relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle.

Related Pearl: Cardiac pressure - volume loop

The volume-pressure curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure(Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

Phase I: Period of filling (between A and B)

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction (between B and C)

Phase III: Period of ejection (between C and D)

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation (between D and A)

where,

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

questions.text: The physician explains the complications of diabetes and the need for compliance in simple terms to his illiterate patient. This is an example of which level of communication?
questions.solution:
This is an example of communication on an intellectual plane.

Communication on an intellectual plane involves giving empathetic, easy-to-understand explanations of their conditions and helping the patients develop insight into their ailments and their treatment plans. The doctor should take into account the fact that the patient's intellectual understanding may not be at the same level and, hence, put it in simple easy-to-understand terms.

For a successful doctor-patient relationship, a doctor must have in his/her regard communication on the following levels:

  • Communication on an emotional plane: Listening with empathy, building rapport, and ensuring openness and trust from the patient is part of this.
    • Example- Dr. X lending a sympathetic ear to the complaints made by the 84-year-old geriatric patient on his lingering backache is the emotional plane.
  • Communication on a cultural plane: To understand the community to which the patient belongs and his/her cultural and lifestyle factors that may influence health and disease and to advise in terms that the patient would understand. 
    • Example- Dr. A, the hypertension clinic physician, making his dietary advice in terms that fit the already existing lifestyle pattern in that area is an example of understanding the cultural plane.

There is no such plane as the scientific plane in communication.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, with her wedding in two months, requests a preventative medication to reduce her migraine frequency. Which of the following would be the most appropriate choice?
questions.solution:
This woman should be prescribed metoprolol for the prevention of migraines.

Beta-blockers such as metoprolol, propranolol, and timolol are first-line agents for preventing migraines.

It is suggested not to use beta blockers as initial therapy for migraine prevention in patients over age 60 and in smokers. Beta-blockers should be cautiously used in patients with

  • Erectile dysfunction
  • Peripheral vascular disease
  • Raynaud’s phenomenon 
  • Baseline bradycardia or low blood pressure. 

Other options: 

Option A: Verapamil (a calcium channel blocker) is commonly used for cluster headaches. It has not been proven effective for migraine prevention in adults.

Option B: Sumatriptan (a serotonin (5-HT1) agonist) is used for abortive treatment of acute migraines but is not recommended for prophylaxis.

Option D: Magnesium sulfate: It is sometimes used intravenously for acute migraine treatment, especially in pregnancy, but it is not proven effective for migraine prevention.

questions.text: During the forensic examination of the teeth of a dead individual, Gustafson's method is used for age estimation. Which of the following teeth is not suitable for this purpose?
questions.solution:
In Gustafson's method for age estimation, the molar teeth are not suitable for this purpose.

In Gustafson's method of estimating age, anterior teeth are more suitable than posterior teeth, and the merit decreases from incisors to premolars; molars, especially the third molar, are unsuitable. This method is based on physiological changes in dental tissues and is mainly useful in adults over 21 years of age.

Gustafson’s criteria:

  • Attrition - Gradual wear and tear changes of the occlusal or upper surface due to mastication.
  • Periodontosis -  Regression of gums and periodontal tissue surrounding the tooth, resulting in loosening of the tooth and falling.
  • Secondary dentin - Deposition of dentin in the pulp cavity and gradual decrease in the size of the cavity.
  • Cementum apposition- Due to changes in tooth position, Cementum increases in thickness near the end of the root. Secondary cementum deposition occurs continually and slowly, forming incremental lines.
  • Root resorption -  Involves both cementum and dentin, which show characteristic sharp grooves.
  • Transparency of the root - This is the most reliable criterion. Canals in dentin get filled with minerals, and they become transparent gradually. Dentine becomes transparent due to rarefaction.

questions.text:
Match the following findings of keratoconus with its method of detection.
1. Scissor reflex a. Slit-lamp examination
2. Munson's sign b. Physical examination
3. Oil droplet reflex c. Distant direct ophthalmoscopy
4. Vogt striae d. Retinoscopy
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1- d, 2 - b, 3 - c, and 4 - a.

1. Scissor reflex d. Retinoscopy
2. Munson's sign b. Physical examination
 3. Oil droplet reflex c. Distant direct ophthalmoscopy
4. Vogt striae a. Slit-lamp examination
  • Munson's sign is the localised bulging of the lower eyelid when the patient is looking downwards.
  • Using distant direct ophthalmoscopy a well-delineated 'oil droplet' reflex can be elicited. It is an annular black shadow that separates the central and peripheral areas of the cornea.
  • Fleischer's rings are epithelial iron deposits that are best seen with a cobalt blue filter during slit-lamp examination.
  • Vogt striae are vertical deep stromal lines seen using a slit-lamp.
  • The scissoring/yawning reflex can be elicited using a retinoscopy. It occurs when two bands of a light beam reflexed from the retina move like the blades of a pair of scissors.
  • Corneal topography and keratometry are also used for diagnosis.

Keratoconus means conical cornea. It is a progressive disorder and occurs due to central/paracentral thinning of the corneal stroma. This results in apical protrusion of the cornea and irregular astigmatism. The aetiology is not fully known and it may be seen associated with Down's, Ehlers-Danlos, and Marfan syndromes. Pathologically, the thinning and ectasia are due to abnormal production of mucopolysaccharide and collagen tissues.

Patients complain of defective vision due to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism despite full correction with glasses. Complications such as acute hydrops can occur, where there is a rupture of the Descemet membrane and sudden influx of aqueous into the cornea. Treatment includes spectacles, rigid contact lenses, and corneal collagen cross-linking (CXL). CXL is done by instilling riboflavin drops to photosensitise the eye, after which ultraviolet type A exposure is given. This is said to stabilise or even reverse ectasia. LASIK is contraindicated in patients with keratoconus.

Related Pearl: Clinical findings in keratoconus

External signs:

  • Munson’s sign- V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze 
  • Rizzuti’s sign- sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side

Slit-lamp signs:

  • Vogt’s striae- fine vertical stress lines in the deep stroma, parallel to the steep axis of the cone. May disappear with external pressure on the globe.
  • Fleischer ring- deposition of iron in the epithelium in a ring shape at the base of the conical protrusion.
  • Corneal thinning- predominantly in the inferotemporal area.
  • Hydrops- an acute rupture in Descemet’s membrane causing imbibition of aqueous into the corneal stroma. It is a complication of long-standing keratoconus.
  • Prominent corneal nerves- increased visibility of the corneal nerve fibres.
  • Rupture in Bowman’s layer- irregular superficial opacities that develop due to breaks in Bowman’s layer.

Retroillumination signs:

  • Scissoring reflex- during retinoscopy, two bands of the light beam reflexed from the retina, moves like the blades of the pair of scissors, towards and away from each other. This sign is diagnostic of keratoconus.
  • Oil droplet sign (“Charleaux” sign)- dark reflex in the area of the cone on observation of cornea in dilated pupil by distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

questions.text: An elderly man is brought by his daughter complaining that he forgets his way back home multiple times. She says that he is also not able to do his routine activities like taking a shower, making a sandwich, or using an oven which he was doing before. Suspecting Alzheimer's disease, what is the pathological finding that is likely to be seen?

choices.text: Loss of myelin in the base of the pons

questions.solution:
The pathological finding in Alzheimer's disease is the presence of neurofibrillary tangles.

The main microscopic abnormalities in Alzheimer's disease are neuritic plaques containing amyloid β, and neurofibrillary tangles containing hyperphosphorylated tau proteins. Neurofibrillary tangles are present in the cytoplasm of neurons, displacing or encircling the nuclei. On H&E staining, they are seen as basophilic fibrillary structures. They are better visible in immunohistochemistry and silver staining. The number of tangles correlates with the degree of dementia. 

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles.

Neuritic plaques are focal, spherical collections of dilated, tortuous, axonal, or dendritic processes (dystrophic neurites) often around a central amyloid core. It may be surrounded by a clear halo.

The image below shows a picture of amyloid neuritic plaques.

Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a common cause of dementia in the elderly. The presentation in AD follows a characteristic pattern, starting with defective memory and progressing to language and visuospatial deficits. This is followed by dysfunction in executing activities.

Grossly, the brain shows variable cortical degeneration that is most pronounced in the medial temporal lobe, inferolateral temporal cortex, and the nucleus of Meynert. Cortical atrophy is marked by gyral narrowing and sulcal widening.

Other options - 

Option B: Alpha-synuclein proteins are seen in multiple system atrophy which presents with features of parkinsonism, cerebellar ataxia, and autonomic failure. It is also seen in patients with Parkinson's disease.

Option C: Loss of myelin in the base of the pons and portions of the pontine tegmentum is seen in central pontine myelinolysis, which arises 2 to 6 days after rapid correction of hyponatremia.

Option D: Spongiform transformation of the cerebral cortex, caudate, and putamen is seen in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Extracellular deposits of aggregated abnormal PrP called Kuru plaques may occur in the cerebellum. It presents as rapidly progressive dementia. It is often associated with involuntary muscle jerks on sudden stimulation known as startle myoclonus.

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text:
Match the following patients with Uterine prolapse with their best treatment option.
                 Age/condition       Management

1. Nulliparous women with a desire for future pregnancy

i. Fothergill's operation 
2. 45-year-old with no desire for menstruation/pregnancy ii. Cervicopexy
3. 30-year-old in puerperal period iii. Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair
4. 38-year-old with family complete but desires for menstruation. iv. Ring pessary
questions.solution:
1-ii, 2-iii, 3-iv, 4-i (Option C) is correct. 

          Age/condition       Management

1) Nulliparous women with a desire for future pregnancy

ii.  Cervicopexy

2) 45-year-old with no desire for menstruation/pregnancy

iii.  Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

3) 30-year-old in puerperial period

 iv.  Ring pessary 

4) 38-year-old with family complete but desires for menstruation.

i.  Fothergill's operation

Sling operations are recommended in cases of nulliparous prolapse for those who wish to retain menstrual and child-bearing functions. Mackenrodt’s and uterosacral ligaments of the uterus are strengthened by using nylon or Dacron tapes as slings. Abdominal sling operations include abdominal wall cervicopexy, Shirodkar’s sling operation, Khanna’s abdominal sling operation, Virkud's sling operation, and Joshi's sling operation.

Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair is the ideal management of genital prolapse in women >40 years of age, those who have completed their families and do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function.

A ring pessary is used for patients who cannot be surgically managed, such as pregnant patients, patients in the puerperium, and very elderly women unfit for surgery. It is used in adjunct with pelvic floor physiotherapy. Pessaries provide mechanical support to the pelvic organs. The first step after fitting the pessary to check if the pessary is adequately retained is to ask the patient to perform Valsalva's manoeuvre or cough and see if the pessary is in place. After being placed, they need to be changed every 3 months. 

Fothergill's repair, also known as Manchester's operation, is suitable for women under 40 years who are desirous of retaining their menstrual and reproductive functions. It involves anterior colporrhaphy with amputation of the cervix. The Mackenrodt ligaments are sutured in the front of the cervix, and colpoperineorrhaphy is done. It increases the risk of cervical incompetence, leading to recurrent abortions and preterm deliveries. Shirodkar's modification of Fothergill's repair avoids cervical amputation, hence, subsequent pregnancy complications are avoided.  

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Category Treatment
Nulliparous or congenital prolapse 

Abdominal sling operations:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation
Pregnancy and postnatal period
  • Ring pessary (up to 16 weeks period of gestation)
  • Pelvic floor exercises
<40 years            
  • Fothergill's repair (Manchester operation)
  • Shirodkar's procedure
>40 years - with completed family  Vaginal hysterectomy and pelvic floor repair 
>60 years - unfit for surgery 
  • Le Fort's repair
  • Colpocleisis

These are done if the patient doesn't want to retain sexual function 

 

Related Pearl: Degrees of vault prolapse

  • First degree: The vaginal apex is visible at the introitus
  • Second degree: The vault protrudes through the introitus
  • Third degree: The entire vagina is outside the introitus

questions.text: Identify the pulse irregularity shown in the image.
questions.solution:
The irregularity of the pulse in the image indicates a bigeminal pulse.

A bigeminal pulse is an irregular pulse characterized by alternating strong and weak beats. It occurs due to premature contractions, typically ventricular (PVCs) or atrial (PACs), which lead to a compensatory pause after each premature beat. The premature beat occurs before the ventricles have fully filled, resulting in a diminished stroke volume and a weaker pulse. This leads to a palpable alternation between a strong (normal) beat and a weaker (premature) beat.

It is commonly associated with hypertension, coronary artery disease, smoking, or electrolyte imbalances (which trigger ectopic beats). Diagnosis is confirmed via ECG, showing PVCs alternating with normal sinus beats. Treatment is focused on addressing the underlying cause. ECG of ventricular bigeminy (a premature ventricular contraction follows every normal QRS complex) is shown in the image below:

Other options:

Option A: Pulsus bisferiens is characterized by a double-peaked systolic pulse, often seen in aortic regurgitation or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Option B: Pulsus alternans involve alternating strong and weak beats in a regular rhythm (normal sinus rhythm with alternating QRS amplitudes),  usually due to left ventricular dysfunction (seen in advanced heart failure). 

Option D: A Waterhammer pulse (Corrigan's pulse) is characterized by a rapid, forceful upstroke followed by a sudden collapse, which is commonly seen in aortic regurgitation. Its waveform shows a sharp rise in systole and a rapid fall in diastole.


The image given below shows a water-hammer pulse (Corrigan’s pulse):

The below image shows different arterial pressure waves:

questions.text: You are performing a cardiotocograph on a woman in labor, and your findings are shown below. What could be the possible cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
The given cardiotocograph shows decelerations that are variable with respect to the size, shape, depth, duration, and timing of uterine contractions. This is indicative of variable decelerations, and the likely cause among the given options is umbilical cord compression.

Baseline variability is observed in many conditions such as:

1. Acceleration: Transient increase in fetal heart rate (FHR) by 15 bpm or more, lasting for at least 15 seconds. It denotes intact neurohormonal and cardiovascular activity and, therefore, a healthy fetus.

2. Deceleration: Transient decrease in FHR below the baseline by 15 bpm or more and lasting ≥15 seconds. Three basic types of deceleration are early, late, and variable:

  • Early deceleration/ Type I Dips: Slowing of FHR and in most cases, the phases of the deceleration (onset, nadir, and recovery) coincide with those of the uterine contraction (beginning, peak, and ending). It is due to head compression (vagal nerve activation).

 

  • Late deceleration/ Type II Dips: that begins after the onset of the uterine contraction. Usually, the onset, nadir and recovery of the deceleration occur after the start, peak and end of the uterine contraction respectively. It suggests uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia (50%). Causes of late deceleration: (i) Placental pathology (postmaturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption); (ii) Excessive uterine contractions; (iii) Injudicious use of oxytocin; (iv) Regional anaesthesia (spinal or epidural)

 

  • Variable deceleration: The most common type of deceleration. Here the decelerations are variable, with varying parameters of size, shape, depth, duration, and timing with respect to uterine contractions. They indicate cord compression and may disappear when the patient's position is altered. Accelerations often precede and follow this type of deceleration.

 

3. Prolonged deceleration is the abrupt decrease in FHR to levels below the baseline, and it lasts for >3 min but <10 min. If it lasts for >10 min, it is a baseline change.

4. Lag period: It is the time taken for the FHR to reach the nadir (the lowest point of the FHR dip) from the apex of the preceding uterine contraction. In deceleration, the lag period is >30 seconds.

5. Sinusoidal pattern: It resembles a sine wave. It has a stable baseline FHR with fixed or absent baseline variability lasting >20 min. Accelerations are absent. It is often associated with fetal anaemia and fetomaternal haemorrhage. It may occur when narcotics are given to the mother. Such FHR patterns are called pseudo-sinusoidal as the fetus is well-oxygenated.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: Which among the following tests is an example of a prospective screening method?

choices.text: Pap smear for detection of cervical cancer

questions.solution:
Screening of blood donors is an example of prospective screening.

Prospective Screening is performed for the benefit of others or public health purposes rather than solely for the benefit of the individual being screened. It is used for disease control and transmission prevention.
Examples:

  • Screening of blood donors to prevent transmission of infections like HIV or hepatitis to recipients.
  • Screening immigrants for infectious diseases such as tuberculosis or yellow fever.
  • HIV screening during antenatal visits and for sex workers.

Prescriptive Screening is performed solely for the benefit of the individual being screened. It is used for early detection and treatment of disease in individuals.
Examples:

  • Pap smear for cervical cancer detection.
  • BRCA gene testing for assessing hereditary cancer risk.
  • HPV DNA testing for early detection of human papillomavirus infections.

questions.text: Acidification of urine is useful in the toxicity management of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Acidification of the urine is useful in the management of amphetamine toxicity.

The renal tubules are highly permeable to the nonionized forms of weak acids and bases undergo net passive reabsorption. However, they are less permeable to the ionized forms of weak acids and bases. Therefore, passive reabsorption of these substances depends on the pH of the urine.

 

Acidic urine

Alkaline urine

Weak acid

Non-ionized and reabsorbed

Ionized and excreted

Weak base

Ionized and excreted

Non-ionized and reabsorbed

Amphetamine is a weakly basic drug. When the urine is acidic, weakly basic drugs are highly ionized and excreted more rapidly.

Urinary alkalinization speeds up the clearance of barbiturates, sulphonamides, salicylates, chlorpropamide, methotrexate, and chlorophenoxy herbicides.

questions.text: During the development of the fetal heart, which of the following forms the smooth part of the atrium behind the crista terminalis?
questions.solution:
The crista terminalis is present in the right atrium and the smooth part behind it is formed by the right horn of sinus venosus.

The right atrium is primarily derived from the following three sources:

  • The right half of the primitive atrium gives rise to the rough trabeculated part in front of the crista terminalis. This is also known as the atrium proper.
  • The right horn of the sinus venosus gets absorbed into the primitive atrium to form the smooth part behind the crista terminalis. This is also known as sinus venarum.
  • The right half of the atrioventricular canal gets absorbed and gives rise to the smooth part present most ventrally.

Other options:

Option A: The primitive atrium gives rise to the rough parts of both the right and left atria.

Option B: The proximal parts of the primitive pulmonary vein forms the smooth part of the left atrium.

Option D: Left horn and body of the sinus venosus reduce in size to form the coronary sinus.

questions.text: A 2-week-old neonate is being evaluated for failure to thrive, excessive vomiting, abdominal distention, and steatorrhea.  Abdominal CT reveals hepatosplenomegaly and calcified adrenals bilaterally. Further investigation reveals a deficiency of the enzyme lysosomal acid lipase (LAL). Which of the following is the probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with failure to thrive, hepatosplenomegaly, intractable vomiting, steatorrhea, and bilateral adrenal calcification points towards a probable diagnosis of Wolman disease.

Wolman disease is a rare disorder that results from a deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase (LAL). This leads to the accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides in most of the visceral organs, leading to organomegaly as in this case. Patients present in the first few weeks of life with failure to thrive, vomiting, abdominal distention, steatorrhea, hepatosplenomegaly, and hyperlipidemia with extensive bilateral calcifications of the adrenal glands.

LAL deficiency can present in two forms- Wolman disease and cholesterol ester storage disease. Cholesterol ester storage disease is less severe and usually presents late in adulthood, whereas Wolman disease presents within the first few weeks of life and results in death within the first 6 months of life. 

Wolman disease can be diagnosed by measuring LAL activity in peripheral leukocytes or cultured skin fibroblasts. Treatment is with a recombinant form of LAL. Those treated have been seen to survive beyond one year of age.

Other options-

Option (A): Krabbe disease is also a fatal disease of early infancy but it occurs due to a deficiency in the enzyme galactocerebrosidase and hence, the accumulation of galactosylceramide in the white matter of the brain.

Option (B): Farber disease results from a deficiency of the lysosomal enzyme acid ceramidase. Thus, ceramide accumulates in various tissues, especially the joints. Symptoms include painful joint swelling and nodule formation, resembling rheumatoid arthritis within the first year of life.

Option (D): Gaucher disease is one of the most common lysosomal storage disorders. It occurs due to a deficiency of acid β-glucosidase. It presents most commonly with organomegaly, bone pain, and pathological fractures. It is most prevalent among Ashkenazi Jews.

Related Pearl: Enzyme Replacement Therapy for Lysosomal Storage Disorders

questions.text: Identify the below procedure and its indication.
questions.solution:
The image shows a Sugiura procedure involving:

  • Devascularisation of the esophagogastric junction
  • Splenectomy
  • Transection of the lower end of the esophagus

It permanently interrupts the intraoesophageal portacaval shunt while perioesophageal varices are preserved. The surgery is performed on the stomach wall, and all venous tributaries are divided except on the lesser and greater curves. The veins in the upper half of the stomach and 8–10 cm of the esophagus are cleared. After devascularisation with careful preservation of the vagus, the lower esophagus is transected just above the cardia using a large oesophageal stapler.

It is used in cases of recurrent or refractory esophageal variceal bleeding.

Other options: 

Option A: The Ivor Lewis procedure is a two-phase esophagectomy done for esophageal carcinoma.

Option B: Warren's procedure is a selective shunt surgery done for esophageal varices involving the creation of a distal splenorenal shunt.


Option D: The toupet procedure is a partial posterior fundoplication for GERD.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause permanent impairment of fingerprint pattern?
questions.solution:
Among the given conditions, electrical injury is most likely to cause permanent impairment of fingerprint patterns.

Some changes in fingerprints include:

  • Moderate epidermal ridge atrophy and loss of pattern in celiac disease
  • Incomplete atrophy of the ridges in dermatitis
  • Ridge alteration occurs in eczema, acanthosis nigricans, scleroderma, and dry or atrophic skin
  • Permanent impairment of the fingerprint pattern occurs in leprosy, electric injury, and after exposure to radiation
  • Distance between the ridges is changed, but the pattern is not altered in infantile paralysis, rickets, and acromegaly

Other options:

First-degree burns (option A) cannot cause permanent damage to the fingerprints. Fingerprints are better protected than other parts of the body in case of burns as they are bent inwards against the palm of the hand.

In decomposed bodies (option C), the skin is found loose like a glove, which is removed, preserved in formalin, and used for impressions. Prints can be obtained from the dermis after the epidermis is lost.

If the fingers are mummified (option D), their outline can be made level by injecting liquid paraffin or formalin.

questions.text: Which of the following acts as an RNA-directed nuclease?
questions.solution:
CRISPR-Cas9 acts as an RNA-directed nuclease.

Clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats-associated gene 9, or CRISPR-Cas9, is a DNA editing/gene regulatory system. It involves two essential components: Cas9, an endonuclease that causes a double-stranded DNA break, allowing modifications to the genomic DNA to be made; and a synthetic single-guide RNA, or sgRNA, responsible for guiding Cas9 to its target.

Once the sgRNA has directed the Cas9 to the section of the genomic DNA to be edited, the 3’ end of the sgRNA comes to lie across a specific sequence of DNA adjacent to the editing side called the protospacer adjacent motif or PAM. The Cas9 now causes a double-stranded break in the DNA at the PAM site, which is then repaired by a non-homologous end-joining.

The following image shows CRISPR-Cas9 system:

Some important enzymes used in recombinant DNA research

Enzyme 

Reaction 

Primary Use 

Phosphatase

Dephosphorylates 5′ ends of RNA and DNA
  • Removal of 5′-PO4 (phosphate) groups prior to kinase labeling
  • Prevent self-ligation

Catalyzes bonds between DNA molecules 
  • Joining of DNA molecules 

DNA polymerase I 

Synthesizes double-stranded DNA from single-stranded DNA 
  • Synthesis of double-stranded cDNA
  • DNA labeling and nick translation
  • Generation of blunt ends from sticky ends

  • Polymerase chain reaction (DNA synthesis)
  • Mutagenesis

  • Nick translation

  • DNA sequencing
  • ChIP-Exo

questions.text:
Which of the following represents the changes in iron profile during pregnancy?

TIBC: Total Iron Binding Capacity

  Serum Iron  Serum ferritin Serum Transferrin TIBC
1 Increased Increased Decreased Decreased
2 Decreased Decreased Increased Increased
3 Increased Decreased Decreased No change
4 Decreased Decreased Decreased No change
questions.solution:
The changes in iron profile during pregnancy are:

  • Serum iron levels decrease
  • Total Iron-binding capacity (TIBC) increases.
  • Serum transferrin, which is the protein responsible for binding and transporting iron, increases in response to the growing need for iron. 
  • Serum ferritin decreases. It is the most reliable indicator of iron deficiency in the absence of inflammation and chronic disease. Serum ferritin is the main storage protein for iron. It is found in all cells but is highest in the hepatocytes.
  • Hemoglobin concentration and hematocrit levels decline further in the second half of pregnancy.

Iron demand during pregnancy significantly increases, particularly in the second half. Even with a well-balanced diet, the additional iron requirements cannot be fully met, resulting in a physiological iron deficiency state. 

During pregnancy, maternal plasma volume increases by approximately 40–50%, while red blood cell (RBC) volume increases by about 20%. This leads to a relative decrease in haemoglobin levels and hematocrit. These values typically return to normal within 6 weeks postpartum.

This combined effect of hemodilution and iron deficient state will result in normocytic normochromic anaemia seen in normal pregnancy. The following are the criteria for the lower limit of physiological anaemia during the second half of pregnancy:

  • Hb: 10g%
  • RBC count: 3.2million/mm3
  • PCV: 32%
  • On peripheral smear- normal morphology RBCs with central pallor

Please note: Transferrin is a protein synthesised in the liver. The major function of plasma transferrin is to deliver iron to cells, including erythroid precursors, which require iron to synthesise haemoglobin. Transferrin saturation is a measure of the amount of iron bound to transferrin. Low serum iron with increased iron-binding capacity results in a reduction of transferrin saturation.

questions.text: A technician working in the MRI department, while giving contrast, developed a prick injury from an HIV-positive patient. He is extremely anxious and wants to get a test done to check for early identification of transmission. Which of the following tests may be helpful in this regard?
questions.solution:
The 4th generation enzyme immunoassay of p24 antigen is useful for this patient to detect early transmission of disease. 

The window period is the time between HIV exposure and detectable levels of antibodies in the blood. During this period, an individual may be highly infectious but test negative on standard antibody tests. The window period may last between 2–8 weeks to a few months. During this period, the individual may be highly infectious. HIV infection can be detected during this period by RNA PCR and p24 antigen assay.

  • HIV RNA detection (RT-PCR): This test directly detects HIV RNA (viral genetic material) as early as 10–12 days after exposure, making it the most sensitive and specific test for diagnosing HIV in the window period. It is the gold standard confirmatory method.
  • p24 Antigen Test (4th Generation ELISA): The p24 antigen becomes detectable after 12–26 days of infection and lasts for 3–4 weeks thereafter.

Other options: 

Option A: 3rd Generation ELISA: This method detects HIV antibodies, which take 2–8 weeks to develop. However, it is not useful for early detection because antibodies appear later in the window period.

Option B: The Western blot test detects individual antibodies against different fragments of HIV. It is used as a confirmatory test after a positive ELISA but not for early diagnosis.

Option C: The rapid HIV Test detects antibodies but is unreliable in the early stages, as antibodies take weeks to develop.

questions.text: The following process where transportation is along the concentration gradient is an example of:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a glucose transporter that transports glucose from a higher concentration to a lower concentration. This is an example of facilitated diffusion. 

When carrier proteins help in the movement of substances in the direction of their chemical or electrical gradients (downhill movement), no energy input is required and the process is called facilitated diffusion.

Glucose transporters also referred to as GLUTs, are transport proteins in the cell membrane responsible for the transfer of glucose into the cells by facilitated diffusion. Facilitated diffusion involves the passage of molecules or ions inside the cell membrane by binding to a carrier/ transport protein. 

For example, insulin stimulates glucose entry into the cells via facilitated diffusion by increasing the number of glucose transporters (GLUTs) in the cell membrane. This type of insulin-dependent glucose transport via GLUT 4 is observed in skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, and adipose tissues. 

Other options - 

Option A. Simple diffusion - It is along the concentration gradient but is not carrier-mediated. In the cell, examples of molecules that can use simple diffusion to travel in and out of the cell membrane are water, oxygen, carbon dioxide, and nitrogen. They pass directly through the cell membrane without energy along the concentration gradient.

Option C. Primary active transport - It is a form of cellular transport requiring energy in the form of hydrolysis of ATP to ship and transfer molecules against a membrane with chemical or electrical gradient differences. The important examples of primary active transport include sodium-potassium ATPase, proton pump, and calcium ATPase.

Option D. In secondary active transport, the active transport of sodium is coupled to the transport of other substances. Examples include the symport of sodium with glucose (luminal membranes of mucosal cells in the small intestine), and Ca2+ in the cardiac muscle cells.

Related Pearl: Characteristics of different types of transport

Type Simple diffusion Facilitated diffusion Primary active transport Secondary active transport Cotransport Secondary active transport Countertransport
Electrochemical gradient Downhill Downhill Uphill Uphill Uphill
Carrier mediated No Yes Yes Yes Yes
Metabolic energy No No Yes Indirect Indirect
Na+ gradient No No -- Yes (same direction) Yes (opposite direction)

Inhibits Na+-K+ pump

 		 -- -- Inhibits Inhibits  Inhibits

questions.text: A 9-month-old child was brought for routine follow-up in a rural subcentre. Upon assessing the child's mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC), it measures 12 cm. What Anatomical structure is used as a reference in scapula to measure MUAC?
questions.solution:
The part of the scapula marked as 2 is the acromian process. It is used as a reference in scapula to measure MUAC.

Shakir's tape is used to measure mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC). It is used by frontline field workers for nutritional screening of malnourished children and those at risk, aged 6-59 months. To locate the midpoint of the left arm, the arm is flexed at the right angle, and the mid-point is marked halfway between the acromion and olecranon process. Color coding is as follows:

  • Red is less than 11.5 cm, which indicates severe acute malnutrition
  • Yellow is from 11.5 to 12.5 cm, which indicates moderate acute malnutrition
  • Green is from 12.5 to 16.5 cm, indicating no acute malnutrition 

The presence of any one of the following confers severe acute malnutrition in children 6 to 59 months of age:

  • Weight-for-height (length) below -3 standard deviation (<-3SD) on the WHO growth standard
  • Presence of bipedal edema
  • Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) below 11.5 cm

Note: In a child below 6 months of age, the MUAC is not used as a criterion. 

Other markings of the scapula given in the image

  • 1 (option A) is the coracoid process.
  • 3 (option C) is the infra glenoid tubercle.
  • 4 (option D) is the inferior angle of the scapula.

The below image shows Shakir's tape.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl diagnosed with adenoid hypertrophy developed pain in the ears and reports decreased hearing and popping sensations in both ears. Otoscopy revealed air-fluid level and bubbles. What type of curve is obtained on tympanometry?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of the child suggests serous otitis media, also known as otitis media with effusion or glue ear. Type B tympanometry curve is obtained in serous otitis media.

Serous otitis media is the collection of nonpurulent effusion in the middle ear cleft due to malfunctioning of the eustachian tube or increased secretory activity of the middle ear mucosa. It presents as conductive hearing loss, leading to delayed and defective speech in children.

Otoscopy reveals a fluid level, bubbles, and varying degrees of retraction, as shown below:

Type B tympanometry curve is obtained in serous otitis media. The fluid accumulation causes decreased mobility of the tympanic membrane leading to a flat or dome-shaped curve, as shown below:

 

Management includes the use of decongestants, antiallergic measures initially, and myringotomy and aspiration of fluid if unresolved. Adenoidectomy and tonsillectomy may be required to treat the cause of serous otitis media.

Other options: 

Option A: Type A curve is a normal tympanogram.

Option C: Type As curve is seen in fixation of ossicles such as otosclerosis.

Option D: Type C curve is seen in negative middle ear pressure and retracted tympanic membrane.

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: Which of the following contraceptives would be least suitable for a patient who has had intercourse 48 hours prior but wants to avoid pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Centchroman would be least suitable for a patient who has had intercourse 48 hours prior but wants to avoid pregnancy. It has to be taken within 24 hours of intercourse.

Centchroman is administered as two tablets of 60 mg taken twice over 24 hours and within 24 hours of intercourse. It acts by preventing the implantation of the blastocyst in the endometrium. It is the only contraceptive that neither suppresses ovulation nor interferes with the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis.

The various emergency contraceptive methods, along with their mechanism of action, have been described below:

  • An intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) prevents the implantation of a fertilized ovum. It does so by acting as a foreign body within the uterine cavity. This leads to increased contractility, and tubal peristalsis, and promotes leukocytic infiltration in the endometrium so that the fertilized egg is unable to implant. 
  • An IUCD such as Copper T (Option C) can be used for emergency contraception if inserted within 5 days of coitus. The administration of postcoital contraceptive agents that interfere with postovulatory events that can lead to pregnancy is known as the emergency contraception method. They are used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse.
  • Ulipristal (Option A) is given as a 30 mg tablet and should be taken within 5 days. It is a synthetic progesterone hormone receptor modulator. The drug attaches to the progesterone receptor, delays ovulation and suppresses endometrium, thereby preventing implantation.
  • Levonorgestrel (LNG) (Option D) is administered as a single 1.5 mg tablet within 72 hours of coitus. It can also be administered as two tablets of 0.75 mg strength, taken 12 hours apart. LNG prevents ovulation and causes desynchronization of the endometrium through its receptors (luteal phase deficiency).
  • Ethinyl estradiol is administered as two oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) containing 50 mcg each within 72 hours of coitus, followed by the 2 tablets after 12 hours. Alternatively, four OCPs of 30 or 35 mcg of ethinyl estradiol, followed by 4 tablets after 12 hours, can be used. The hormone may delay ovulation if taken soon after intercourse, bringing about cervical mucus changes and endometrial atrophy.
  • Mifepristone is administered as a single 200 mg tablet within 72 hours. It is a steroid with an affinity for progesterone receptors. It prevents fertilization by blocking the action of progesterone on the endometrium. This leads to sloughing and shedding of decidua, thus preventing implantation.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

Related Pearl: Classification Of Contraceptives Based On Effectiveness

questions.text:
Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for drug resistance to Macrolides?
  1. Drug efflux by an active pump mechanism
  2. Ribosomal protection by inducible or constitutive production of methylase enzymes, which modify the ribosomal target and decrease drug binding
  3. Macrolide hydrolysis by esterases 
  4. Chromosomal mutations that alter a 50S ribosomal protein
questions.solution:
Statements 1,2,3,4 (Option D), all are the mechanisms of drug resistance against Macrolides.

Macrolides are a group of antibiotics that inhibit protein synthesis by acting on the 50s subunit of ribosome & block the translocation of t-RNA. They are bacteriostatic agents. Examples of Macrolides are erythromycin, Azithromycin, Clarithromycin, and Telithromycin. 

Mechanisms of drug resistance to Macrolides:

  • Drug efflux by an active pump mechanism (Statement 1).
  • 50S Ribosomal unit is Methylated by inducible or constitutive production of methylase enzymes, which decreases drug binding - MLSB resistance (Statement 2).
  • Macrolide hydrolysis by esterases produced by Enterobacterales (Statement 3).
  • Chromosomal mutations that alter a 50S ribosomal protein (Statement 4) in Bacillus subtilis, Campylobacter spp., mycobacteria, and gram-positive cocci.

The MLSB resistance (Macrolide-lincosamide-streptogramin B) is conferred by the ERM gene (erythromycin ribosome methylase).

questions.text: Which of the following appearance of Bacillus anthracis is incorrectly paired with the modality in which it is seen?

choices.text: Bamboo stick appearance on gram staining from cultures
String of pearls reaction in Elek's gel
Medusa head appearance of colony in nutrient agar
Inverted fir tree appearance in gelatin stab culture

questions.solution:
A string of pearls reaction of Bacillus anthracis is seen in a solid medium containing penicillin- 0.05-0.50 units/ml.

B.anthracis grown in this medium for 3-6 hours become large and spherical, and occur in chains on the surface of the agar, resembling a string of pearls. String of pearls reaction on solid media containing penicillin.


Appearances of Bacillus anthracis:

  • Boxcar appearance/bamboo stick appearance on gram stain from culture
  • Medusa head appearance of the colony in nutrient agar
  • M’Fadyean’s reaction – It shows a capsule when stained with polychrome methylene blue.
  • Inverted fir tree appearance on gelatin slab
  • Frosted glass appearance on the agar plate

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is found to have colonic cancer on routine colonoscopy and biopsy. His father had developed a similar colonic cancer and died at the age of 40. His family history is remarkable for endometrial and urothelial cancer. There is no history of familial adenomatous polyposis. Abnormality in which of the following DNA repair mechanisms is responsible for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Regulated genomic instability in lymphoid cells

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of a diagnosis of Lynch syndrome/Hereditary non-polyposis colonic cancer (HNPCC). HNPCC results from a defect in the DNA mismatch repair system.

HNPCC is an autosomal dominant disorder that leads to the development of carcinoma in the cecum and proximal colon. One defective copy of the gene is inherited while the other gene undergoes a loss of function mutation.  

DNA mismatch repair proteins function as spell checkers during DNA replication by correcting the incorrect pairing. In HNPCC, the proofreading function is lost leading to the accumulation of errors throughout the genome and microsatellite instability. A microsatellite is a sequence of 1-6 nucleotides found repeated throughout the genome. They are found in normal individuals at a constant length. In patients with DNA mismatch repair, these lengths are variable leading to mutated alleles. 

Other options: 

Option A: Patients with regulated genomic instability in lymphoid cells develop T and B cell neoplasia. 

Option C: Patients with a defect in the nucleotide excision repair pathway develop xeroderma pigmentosum.

Option D: Patients with defects in the homologous recombination DNA repair system may develop Bloom syndrome, ataxia-telangiectasia, and Fanconi anemia.

Related Pearl: Amsterdam Criteria II - Revised Criteria for HNPCC

The diagnostic criteria for HNPCC are referred to as the Amsterdam criteria or the 3-2-1-0 rule.

It includes the following:

  • Three or more relatives with HNPCC-associated cancer (colorectal cancer, endometrial cancer, cancer of the small bowel, ureter, or renal pelvis), one of whom is a first-degree relative of the other two
  • At least two successive generations affected
  • At least one case diagnosed before the age of 50 years
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis excluded.
  • Tumors verified by pathologic examination.

All of the above must be applicable for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC to be made in a family.

questions.text:
Assertion: Bronze Baby syndrome is a complication of phototherapy in infants with porphyria.
Reasoning: Bronze baby syndrome is characterized by photo-induced modification of porphyrins.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is a correct explanation of Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason is not a correct explanation of Assertion.
Assertion is true, and Reason is false.
Assertion is false, and Reason is true

questions.solution:
Bronze baby syndrome is a complication associated with phototherapy, which is used to manage neonatal jaundice in infants. However, Phototherapy is contraindicated in porphyrias, so the assertion is false. Skin discoloration in bronze babies is due to the oxidation of porphyrins under the influence of light, i.e., photo-induced modification of porphyrins, so the reason is true. 

Bronze baby syndrome is a complication associated with phototherapy that causes dark, greyish-brown skin discoloration in infants. Skin discoloration is due to the oxidation of porphyrins under the influence of light (photo-induced modification of porphyrins). As porphyrins are altered, they produce a characteristic bronze or brownish color in the skin. When exposed to light (like phototherapy), the accumulation of porphyrins or their precursors can trigger or exacerbate symptoms of porphyria, including skin damage, blistering, and painful skin reactions.

Other complications associated with phototherapy include: 

  • Loose stools
  • Erythematous macular rash
  • Purpuric rash associated with transient porphyrinemia 
  • Dehydration (increased insensible water loss, diarrhea)
  • Hypothermia from exposure

questions.text: In a 60-year-old chronic smoker with lung carcinoma, the radiological investigations reveal a centrally located tumor with the histopathology showing a characteristic Azzopardi effect as shown in the image below. Which of the following marker you would expect to be positive in the immunohistochemistry of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histological image showing a characteristic azzopardi effect is suggestive of a small cell carcinoma of the lung. Chromogranin is a marker of small cell lung carcinoma.

Azzopardi effect is described as basophilic staining of vascular walls due to encrustation by DNA from necrotic tumor cells.

Histology of small cell lung carcinoma shows clusters of small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli. The cells are round, oval, or spindle-shaped, and nuclear molding is prominent.

Markers seen in small cell lung carcinoma includes,

  • Chromogranin,
  • Synaptophysin,
  • CD56

Note: Insulinoma-associated protein 1 (INMS 1) is a nuclear protein that serves as a transcription factor and has gained prominence as a neuroendocrine marker. Originally identified in insulinomas, INSM1 has been to be a reliable marker for various neuroendocrine tumors (NETs).

Related Pearl: Types of lung cancer

Features Adeno-carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma Small cell carcinoma
Association with smoking Present, but most common type of lung cancer in non smokers Strong Strongest association
Common genetic alterations EGFR and TP53 TP53,  CDKN2A RB, TP53, MYC
Location Peripheral Central/hilar Anywhere
Precursor lesions Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia, Adeno-carcinoma in situ Squamous dysplasia, Carcinoma in situ None
Histology

Glandular differentiation, mucin production, Lepidic growth pattern

 Keratinization, squamous pearls, intercellular bridges Small cells, scant cytoplasm, salt and pepper chromatin, Azzopardi effect
IHC Mucin, TTF-1, Napsin-A p40, p63

Chromogranin, Synaptophysin, and CD56

questions.text: During the psychiatry ward rounds, the consultant came across a patient with complaints of insomnia, agitation, and restlessness, with a history of multiple similar episodes in the past. When the doctor asked the patient what is your name? The patient replied-"I forgot my name, as when I was sleeping, my wife stole my memories." Which category of thought disorder does this fall under?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests the patient is suffering from mania with thought withdrawal, which is a disorder of Possession of thought.

Thought withdrawal: The delusion that someone or something is removed from one's mind, and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories, and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep."

Thought insertion: Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind, and they recognise them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus.

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbours, and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night."

Thought broadcasting: The belief is that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet, and I think I can broadcast them globally."  

Thought echo: The patient hears the 'echo' of his thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning, and surprisingly, a voice from nowhere told me to make a sandwich out loud." 

Related Pearl: Classification of disorders of thought

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer and multiple skeletal metastases presents to the emergency department with confusion, lethargy, and nausea. Her ECG is given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
In a breast cancer patient with skeletal metastases, the given clinical presentation and ECG showing marked shortening of QT interval is suggestive of hypercalcemia. The initial treatment of severe, symptomatic hypercalcemia is volume expansion with 4-6 L of intravenous fluids.

Management of hypercalcemia depends on the severity and underlying cause. Mild, asymptomatic cases typically don't require immediate treatment, while significant, symptomatic hypercalcemia needs intervention.

Initial treatment involves volume expansion with 4-6 L of IV saline over 24 hours. Loop diuretics (Option C) may be used after normalizing volume, especially in patients with heart failure. However, loop diuretics should not be initiated until dehydration is corrected.

For hypercalcemia due to bone resorption (malignancy or severe hyperparathyroidism), bisphosphonates such as zoledronic acid (Option A) or pamidronate are the primary therapy. Denosumab is an alternative for bisphosphonate-resistant cases. Gallium nitrate is another option, but it has nephrotoxicity risks. Dialysis may be necessary in severe cases. Although intravenous phosphate can reduce serum calcium levels, it carries the risk of organ damage due to the deposition of calcium-phosphate complexes.

For 1,25(OH)2 D-mediated hypercalcemia (such as granulomatous diseases (e.g., sarcoidosis) or lymphomas), glucocorticoids (Option D) are the treatment of choice, reducing 1,25(OH)2 D production. Other agents like ketoconazole may also be used occasionally.

questions.text: A patient comes to your clinic with a complaint of multiple episodes of loose watery stool for 3 days.  Which of the following is the most common viral cause of diarrhea in adults?
questions.solution:
The most common viral cause of diarrhea in adults is Norovirus.

Norovirus is the most common agent to cause viral gastroenteritis among older children and adults. Noroviruses previously called Norwalk-like viruses belong to the family Caliciviridae.

Gastroenteritis caused by Norovirus has a sudden onset and generally lasts 1-3 days. It is characterized by nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, diarrhoea and constitutional symptoms like headache, fever, chills, and myalgias. Vomiting is more prevalent among children, whereas a greater proportion of adults develop diarrhoea. The stools are characteristically loose and watery, without blood, mucus, or leukocytes.

Other options:

Option A- Enteric adenoviruses cause diarrheal episodes in young children which consists of ~2–12% of all diarrheal episodes in children.

Option B- Rotavirus is the most common viral agent among young children. Nearly all children are infected with rotavirus by 3–5 years of age. Infants and young children who develop severe dehydration are more likely to have an infection from rotavirus than other viruses.

Option D- Cytomegalovirus causes mononucleosis in healthy individuals and disseminated diseases like leukopenia, hepatitis, colitis, pneumonitis, esophagitis, gastritis, and retinitis in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient with major depressive disorder on fluoxetine complains of sexual dysfunction. She is a smoker and her medical history includes bulimia nervosa and diabetes mellitus. Her physician plans to stop fluoxetine and switch to bupropion, due to its low incidence of sexual side effects. However, which of the following could be a reason to avoid bupropion in this patient?
questions.solution:
Bupropion is associated with an increased risk of seizures in patients with bulimia nervosa or anorexia nervosa. For this reason, bupropion is contraindicated in these patients.

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as fluoxetine are the first-line management of the major depressive disorder. The most common adverse effect of SSRIs is sexual dysfunction. Among the second-line drugs, bupropion has a low incidence of sexual side effects. But, bupropion increases the risk of seizures in patients with bulimia nervosa.

Buproprion is an atypical antidepressant that inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine. It is also used for the treatment of attention deficit hyperkinetic disorder, obesity, smoking dependence, and peripheral neuropathy.

Buproprion is the most anxiogenic antidepressant. Adverse effects of bupropion include stimulant side effects like tachycardia, insomnia, headache, and seizures in anorexic/bulimic patients. It decreases the risk of sexual dysfunction and weight gain compared to other antidepressants.

Atypical anti-depressants such as mirtazapine and bupropion do not cause sexual dysfunction.

Other options:

Option A: A history of smoking would further prompt the use of bupropion in this patient because it aids in smoking cessation.

Options C and D: Diabetes mellitus and age are not contraindications for the use of bupropion.
