questions.text: Which enzyme is involved in cataract formation in a patient with diabetes?
questions.solution:
Aldose reductase is the enzyme involved in cataract formation in a diabetic patient.

The polyol pathway has been implicated in the formation of diabetic cataracts. This pathway results in the production of fructose from glucose and, sorbitol is formed as an intermediate. Glucose is reduced to sorbitol by aldose reductase. Sorbitol does not diffuse through cell membranes, but accumulates, causing osmotic damage. 

Diabetics have increased glucose levels in the lens, peripheral nerves, and renal glomeruli which are not insulin sensitive. This increases the activity of aldose reductase in these tissues. The sorbitol so formed accumulates in the lens leading to cataract formation in diabetic patients.

Options B and C are enzymes of galactose metabolism. Classical galactosemia is caused by deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT).  Without GALT, the infant cannot metabolize galactose 1-phosphate, which accumulates and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain. Galactokinase is the enzyme responsible for the conversion of galactose to galactose 1-phosphate. Only cataract is seen in the deficiency of this enzyme because galactose-1-phosphate is not formed. Hence no toxic effects of this compound are manifested. 

Option D:  Aldolase B is the enzyme that cleaves fructose-1-phosphate in fructose metabolism. A deficiency of this causes hereditary fructose intolerance.

questions.text:
A patient with chronic tophaceous gout was prescribed probenecid. Which of the following statements is/are true regarding the drug?
  1. It inhibits the reabsorption of uric acid in the renal tubules.
  2. It can precipitate uric acid calculi.
  3. It promotes the urinary excretion of penicillin and methotrexate.
  4. Aspirin blocks the uricosuric action of probenecid.
questions.solution:
The true statements about probenecid are 1,2, and 4.

Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that promotes the excretion of uric acid. It is used to decrease the body pool of urate in patients with chronic gout. The drug acts by inhibiting the organic anion transporter, particularly URAT-1 in the renal tubules that are involved in uric acid reabsorption. It is used as an adjuvant to allopurinol in chronic gout and hyperuricemia.

Probenecid increases urinary urate levels. Plenty of fluids are given to avoid urate calculi formation. Probenecid should not be used in gouty patients with nephrolithiasis or with overproduction of uric acid.

Probenecid inhibits the urinary excretion of penicillin hence prolonging penicillin action by enhancing and sustaining their blood levels. It inhibits the urinary excretion of other drugs such as cephalosporins, sulfonamides, methotrexate, and indomethacin. Aspirin blocks the uricosuric action of the drug.

questions.text: A mother presents with itching that worsens at night. On examination, you notice lesions as shown in the image below. Her 15-day-old baby has some vesicles on various parts of his body. Considering your diagnosis based on these observations, which is the site where the lesions will be found in the baby but not in the mother?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of itching in the mother that worsens at night, with similar symptoms seen in her baby, and physical examination revealing burrows is suggestive of scabies. In scabies, the site that is involved in neonates but not in adults is the face.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic skin infection that is transmitted through the means of close personal contact/fomites. It is caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis or human itch mite. It leads to severe pruritus, excoriating papules, and burrows. The typical lesions of scabies are burrows. The pruritus typically shows nocturnal exacerbations. In adults, the face is often spared. Typical sites involved include the finger webs, the flexor surfaces of the wrists, elbows, axillae, buttocks, and genitalia.

The image below shows an adult S. scabiei mite.

Treatment for scabies:

  • Administration of antihistamines for pruritus
  • Application of topical 5% permethrin and rinsing off after 8–12 hours, with reapplication after 1 week, if required
  • Washing of clothes and linen and anti-scabetic treatment of family members

Related Pearl: Difference between classic and neonatal scabies

  Classic scabies Neonatal scabies
Site of involvement Interdigital webs, trunk, genitals, flexors, sparing of palms and soles, and skin above neck Face, scalp, palm, and soles
Morphology of Lesion Papules, pustules, excoriation, eczematization, burrow Vesicles, pustules, bullae, erosions, and ulcerations
Burrows Present Usually absent

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer complains of high-grade fever with chills, yellowing of skin, retro-orbital pain, and conjunctival suffusion. Examination revealed tenderness of the liver and calf muscles. Lab results show hypokalemia. Which of the following is the test of choice to diagnose this patient?

choices.text: Urine culture in fibroblast cell line
Dark field microscopic examination of the organism
Culture of CSF on blood agar

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation strongly suggests leptospirosis. The best test to confirm the diagnosis in this patient would be to perform serologic testing for anti-leptospiral antibodies.

Leptospirosis, caused by spirochete Leptospira, is a zoonotic infection. Patients with mild disease may present with flu-like symptoms of sudden onset, fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, conjunctival suffusion, and myalgia. The muscle pain usually affects the calves, abdomen, and back. Severe cases of leptospirosis, which can progress rapidly and have a high fatality rate, are associated with Weil's syndrome, characterized by a triad of:

  • Hemorrhage
  • Jaundice
  • Acute kidney injury

The image below shows icterus and conjunctival suffusion in a patient with leptospirosis:

Acute and convalescent sera are tested for anti-leptospiral antibodies to diagnose leptospira. The microscopic agglutination test (MAT) using paired sera (acute and convalescent phases) is the gold standard for detecting antibodies. A four-fold rise in antibody titers between acute and convalescent samples confirms the diagnosis.

Leptospires can be isolated from urine, but culture requires specialized media (e.g., Ellinghausen-McCullough-Johnson-Harris [EMJH] medium) and prolonged incubation (up to 6 weeks) (Option B). Leptospires are motile and can be visualized using dark-field microscopy, but the method is operator-dependent and lacks sensitivity (Option C). While leptospires may be found in the CSF during the first 10 days of illness, blood, and urine are more common diagnostic samples (Option D).

Transmission occurs through cuts or breaks in the skin and mucous membranes (conjunctival and oral mucosa). Several outbreaks have been reported, resulting from exposure to floodwaters contaminated by urine from infected animals. The organism enters the bloodstream and lodges in the parenchymatous organs (liver and kidneys), leading to hemorrhage and tissue necrosis, which causes organ dysfunction. 

Treatment for leptospirosis depends on the severity of the disease. In mild cases, oral doxycycline, ampicillin, or amoxicillin is preferred, and in severe cases, intravenous penicillin, ampicillin, or ceftriaxone is commonly used.

questions.text: Identify the brace given below and its use.

choices.text: Anterior spinal hyperextension brace, Dorso-lumbar injury
Sterno-occipital mandibular immobilization brace, cervical spine injury

questions.solution:
The given image shows a sterno-occipital mandibular immobilization (SOMI) brace which is used for cervical spine injuries.

The SOMI brace contains a rigid anterior chest piece connected to rigid shoulder supports by straps across the patient’s back. The mandibular support can be removed during eating. The brace provides good restriction to flexion.

It is indicated in relatively stable injuries to the lower cervical spine, postoperatively for patients with questionable fixation, or in the treatment of cervicothoracic injuries.

 

Other options:

Option A: Scoliosis and kyphosis can be managed with the Milwaukee brace, also known as a cervical-thoracic-lumbosacral orthosis (CTLSO). It contains a pelvic girdle (pelvic mold), bars (superstructures), and a combination of corrective slings and pads that attach to the superstructure. The pelvic girdle locks onto the waist roll and reduces lumbar lordosis, which helps in kyphosis correction.

The image shown below is the Milwaukee brace.

Option B: Anterior spinal hyperextension brace(ASHE brace) is used in dorsolumbar spinal injury. A hyperextension brace will take the pressure off the weak vertebrae and limit forward bending. It is shown in the image below.

Option C: Taylor brace is indicated for stabilization of the spine in dorsolumbar spinal injury. It is designed to control the upper and lower regions of the spinal column and support the spine while standing, sitting, and walking after spinal surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred irrigating fluid in monopolar-TURP and bipolar-TURP respectively?
questions.solution:
The preferred irrigating fluid for M-TURP and B-TURP are 1.5% isotonic glycine, and Normal saline respectively. 

Monopolar transurethral resection of the prostate (M-TURP) removes tissue with a wire loop that has an electrical current flowing in one direction (monopolar). The surgical site is irrigated with a non-conducting non-ionic fluid as the use of an ionic solution leads to dissipation of the cutting current and poor cutting efficacy. Thus, normal saline and N/5 saline cannot be used.

Bipolar transurethral resection of the prostate (B-TURP) uses a specialized resecting loop that incorporates both the active and the return portions of the circuit on the same electrode and an ionic irrigating solution such as normal saline can be used safely. 

The use of distilled water in TURP leads to the water-intoxication syndrome.

questions.text: Which condition is commonly treated using the surgical procedure in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shown is the Limberg/rhomboid flap used to treat the Pilonidal sinus.

The Limberg/rhomboid flap excises the pilonidal disease in a rhomboid shape and rotates a fascio-cutaneous flap for wound closure.

The pilonidal sinus is an epithelium-lined tract commonly seen in the natal cleft, more in men, usually after puberty. Drivers and hairdressers are most widely affected. The pilonidal sinus opening is usually seen in the midline between the sacrococcygeal joint's level and the coccyx's tip. The other sites that can be affected include the interdigital cleft and axilla.

Treatment includes non-surgical and surgical approaches.

Surgical approaches for the management of pilonidal sinus disease include:

  • Incision and drainage- for pilonidal abscess refractory to medical treatment.
  • Bascom's procedure- incision is made lateral to the midline to gain access to the sinus cavity to remove hair and granulation tissue followed by excision and closure of the midline pits
  • Karydakis procedure- an ovoid area of pathologic tissue is excised parallel to the natal cleft and a fascio-cutaneous flap is mobilized to cover the defect.
  • Others- VY advancement flaps, and Z-plasty.

Non-surgical approaches include conservative treatment with proper hygiene and regular shaving of hair in the area. In case of an abscess- adequate rest, baths, local antiseptic dressings, and broad-spectrum antibiotics are advised.

Fistula-in-ano (Option A) is surgically managed by fistulotomy, fistulectomy, Ligation of the inter-sphincteric fistula tract (LIFT), or setons.

Piles (option C), also known as haemorrhoids, can be internal or external. Treatment includes rubber band ligation, sclerotherapy or haemorrhoidectomy, depending on the degree of the haemorrhoids.

Perianal abscess (option D)- Treatment is drainage of pus and appropriate systemic antibiotics. Conventionally, a cruciate incision over the most fluctuant point is done with the excision of skin edges to de-roof the abscess wall. Excess skin excision should be avoided.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about pre- Bötzinger complex.

choices.text: Acts as a pacemaker for respiration
Dorsal and ventral respiratory neurons project to it
Located in the nucleus parabrachialis of the pons
Produces discharges in phrenic motor neurons

questions.solution:
The pre- Bötzinger complex (pre-BÖTC) is located on either side of the medulla between the nucleus ambiguus and the lateral reticular nucleus. It is a group of pacemaker cells that initiate rhythmic respiration.

These neurons produce rhythmic discharges in phrenic motor neurons. They are also connected to the hypoglossal nuclei, thus involving the tongue in the regulation of airway resistance. NK1 receptors and μ-opioid receptors are present in these neurons. Substance P stimulates and opioids inhibit respiration.

Dorsal and ventral groups of respiratory neurons (DRG and VRG) are present in the dorsal and ventrolateral portions of the medulla respectively. They have projections on the pre-BÖTC pacemaker neurons. 

  • Dorsal group of respiratory neurons (DRG):
    • Located mainly in the nucleus of the tractus solitarius.
    • This group of neurons emits repetitive bursts of inspiratory neuronal action potentials
  • Ventral group of respiratory neurons (VRG):
    • Located in the nucleus ambiguus rostrally and the nucleus retroambiguus caudally.
    • They provide expiratory signals to the abdominal muscles during very heavy expiration.
    • Acts as overdrive mecha­nism when high levels of pulmonary ventilation are required during heavy exercise
    • May contribute to both inspiration and expiration.

Mnemonic DIVE: Dorsal respiratory group for Inspiration and Ventral respiratory group for Expiration.

The pneumotaxic center is located dorsally in the nucleus parabrachialis of the upper pons. The function of the pneumotaxic center is to limit inspiration. It has a secondary effect of increas­ing the rate of respiration because limitation of inspiration also shortens expiration and the entire period of each respiration.

Related Pearl: Respiratory Centres

Respiratory center component

Primary function

Pre-Bőtzinger complex

Pacemaker cells of spontaneous or automatic breathing

Dorsal Respiratory Group (DRG)

Respiratory rhythm generator (inspiratory ramp signal)

Ventral Respiratory Group (VRG)

Overdrive mechanism

Pneumotaxic centre

Controls the “switch off” point of inspiratory ramp signal

Apneustic centre

Delays switch off signal- promotes inspiration

Vagi

Inhibits inspiratory discharge

questions.text:
An infant presents with a history of progressively increasing head circumference, irritability, and vomiting. Imaging reveals the presence of Mickey Mouse ventricles. Choose the correct statements about this patient's condition:
  1. The cause is likely obstruction of CSF flow at the level of the aqueduct of Sylvius.
  2. Leads to increased ICP and subsequent brain damage if not treated.
  3. The preferred diagnostic imaging modality is non-contrast CT of the head.
  4. The condition is associated with a normal-sized fourth ventricle.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of progressively increasing head circumference and imaging showing Mickey Mouse ventricles (ballooning of the frontal horns of the lateral ventricles and third ventricle) suggest Aqueductal Stenosis.

Aqueductal stenosis involves obstruction of the aqueduct of Sylvius. This blockage of the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the third ventricle to the fourth ventricle causes hydrocephalus. Increased intracranial pressure (ICP) from CSF accumulation can cause brain damage and require prompt treatment.

MRI is the preferred imaging modality for aqueductal stenosis, not CT, as it provides detailed visualization of the ventricles and surrounding structures. Aqueductal stenosis usually leads to enlarged lateral and third ventricles, while the fourth ventricle often remains normal-sized (or less affected).

Treatment for aqueductal stenosis includes ventriculostomy, diuretics, and CSF diversion. In severe cases, CSF diversion procedures (shunting), may be necessary to redirect the flow of CSF and relieve pressure on the brain.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman is declared brain dead shortly after arriving at the emergency department following a road traffic accident. A junior doctor observes some movements in the patient and reports them to the consultant, who explains that certain autonomic reflexes can persist despite the absence of brainstem function. Which of the following findings is NOT compatible with the diagnosis of brain death?
questions.solution:
The junior doctor has likely noticed some spinal movements in the brain-dead patient. These movements should not be mistaken as evidence of brainstem function. Pathological flexion is not a brain-death-associated autonomic reflex.

Pathologic flexion is an abnormal reflex that involves the flexion of a limb in response to a stimulus. Pathologic flexion can be a sign of an upper motor neuron lesion. eg- Positive Babinski sign.

The spinal cord is a source of movement of the brain-dead body. Within the spinal cord, neuronal networks exist that serve as the origin of specific motor patterns. Supraspinal disconnection of these tracts may increase their excitability at the spinal level, resulting in spinal movements during brain death. However, this possibility has not been thoroughly studied, and the exact physiology is yet to be described. 

The American Academy of Neurology has established criteria for the diagnosis of brain death which includes certain movements as acceptable findings that should not be misinterpreted as evidence for brainstem function: 

1. Spontaneous movements of limbs other than pathological flexion or extension response. 

2. Respiratory-like movements (shoulder elevation and adduction, back arching, intercostal expansion without significant tidal volumes). 

3. Sweating, blushing, tachycardia. 

4. Normal blood pressure without pharmacological support or sudden increases in blood pressure. 

5. Absence of diabetes insipidus. 

6. Deep tendon reflexes, superficial abdominal reflexes, triple flexion response. 

7. Babinski reflex

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling in the great toe. The microscopic examination of urine is shown below. What is the type of stone seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows crystals of varying shapes (rhomboids or parallelograms), suggesting uric acid stones. A patient with gout is at a higher risk of developing uric acid stones.

Gout is a hyperuricemic metabolic condition, typically manifested by episodic inflammatory arthritis due to crystal formation and deposition of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals within the joints and connective tissue.

Acute recurrent gout flare is characterized by painful, warm, red, tender, and substantially swollen joints. The metatarsophalangeal joint of the first toe is involved in 70–90% of cases (podagra), followed by tarsal joints, ankles, and knees. 

The main risk factors for uric acid stones are low urine pH and higher uric acid excretion. Therefore, the mainstay of prevention of uric acid stone formation is alkalinizing urine and reducing intake of purine-containing foods as uric acid is the end product of purine metabolism. Uric acid excretion can be reduced by the use of a xanthine oxidase inhibitor such as allopurinol or febuxostat. 

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

Related Pearl: Radiolucent Renal Stones

Radiolucent Renal Stones

Mnemonic: X UTI

  • Xanthine
  • Uric Acid (most common)

Drug induced renal stones

  • Triamterene
  • Indinavir

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents with increasing fatigue, bone pain and is found to be anemic. Physical examination reveals a hard 1-cm nodule in the prostate and the PSA level is elevated. Peripheral blood smear findings include occasional myelocytes, a few tear-drop red blood cells (RBCs)  and two nucleated RBCs per 100 white cells. Erythrocytes are normochromic and normocytic. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a patient suspected to have metastatic prostate cancer now presenting with normocytic normochromic anemia with a leukoerythroblastic picture and tear-drop-shaped RBCs on the peripheral smear, a diagnosis of myelophthisic anemia is most likely.

Myelophthisic anemia is a form of marrow failure in which space-occupying lesions replace normal bone marrow elements. The most common cause is metastatic cancer, most often carcinomas arising from the breast, lung, and prostate. Myelophthisic anemia can also be seen in the spent phase of myeloproliferative neoplasms.

Infiltration of the bone marrow leads to fibrosis and structural distortion. This disturbs the normal mechanisms by which RBCs and WBCs come out from the bone marrow into the blood. This leads to the premature release of nucleated erythroid precursors and immature granulocytic forms. This is referred to as a leukoerythroblastic picture. Moreover, dacrocytes (tear-shaped RBCs) are also seen; they are formed due to their deformation during release from the bone marrow.

Due to fibrosis and structural distortion of bone marrow, extramedullary hematopoiesis occurs in the liver and spleen, leading to hepatomegaly and splenomegaly.

The image given below shows a leukoerythroblastic blood picture with nucleated RBCs, tear-drop cells, and immature myeloid cells:

Other options:

Option A: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA) is caused due to trauma to RBCs inside the blood vessels. The hemolysis is a result of the shear forces which act on the RBCs. This occurs in prosthetic heart valves, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). These disorders lead to luminal narrowing and thrombus formation and thus cause mechanical damage to the RBCs. MAHA shows schistocytes or helmet cells on peripheral smear.

Option C: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia is caused by antibody and complement-mediated RBC destruction. The diagnosis of autoimmune hemolytic anemia requires direct and indirect Coombs test.

Option D: Aplastic anemia refers to primary bone marrow failure and consequent pancytopenia. Although aplastic anemia also presents with normocytic normochromic anemia, it will not show a leukoerythroblastic picture in the peripheral smear. Hepatomegaly and Splenomegaly are not seen in aplastic anemia.

questions.text:
A patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus just underwent hernioplasty. All his oral diabetic drugs were given until the day before surgery. Few hours later he complained of abdominal pain and was hypotensive. His lab results are given below. Which of the following drugs would have caused this ?

Random blood surgar : 106 mg/dL

Urine ketone : +++
questions.solution:
The immediate postoperative features, along with a normal blood glucose value, suggest euglycemic ketoacidosis. If SGLT-2 inhibitors like empagliflozin are not stopped 24 hours before elective surgery, postoperative euglycemic ketoacidosis can occur.

SGLT-2 inhibitors act by inhibiting the reabsorption of glucose in the kidney, depriving the body of glucose to the extent that ketone bodies start to be utilized as energy sources. Hence, all other oral hypoglycemic agents can be stopped on the day of surgery except SGLT-2 inhibitors.

SGLT-2 inhibitors must be stopped:

  • 24 hours before an elective surgery
  • 72 hours before intermediate to high-risk surgery

Linagliptin (option A) is a DPP-4 inhibitor that can cause hypersensitivity reactions and pancreatitis.

Glipizide (option B) is a sulfonylurea that can cause hypoglycemia and weight gain.

Liraglutide (option D) is a GLP-1 agonist that can cause pancreatitis.

questions.text:
Which of the following would be seen in a patient with complete androgen insensitivity?
  1. Normal pubic and axillary hair
  2. 46 XX karyotype
  3. Very Low testosterone levels
  4. Absent uterus
  5. Normal breasts
questions.solution:
Absent uterus and normal breasts would be seen in patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome. 

Androgen insensitivity syndrome is an X-Linked Recessive condition in which there is a decrease in the function of the androgen receptor. The karyotype is 46, XY and affected individuals have normal male levels of testosterone, but the lack of receptor response to testosterone is responsible for the manifestations. Hence, gonad is testis and the uterus is absent. The pubic and axillary hair are sparse since they are androgen dependent. But, breast development is normal.

Presentation Mullerian agenesis  Androgen insensitivity /Testicular feminization syndrome 
Inheritance pattern Sporadic  X-linked recessive
Karyotype  46, XX 46, XY
Breast development  Yes  Yes
Axillary and pubic hair Yes No
Uterus Absent Absent
Gonad Ovary Testis (Intraabdominal)
Testosterone  Female levels Male levels
Associated anomaly Yes  No

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with a probable patellar fracture following an injury to his left knee. The X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is ideal for the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray shows an undisplaced patella fracture. Undisplaced fractures are treated with a cylinder cast extending from the groin to just above the malleoli, with the knee in full extension, for at least 3 weeks.

A patellar fracture occurs due to trauma or injury, often from a direct blow to the knee or a fall. It is commonly seen in sports injuries or accidents, but it can also occur from a sudden, forceful contraction of the quadriceps muscle, which can cause the patella to fracture transversely. The injury can range from a simple, undisplaced crack to a more complex, comminuted fracture.

The clinical presentation of a patellar fracture typically includes pain, swelling, and inability to fully extend the knee, known as extensor lag, due to disruption of the quadriceps tendon. In some cases, bruising or a palpable gap between bone fragments may be noted, particularly in displaced fractures.

The management of a patellar fracture depends on the type of fracture: 

  • Undisplaced fractures: Treated with a cylinder cast extending from the groin to just above the malleoli, with the knee in full extension, for at least 3 weeks.
  • Transverse fractures: Surgical reduction using tension-band wiring and K-wire fixation, followed by extensor retinaculum repair and physiotherapy. Followed by a cylinder cast for 4-6 weeks.
    • If reduction is not possible: Total Patellectomy and extensor retinaculum repair
    • If one of the fragments makes only one pole of the patella: Partial Patellectomy (major fragment is preserved followed by extensor retinaculum repair) 
  • Comminuted fractures: Total Patellectomy

Related Pearl: Tension Band Wiring

A tension band wire is a form of internal fixation used to convert distraction forces into compression forces, promoting bone healing.

It is used in:

  • Fracture patella
  • Fracture olecranon 
  • Fracture lateral malleolus
  • Fracture greater trochanter

The below image shows tension band wiring for a fracture olecranon

questions.text:
Match the given urea cycle disorders to their respective properties
 Enzyme defect  Findings

i)N-Acetyl Glutamate Synthase

 a)Raised orotic acid and pyrimidine excretion in urine
ii)Ornithine Transcarbamylase b)Raised ornithine levels along with raised ammonia 
iii)HHH syndrome c)Raised citrulline levels
iv)Citrin transporter d)Raised ammonia with raised non-specific amino acids and normal orotic acid levels
questions.solution:
The correct matching sequence is i-d; ii-a; iii-b; iv-c.

Enzyme Defect Findings
i) N-Acetyl Glutamate Synthase d) Raised ammonia with raised non-specific amino acids and normal orotic acid levels.
ii) Ornithine Transcarbamylase a) Raised orotic acid and pyrimidine excretion in urine
iii) HHH Syndrome b) Raised ornithine levels along with raised ammonia
iv) Citrin Transporter c) Raised citrulline levels

N-Acetyl Glutamate Synthase (NAGS) - NAGS deficiency causes a defect in the CPS I (Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase I) enzyme, leading to hyperammonemia and accumulation of non-specific amino acids (such as glutamine) without elevated orotic acid or pyrimidine excretion in urine.

Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC)- OTC deficiency leads to the accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate, which is shunted into the pyrimidine biosynthesis pathway. This results in orotic acidemia and pyrimidine excretion in the urine, which is characteristic of the disorder.

HHH Syndrome (Hyperornithinemia, Hyperammonemia, and Homocitrullinemia)- is caused by a defective ornithine transporter. This results in hyperornithinemia and hyperammonemia.

Citrin Transporter (Citrin Deficiency)- A defect in the citrin transporter leads to citrullinemia type 2, which has elevated citrulline levels.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: Antibodies formed in the spleen that are directed against the cell surface antigens GpIIb/IIIa or GpIb/IX are characteristically seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
In Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), antibodies are formed in the spleen against the cell-surface antigens GpIIb/IIIa or GpIb/IX, causing increased peripheral destruction of platelets.

Clinically, ITP may be divided into an acute form and a chronic form. Both clinical types of ITP are associated with the development of antiplatelet antibodies, mainly against the platelet antigens GpIIb/IIIa and GpIb/IX.

The acute form is more commonly seen in children following a viral infection, while the chronic form is more often seen in adult women of childbearing years. Most individuals with ITP are asymptomatic, but if the platelet count drops low enough, they may develop petechial hemorrhages or epistaxis, usually after an upper respiratory infection.

Related Pearl: Idiopathic/Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

It is characterized by

  • Isolated thrombocytopenia—the presence of antibody against platelet membrane glycoprotein and subsequent destruction in reticuloendothelial system
  • Normal bone marrow—normal or even increased number of megakaryocytes
  • Absence of other causes of thrombocytopenia. 

Types:

Acute (<6 months) and chronic (>6 months) idiopathic/immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the ER after she had a road traffic accident 2 hours ago. On examination, she opens her eyes when called by name, responds appropriately to questions, and follows commands by raising her hands and showing her tongue. The emergency physician asks how urgently a CT scan should be performed. What is your advice?

choices.text: Within 8 hours, as the GCS is < 15
Within 1 hour, as the GCS is < 13
Within 1 hour, as the GCS is < 15

questions.solution:
The NICE guidelines indicate that a CT scan should be performed for all patients with a head injury with a GCS < 15 at 2 hours after the injury.

The patient has an eye response to verbal stimulus (+3), is able to obey commands (+6), and is oriented (+5). Hence, her GCS score is 3+6+5 = 14. As the GCS is < 15 at 2 hours since the injury, this girl would require a CT scan of the head within 1 hour of arrival at the hospital.

Note: A CT scan within 1 hour is indicated for a patient with a GCS < 13 at any point of time, and a GCS < 15 after 2 hours of the injury.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A patient is admitted for evaluation of recurrent deep venous thrombosis. There is no history of any medical illness. All of the following investigations can be done for evaluating this patient except:
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of recurrent DVT in a patient warrants further investigation of the cause of deep venous thrombosis (DVT). DVT can occur in hypercoagulable states caused by either deficiency of protein C or antithrombin III or factor V of Leiden mutation.

Antibodies to factor VIII causes deficiency of factor VIII leading to haemophilia (bleeding disorder).

Deep vein thrombosis:

 i.   Sites:

  1. Pelvic veins
  2. Leg veins—common in femoral and popliteal veins (common on the left side).

ii.   Features of DVT:

  • Fever- earliest
  • Tense, tender, warm, pale/bluish, shiny swelling calf
  • Positive Homan’s, Mose’s, or Neuhof’s signs
  • Inverted champagne bottle sign
  • Features of pulmonary embolism

iii.   Treatment:

  • Rest, the elevation of the limb, bandaging the entire limb with
  • crepe bandage.
  • Anticoagulants: Heparin/low molecular weight
  • Warfarin, phenindione.
  • Palma operation
  • May-Husni operation

iv.   Investigations:

  • Venous Doppler with duplex scanning
  • Haemogram with platelet count
  • D-dimer assays
  • MR Venography 
  • Ventilation-perfusion scanning

Choice of prophylaxis: 

  • Major trauma, abdominal and orthopedic surgeries warrants a longer duration of postoperative immobilization. The pharmacological method is efficacious in these situations.

  • Patients who are expected to be up and walking within 24 to 48 hours after minor trauma, operations are at low risk for the development of venous thrombosis. The mechanical method is advised in these situations. The simplest method is for the patient to walk. Activation of the calf pump mechanism is an effective means of prophylaxis.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Venous Thromboembolism

The risk factors for venous thromboembolism (pulmonary embolism and DVT) are as follows:

  • Major trauma like spinal cord injury or fracture of lower limb
  • Surgery like hip or knee replacement
  • Hospitalization for heart failure or atrial fibrillation/flutter within last 3 months
  • Myocardial infarction within last 3 months
  • Previous venous thromboembolism
  • Infections and inflammatory bowel disease
  • Autoimmune diseases:
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (APLA)
    • SLE
  • Inherited thrombophilias:
    • Factor V leiden mutation
    • Deficiency of antithrombin III
    • Deficiency of protein C or protein S
  • Hypercoagulable states:
    • Pregnancy and postpartum period
    • COPD
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Polycythemia vera
    • Malignancies
  • Iatrogenic:
    • OCPs
    • Hormone replacement therapy
    • Chemotherapeutic drugs
    • Insertion of central venous lines
  • Varicose veins
  • Prolonged car or air travel.

questions.text:
An HIV patient came to the clinic with a history of diarrhoea. The stool sample subjected to Kinyoun staining revealed 4-6 µm structures as shown below. Which of the following statements are true with regard to the causative organism?
  1. The sporulated oocyst is round and contains four sporozoites.
  2. Unsporulated cyst is the diagnostic form.
  3. It has a monoxenous life cycle.
  4. Sporulation of the oocyst occurs in the soil.
  5. Nitazoxanide is used for the treatment.
questions.solution:
Statements 1,3,5 (Option C) are correct.

In the given clinical scenario, the presence of diarrhoea in an immunocompromised patient with stool sample showing Kinyoun stain-positive oocysts of size 4-6 µm is suggestive of cryptosporidiosis.

Cryptosporidium is a coccidian parasite implicated in causing traveller's diarrhea in immunocompromised patients. The two cryptosporidium species responsible are C. hominis and C. parvum. The parasite has a monoxenous life cycle where it completes both sexual and asexual phases in a single host which is a man.

Both the infective and diagnostic forms are sporulated oocysts. Sporulation occurs inside the host cell and each sporulated oocyst is round and contains four sporozoites. The oocyst excreted in the patient's feces, can be acquired through drinking water or recreational water activities. The oocysts are immediately infectious (unlike isospora oocysts, which require maturation), and may cause autoinfection.

Once ingested, the 4 sporozoites are released from each cyst and attach to the small intestinal mucosa. It causes crampy abdominal pain and non-inflammatory watery diarrhea.

Because of their small size, they are difficult to see using routine staining and hence, acid-fast staining is done.

Treatment is mainly supportive, though nitazoxanide has been approved for use in cryptosporidium infection.

Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

Property  Cryptosporidium Cyclospora Cystoisospora
Sporulated oocyst 4-6 μm, round,  contains four sporozoites 8-12 μm, round, contains 2 sporocysts each having two sporozoites 23-36 μm, oval, contain two sporocysts, each having four sporozoites.
Acid-fast detection  Uniformly acid-fast Variable acid-fast Uniformly acid-fast
Sporulation of the oocyst Occurs inside the host cell Occurs in soil Occurs in soil
Diagnostic form Sporulated cyst Unsporulated cyst Unsporulated oocyst

The below image shows oocysts of Cyclospora cayetanensis in the modified acid-fast stain. 

The below image shows oocysts of Cystoisospora in the modified acid-fast stain. 

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms of various protozoa

questions.text: Which type of von Willebrand disease is characterized by the following pedigree chart along with the complete absence of the von Willebrand factor?
questions.solution:
The given pedigree depicts an Autosomal recessive type of inheritance pattern. Type 3 von Willebrand disease has an Autosomal Recessive inheritance pattern along with the complete absence of the von Willebrand factor.

In the above pedigree chart, both males and females are carriers (equally affected) which indicates an autosomal pattern. Parents are unaffected (both are carriers/heterozygotes), and no affected members in other generations. 25% of the children are normal, 50% are carriers, and only 25% are affected. This indicates a recessive pattern. 

Von Willebrand disease

 Defect

Inheritance

 Mutation
Type 1 Quantitative (mild to moderate deficiency of vWF) Autosomal dominant Point mutation interfering with the maturation of vWF

Type 2 (2A 2B 2M 2N)

2A is the most common type

 Qualitative (normal quantity of vWF)

Autosomal dominant is the most common. Rarely autosomal recessive

 Missense mutations leading to defective multimer assembly
Type 3 Quantitative (complete absence of vWF) Autosomal recessive Frameshift mutation or deletion

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents to the emergency department with painless vaginal bleeding. Sonography reveals velamentous chord insertion, and  CTG shows the following pattern. The obstetrician collects the blood to perform a diagnostic test. Identify the test and its principle among the options given below:
questions.solution:
The given scenario of antenatal painless bleeding per vagina, velamentous cord insertion, and sinusoidal pattern on CTG points towards vasa previa. An Apt test (alkali denaturation test) is used to confirm that the source of the bleeding is fetal blood vessels.

Vasa previa is a presentation in which part of the membrane with the vessels lies in front of the presenting part and above the internal os. The umbilical vessels traverse unsupported by Wharton jelly before entering the placenta and are more prone to damage. Vaginal bleeding due to velamentous insertion of the placenta is often associated with fetal distress - tachycardia, sinusoidal FHR tracing.

The Apt test is an alkali denaturation test to detect fetal haemoglobin (HbF). A positive Apt test suggests that the blood is fetal. It is based on the principle that HbF is resistant to alkali denaturation, while HbA is not. The test is performed by collecting the blood sample in a test tube containing water and adding NaOH. Maternal blood turns yellow-brown, while fetal blood remains pink in the test tube. Colour flow Doppler can also be used for diagnosis.

If diagnosed before bleeding occurs, the patient can be managed by elective C-section before the onset of labour. Bleeding leads to fetal exsanguination and must be managed immediately with an emergency C-section. 

The Kleihauer–Betke test (or acid elution test) quantitates (Option D) the amount of feto-maternal haemorrhage to calculate the dosage of anti-D required in Rh-negative mothers.

questions.text: The technique known as "ChIP-Seq" is primarily used for:

choices.text: Identifying the binding sites of DNA-binding proteins
Measuring the folding patterns of proteins
Visualizing protein interactions in living cells

questions.solution:
"ChIP-Seq" is primarily used to identify the binding sites of DNA-binding proteins.

ChIP-seq (Chromatin Immunoprecipitation Sequencing) is used to identify the binding sites of DNA-binding proteins, such as transcription factors, chromatin remodelers, or any protein that interacts with DNA. It can also be used to map histone modifications and other chromatin-related features.

Chromatin Immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-Seq) is used to study protein-DNA interactions.

ChIP-Seq directly sequences immunopurified DNAs using Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) methods. Two variants of ChIP-Seq are "standard" ChIP-Seq and ChIP-Exo. These two approaches vary in their ability to resolve and map the locations of the bound protein on genomic DNA.

In the standard ChIP-Seq, the immunopurified DNA is directly subjected to NGS/ high-throughput DNA sequencing whereas in ChIP-Exo the immunopurified, cross-linked protein-DNA complex is treated with exonucleases to remove cross-linked DNA sequences that are not in intimate contact with the protein of interest. ChIP-Exo has the added advantage of allowing investigators to map in vivo protein occupancy at single nucleotide-level resolution.

Other Options:

Option B: X-ray crystallography, nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy, and cryo-electron microscopy are the techniques used to determine the folding patterns of proteins.

Option C: Metabolomic profiling is most often performed using either nuclear magnetic resonance or mass-spectrometry.

Option D: Fluorescence Microscopy is the most common technique used to visualize protein interactions in living cells.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the OPD with finely mottled, raindrop pigmentation on the flexures, temples, eyelids, and neck. Aldrich-Mees lines are present in the fingernails. A particular type of poisoning is suspected. Which of the following enzymes of the Glycolysis pathway is inhibited by the suspected poison?
questions.solution:
Finely mottled, raindrop pigmentation appearing on the skin of flexures, temples, eyelids, neck, and fingernails showing Aldrich-Mees lines are suggestive of Chronic Arsenic poisoning. Arsenic inhibits the enzyme - Phosphoglycerate kinase (which converts 1,3 bisphosphoglycerate to 3-phosphoglycerate).

There are several types of arsenic poisoning:

  • Fulminant - When massive doses are rapidly absorbed, death occurs in 1–3 hours due to shock and peripheral vascular failure.
  • Gastrointestinal - This is the most common form of acute poisoning and resembles bacterial food poisoning. There is a constriction in the throat and difficulty in swallowing. The stools are dark-colored, foul smelling, and bloody initially and later take a colorless odorless watery form similar to the rice-water stools of cholera.
  • Chronic poisoning - It occurs due to repeated daily exposure. The main features include finely mottled, raindrop pigmentation that appears on the skin of flexures, temples, eyelids, and neck. In prolonged contact, hyperkeratosis of the palms and soles occurs along with the development of a transverse white line in the fingernails called the Aldrich-Mees lines.

Tests to detect arsenic poisoning:

  • 24-hour urinary excretion of arsenic
  • Detection of arsenic by atomic absorption spectroscopy
  • Marsh and Reinsch's tests are now considered obsolete.

The preferred treatment option is freshly prepared hydrated ferric oxide, which converts toxic arsenic to non-toxic ferric arsenite. DMSA (Succimer), British anti-Lewisite (BAL), and penicillamine can also be used.

Related Pearl: Inhibitors of metabolic pathways

questions.text:
A young woman was brought to the emergency department after she had an episode of syncope. Her heart rate was 50 beats per minute. ECG was taken immediately and is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?

AV - atrioventricular
questions.solution:
This patient's symptoms of syncope with bradycardia are suggestive of a Stokes-Adams attack. ECG findings of the atrioventricular block with RBBB suggest the diagnosis of Mobitz type II block.

In the given ECG, the PR segment remains the same in each successive cycle. However, some P waves are not followed by QRS complexes, which means that some of the P waves are blocked. This is typical of Mobitz type II block. The other finding present is a right bundle branch block that is seen as a wide QRS and rsR' pattern in V1 - V3.

Stokes Adam's attack refers to the syncopal attack resulting from bradycardia or asystole.

Atrioventricular (AV) blocks can be of three types based on ECG appearance:

  • First-degree AV block occurs due to the slowing of conduction within the AV node. 
    • The ECG will show a fixed prolongation of PR interval that is more than 200ms.
  • Second-degree AV block occurs due to the intermittent failure of impulse conduction from the atrium to the ventricle. They can be of two types:
    • Mobitz type I/Wenckebach block is seen as a progressive lengthening of the PR interval followed by an absence of one QRS complex (non-conducted P wave).
    • Mobitz type II block occurs due to an infranodal pathology. Here the PR intervals are fixed, but, there are intermittent non-conducted P waves. 
  • Third-degree AV block/complete heart block (CHB) occurs when none of the impulses from the atria is conducted to the ventricles.
    • The ECG shows complete AV dissociation, which means that there is no relation between the P waves and QRS complexes.

AV node block can occur due to myocardial infarction, fibrosis, sclerosis, and cardiac infiltrative diseases. Iatrogenic causes include cardiac valvular surgery and drugs like digoxin, beta-blockers, verapamil, and diltiazem. 

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

Related Pearl: Adult Bradycardia with Pulse Algorithm

When a patient is in bradyarrhythmia typically with a heart rate of <50 bpm the initial intervention consists of identifying and treating the underlying cause. This includes: 

  • Maintaining a patent airway and assisting breathing as necessary
  • Administering oxygen if hypoxemic
  • Attaching cardiac monitor to identify rhythm; monitor blood pressure and oximetry
  • IV access
  • 12-Lead ECG 

If the bradyarrhythmia is persisent causing hemodynamic instability, then the management is as depicted by the flowchart (based on the AHA guidelines) below:

questions.text: A 38-year-old man came to the orthopedic outpatient clinic with a high stepping gait and is found to have a fracture at the neck of the fibula on an X-ray. This is associated with a loss of sensation in which of the following area/areas of the foot?
questions.solution:
A fracture at the neck of the fibula and a high stepping gait (foot drop) suggests injury to the common fibular nerve. This is associated with loss of sensation over the dorsum of the foot (marked 4) and the first interdigital space (marked 1). 

The nerves supplying the marked areas are shown below.

The common fibular nerve is derived from the dorsal branches of the 4th and 5th lumbar and 1st and 2nd sacral ventral rami. It runs obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa to the fibular head. It lies between the biceps femoris and the lateral head of the gastrocnemius. It then curves laterally around the neck of the fibula and gets divided into superficial and deep fibular nerves. 

The first interdigital space is supplied by the deep fibular nerve while the dorsum of the foot (except lateral and medial borders) is supplied by the superficial fibular nerve.

  Superficial fibular nerve Deep fibular nerve
Motor innervation
  • Peroneus longus
  • Peroneus Brevis
  • Extensor digitorum longus
  • Extensor hallucis longus
  • Tibialis anterior
  • Peroneus tertius
Sensory innervation
  • Lateral aspect of the lower leg
  • Dorsum of the toes except for the lateral side of the 5th toe and the first interdigital webspace

 
  • The first interdigital space
 

 

Injury to the common peroneal nerve at the level of the neck of the fibula causes foot drop. Ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and eversion of the foot are lost, while the inversion and plantar flexion are usually preserved. Sensory innervation to the dorsum of the foot, including the first web space, is lost. The ankle reflex is usually preserved.

Other options:

Area 2 represents the lateral aspect of the foot which is supplied by the sural nerve.

Area 3 represents the medial aspect of the foot which is supplied by the saphenous nerve.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with ongoing generalized tonic-clonic seizures for last 15 minutes. After securing the airway, providing oxygen, and checking vital signs, intravenous Lorazepam 0.1 mg/kg is administered. However, seizures persist even after the repeat dose of Lorazepam in 5 minutes. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Administer an additional dose of Lorazepam

questions.solution:
In the management of Status epilepticus, if benzodiazepines fail, Fosphenytoin (20 mg/kg IV) is the next drug of choice.

Fosphenytoin stabilises neuronal membranes by blocking sodium channels, effectively preventing further seizure activity. It has fewer cardiovascular side effects compared to phenytoin and is easier to administer quickly.

Other options:

Option A: Lorazepam (0.1–0.15 mg/kg IV) is the initial drug of choice for status epilepticus. It has a rapid onset and longer duration of action compared to Diazepam. If the seizures persist, administering additional Lorazepam is not recommended, as the protocol suggests transitioning to a second-line antiepileptic after the failure of the initial benzodiazepine dose.

Option C: Phenobarbital is reserved for refractory cases where seizures persist after both benzodiazepines and fosphenytoin. It acts by potentiating GABAergic inhibition but is associated with significant sedation and respiratory depression, requiring airway management.

Option D: Lidocaine infusion is used in refractory status epilepticus when seizures are not controlled after the above steps and seizures persist beyond 48 hours.

questions.text: Identify the chart given in the picture below.
questions.solution:
The chart in the picture is the teller chart.

The teller chart is a preferential acuity test. It is an objective test. It tests visual acuity in children (1-3 years) and people with disabilities. It consists of 17 cards, with one half having a black-and-white bar and the other half having a uniform grey background.

Other options:

Option A: The ETDRS chart (The early treatment diabetic retinopathy study) presents a series of five letters of equal difficulty on each row, with standardized spacing between letters and rows. It consists of 14 lines with 70 letters. The chart is also used to test visual acuity. Below is an image of the ETDRS chart.

Option B: The Pelli-Robson contrast sensitivity letter chart consists of letters of constant size but decreasing contrast. The patient views it from a distance of 1 meter until the lowest resolvable group of three letters on the chart is reached. The chart measures contrast sensitivity, which is the ability to distinguish an object from its background. An image of the Pelli-Robson chart used in the Middle East is given below.

Option D: Landolt C chart works on the same principle as Snellen’s chart and is used to test visual acuity but for illiterate patients. An image of the Landolt C chart is given below.

questions.text:
Which of the following findings would be consistent with a diagnosis of Chediak-Higashi syndrome?

1. Giant inclusions in polymorphonuclear neutrophils
2. Peripheral Neuropathy
3. Oculocutaneous hyperpigmentation
4. Recurrent pyogenic infections
questions.solution:
The findings consistent with Chediak-Higashi syndrome are represented by Statements 1, 2, 4 (Option D):

  • Giant inclusions in polymorphonuclear neutrophils,
  • progressive intellectual decline
  • recurrent pyogenic infections.
  • Oculocutaneous hypopigmentation (not hyperpigmentation)

Chediak-Higashi syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to the loss of function of the LYST gene (Lysosomal trafficking regulator gene)- a protein required for the normal packaging and distribution of granules. This defect results in defective chemotaxis, phagolysosome fusion, degranulation of T-cells and NK cells, and ADP granule function in platelets.

Clinical features occur due to defective transport of cell products. These are neutropenia, significant pyogenic infections, oculo-cutaneous albinism (due to abnormalities of melanocytes), neurological abnormalities (peripheral neuropathy, progressive intellectual decline, cranial nerve palsies, decreased deep tendon reflexes, tremor, abnormal gait, nerve cell dysfunction), and bleeding.

The image below shows Wright-Giemsa staining of a peripheral blood smear showing polymorphonuclear leukocytes with abundant giant intracytoplasmic granules.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

Disease

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the correct sequence of completion of events after transection of a nerve -
  1. Myelin sheath degeneration
  2. Chromatolytic reaction
  3. Regenerative sprouting
  4. Denervation hypersensitivity
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the correct sequence is 1-2-3-4 (option A)

Wallerian degeneration is a type of orthograde degeneration triggered by an injury to the axon. These changes occur from the point of injury in the neuron and move towards the nerve terminal, thereby interrupting the functional neural transmission. 

The sequence of changes that occur:

  • Myelin sheath degeneration distal to the injury.
  • Proximal axon degeneration (retrograde - from the axon to the cell body)
  • Chromatolysis reaction- Swelling of the cell body, eccentrically placed nucleus, and fragmentation of the rough endoplasmic reticulum
  • Regenerative sprouting - neurons regrow projecting multiple small, branches. 
  • Sometimes when a motor nerve is injured, there is a marked proliferation of the nicotinic receptors making them extremely sensitive. This is known as denervation hypersensitivity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man was trapped under a 40-meter landslide for 7 hours. Upon admission to the ER, his left leg was painful as shown in the image below and his renal parameters were deranged. Which of the following is not done in treating this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient trapped in a landslide with a painful leg and deranged renal parameters is suggestive of crush syndrome. In these patients, an early fasciotomy is preferred over a late fasciotomy as it can decompress muscle compartments and thereby reduce the need for amputation. 

A late fasciotomy can lead to a massive release of myoglobin and also lead to infection of the dead tissue. It is best not to perform fasciotomy where the patient has been entrapped for more than 12 hours as muscles of the compartment are likely to be dead and can lead to massive release of vasoactive mediators during debridement.

Crush syndrome occurs due to prolonged compression of a limb leading to myonecrosis and decreased perfusion. When the limb is freed, vasoactive mediators and myoglobin are released. There is associated renal vasoconstriction and ischemia which can lead to renal failure.

Management of crush syndrome includes:

  • Aggressive fluid resuscitation, ideally until myoglobin is not detectable in urine (Option A)
  • The bladder should be catheterized to measure urine output
  • Administration of mannitol may reduce the reperfusion component (Option D) 
  • Renal hemofiltration if there is oliguria or renal failure(Option C)
